DOC.HEAD: Nurses Stage Nationwide Protest Against Working Conditions
DOC.TEXT: About 100,000 nurses have staged a day of strikes and protests nationwide, demanding an end to low pay, long hours and overwork that they say causes many to quit after a few years. The strikes Friday were the first in 21 years by the 170,000-member Japan Federation of Medical Workers Unions. The federation wants more nurses hired at more than 1,000 medical institutions, said spokeswoman Seishi Katsuragi. Daylong strikes were held Friday at 522 private hospitals, Ms. Katsuragi said. Because strikes are illegal for workers at national institutions, nurses at the National Cancer Center Research Institute handed out leaflets and gathered for a rally before work hours. Ms. Katsuragi said the number of nurses employed needs to double to about 1.5 million - about the number of registered nurses in the country. However, many prospective nurses refuse to work for the low pay. Their starting salary is about $1,160 a month; they want $1,230. Nurses also get bonuses totaling about 4{ months' pay in two installments each year. Now, the union federation says, most nurses must work late into their pregnancies and nearly 70 percent have problematic pregnancies as a result. Often two nurses must take care of 50 patients at night, according to the group's study. Toshihiro Kitagawa, secretary-general of the National Medical Labor Union, which staged the protest at the National Cancer Center Research Institute in Tokyo, said many of the nurses are working three hours of overtime daily. ``Many nurses quit after about three years because they cannot take the low pay, long hours and hard work,'' said Masahiko Kodama, another union leader at the hospital. Hospital management has not made any counter-offers, and the federation says its members will strike again Nov. 27 if there is no progress in negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Tells Prosecutors To Refile 22 Of 42 Counts Against Keating
With PM-Senators-Keating
DOC.TEXT: Shabby writing spurred a judge to order the dismissal of more than half the securities fraud charges against Lincoln Savings and Loan tycoon Charles H. Keating Jr. unless prosecutors can whip them into shape. Twenty-two of the 42 counts Keating faces were flawed, Superior Court Judge Lance Ito ruled Friday, saying 20 of the poorly written charges do not mention a crime. Ito gave federal prosecutors until Nov. 19 to submit a revised indictment. The next hearing was set for Dec. 3. Those 20 counts allege defendants Keating, former Lincoln presidents Ray C. Fidel and Robin S. Symes, and American Continental president Judy J. Wischer sold junk bonds in ways that exceeded authority given them by the state Department of Corporations. The department also approved the bond sales. The law under which the four are charged states only that it is against the law to sell bonds without getting Department of Corporations authority. Since they had it, the judge reasoned, that law could not apply. Another count that Ito jeopardized alleges the defendants published advertising for a bond sale without properly filing a copy of the ad with the state Department of Corporations. The final count Ito questioned as flawed alleges they lied to the department. The junk bond sales occurred at branches of Lincoln, the Irvine-based thrift whose $2 billion failure may become the costliest ever to taxpayers. The bonds became worthless in spring 1989 when Phoenix-based American Continental filed for bankruptcy protection and regulators seized Lincoln. Keating spent 33 days in jail until he was allowed to post a reduced bond of $300,000 last month. The defendants are accused of deceiving investors about the safety of $250 million in the now-worthless bonds. Many elderly buyers lost their life savings. If convicted, the four each could receive maximum 10-year prison terms. Keating, in a phone call from Phoenix, said he was ``elated'' Friday. ``We've said all along that we didn't do anything illegal,'' he said. Prosecutors and defense attorneys disagreed over how severe a blow the government suffered in its case. It is the first criminal prosecution stemming from the collapse of Lincoln and its parent American Continental. ``I think in this case unfortunately the district attorney cut too many corners,'' said Abbe Lowell, who represents Wischer. ``If they think they can now cut and paste and succeed in doing what they did before, let them try.'' But prosecutors characterized the problems as technical and said they believed revised charges would stand. Deputy District Attorney William Hodgman said he would address some of the judge's concerns by being more specific about charges, probably by adding additional counts. Stephen C. Neal, Keating's attorney, said the defense would challenge whatever charges survive on grounds of insufficient evidence. Prosecutors must prove that the four defendants are guilty even though they did not personally sell any bonds. They are being held liable for their employees' actions. In a related matter, Arizona Republican John McCain will be the first of the ``Keating Five'' senators to state his case when the Senate Ethics Committee begins public hearings next week, officials said. Until now, the panel has heard testimony and deliberated in secret, but beginning Thursday, it will publicly listen to facts and explanations from the five senators who went to bat for Keating's savings and loan. McCain will be followed by four Democrats: Sens. John Glenn of Ohio, Donald Riegle of Michigan, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Alan Cranston of California.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Hawkers: Have To Put Food On The Table
DOC.TEXT: The $74 Eddy Nadreau took to the homeless shelter where he is staying was more than enough motivation to sell the Daily News despite the pickets who occasionally tried to shout him down. ``I need food on my table,'' Nadreau said, estimating more than 50 men from the Atlantic Men's Shelter in Brooklyn had begun selling the strike-plagued New York tabloid. The poor and the homeless became sales people Friday as the Daily News tried to overcome circulation problems caused by the 2-week-old strike. It was unclear what effect the new work force was having on distribution, but it was clearly a big boost to the wallets of men such as Nadreau. He stood in front of Grand Central Terminal and sold about 150 newspapers in four hours, enough to bring about $74. He said the Daily News had called the shelter, offering $6 an hour and a percentage of sales, and the word spread. Harassment from union members didn't have much impact when compared with an empty stomach, he said. Selling papers nearby was 30-year-old Wayne Malone of Englewood, N.J., wearing a cap that read, ``Don't worry, be happy.'' ``I don't even know what the strike is about, to be honest,'' the previously unemployed man said. Three men were trying to sell the Daily News across the street from Radio City Music Hall in midtown Manhattan. They said on Friday morning one of them was attacked by a group of about 15 people, including five women, who scattered about 50 newspapers. ``They grabbed me,'' said Clive Vernon, 23. ``One guy tried to swing at me and missed. They won't be back. They know we're swinging back now.'' Jonathan Frazier, 26, and Greg Hamonds, 35, who were selling papers across the street, ran to help and they were also confronted. ``We told them if they got a beef, take it up to the Daily News,'' Frazier said. ``They've got a right to strike and we've got a right to make a living.'' Mary Brosnahan, a representative of the Coalition for the Homeless, said ``It is unconscionable to be using the poorest of the poor as strikebreakers.'' The state Assembly's labor committee plans to hold hearings into allegations of violence by both sides in the strike, committee chairman Frank Barbaro said Friday. Those allegations include acts of violence against strikers. Several striking News workers and a New York Times driver, speaking at a news conference held by Barbaro, said they had been assaulted or intimidated by ``goons and thugs'' hired by the newspaper. The News, using management employees, replacement workers and union members willing to cross picket lines, has published each day of the strike, but circulation has been a major problem. Daily News Publisher James Hoge said this week that 600,000 papers were being printed daily, with two-thirds finding their way to buyers. Union officials and competitors disputed those figures. Pre-strike circulation was about 1.09 million copies daily, making the News the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Producer Hopes TV Quake Movie Will `Wake People Up'
DOC.TEXT: A TV movie that shows an earthquake leveling Los Angeles will make people aware of the potential for disaster without dashing hopes for survival, the film's producer says. Criticism that ``The Big One: The Great Los Angeles Earthquake'' will unnecessarily frighten people is ``hogwash,'' said Robert M. Sertner, co-executive producer of the mini-series slated for broadcast Sunday and Monday nights on NBC. ``Our goal is to wake people up,'' especially in other regions of the nation that could be hit by strong quakes, Sertner said Friday. Scientists and emergency officials have said the film exaggerates the death and devastation a big quake would cause in Los Angeles. They fear that it may discourage viewers from adequately preparing for seismic disaster. ``It makes me crazy,'' Sertner said of such criticism. ``I'm not pretending this is a documentary, but it's raising people's consciousness, and that's what we wanted to do. So it's hogwash'' to contend the mini-series will discourage emergency preparations. ``I wanted to let people know preparedness makes a difference,'' he said, noting that the film shows the importance of learning how to shut off gas lines and stockpile emergency supplies. Station KNBC-TV in Los Angeles arranged for local Red Cross chapters to operate earthquake preparedness hotlines. ``It's possible some people may have a very emotional reaction'' to the mini-series, said Sylvia Stewart, spokeswoman for the Red Cross' Orange County chapter. ``Small children may be frightened.'' To provide earthquake preparedness brochures to movie viewers, the American Red Cross already is operating a 24-hour, nationwide toll-free hotline. The number is (800) 842-2200. California Office of Emergency Services officials were upset to learn the movie depicts the agency trying to stifle an earthquake prediction to protect a wealthy developer. ``I absolutely feel bad'' about that, but it was done to dramatize the dilemma facing officials who must decide whether to warn the public based on uncertain earthquake forecasts, Sertner said.

DOC.HEAD: Veterinarians Urged to Take Stands On Animal Welfare Issues
DOC.TEXT: Veterinarians often are silent on animal-rights issues but should speak out if they oppose such controversial practices as large-scale vermin trapping and laboratory experiments, an animal-welfare official says. ``Veterinarians have a scientific background, so they understand the importance of experiments using animals,'' said Gus W. Thornton, president of the Boston-based Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. ``They also sympathize with some of the group's concerns about animals' welfare. But they've been hammered so much from both sides that they've learned to keep their opinions to themselves,'' Thornton said. Thornton spoke at a forum sponsored by the American Veterinary Medical Association. About 125 veterinarians and animal-ethics experts from the United States, England and Canada attended. Thornton said if veterinarians consider animal traps or experimental conditions to be cruel, they should suggest alternative, humane ways to control pet populations and to slaughter animals for food. ``But you can't ignore the fact that people are going to eat meat and that some rats have to be trapped and killed to prevent disease,'' he said. ``Some extremist groups will never accept that. ``We will not and should not agree with everyone,'' Thornton added. ``But we must take a stand and provide our expertise.'' Katherine A. Houpt, a professor at New York State College of Veterinary Medicine, said veterinarians should push for more funding of behavioral and psychological studies to determine the most humane conditions for housing animals. For example, she outlined a study she conducted to test whether horses prefer to lie on concrete, wood chips or straw. Researchers found that horses opt for wood chips and that the animals also like well-lighted stalls where they face an aisle rather than a wall. Such stalls allow the horses to see other horses better. ``That can be kept in mind when designing stalls,'' she said. ``It won't make them the easiest to clean. But it'll certainly be more humane.'' Studies like Houpt's can pinpoint an animal's preferences, but veterinarians also should remember that people have different perceptions of what constitutes animal cruelty, another speaker said. ``You can't measure cruelty like you measure an animal's weight and size. It's an ethical judgment,'' said Jerrold Tannenbaum, a clinical assistant professor at Tufts University's School of Veterinary Medicine in Grafton, Mass. ``One investigator might think that what we owe animals is an absence of suffering, while another thinks that what we owe animals is a state of complete mental and physical health,'' said Tannenbaum. ``Those aren't the same things.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Back Decision To Give Force Muscle To Attack; But Some Reluctant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-7 `But while...parking lot'' with 5 grafs to ADDS another quote, edit style. Pickup 8th graf `Marine Staff...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While some American GIs still don't have tents to sleep in, they back President Bush's decision to give Operation Desert Shield enough muscle to attack the Iraqis. But some troops have reservations about war. ``Militarily speaking, he's absolutely right,'' Air Force Capt. Patrick Ryan, 28, of New Orleans said Friday as he waited for a flight at an air base in eastern Saudi Arabia. ``I don't think we have to worry much about the Iraqis launching an offensive any more. The big thing right now is how to get those guys out of Kuwait and to launch an offensive it's going to take quite a lot of firepower,'' said the Panama-based fighter pilot. Like many servicemen here, Ryan said he hoped Iraqi President Saddam Hussein would pull his troops out of Kuwait, but he said the U.S.-led forces must be prepared if he refuses. Many of the untested young soldiers are looking for a fight. ``We just want to go in and clean house and go home,'' said Airman Mike Beam, 22, of Houston, with the 401st Supply Squadron. ``All of us don't want this to be another Vietnam War. Do it once - take them out, and just make Iraq a big parking lot.'' Combat veterans say they hope for peace. After 30 years in the Marines and two tours in Vietnam, Brig. Gen. Mike Myatt, commander of the 30,000-member Marine ground force in northeastern Saudi Arabia, said he hopes his men will leave the desert without firing a shot. ``Nobody who's been in combat ever wants to go back into combat. But they know that if we have to, we have to be ready,'' said Myatt, 49. Marine Staff Sgt. Arthur Allen spoke for other soldiers who won't state their views publicly when he said: ``I didn't think there ever was a significant threat to Saudi Arabia or the oil supply to the West.'' ``We should never have been sent,'' Allen said Friday at Torrejon Air Force Base in Spain, en route back to the United States. However, he said the United States cannot leave now until Saddam is diposed of. ``Otherwise, if we leave, he'll run back in his cave and come out 10 times stronger.'' Bush on Thursday ordered about 200,000 additional troops to the Persian Gulf to join the 230,000 U.S. military personnel who have been defending Saudi Arabia against an Iraqi attack. Allies from 26 countries have sent 100,000 soldiers to the multinational force assembled in the area. The president said he wanted the the allied forces to have an ``adequate offensive military option'' should global sanctions fail to convince Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait. Iraq has deployed an estimated 430,000 troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq since it invaded the oil-rich emirate Aug. 2. A ranking U.S. military official in Saudi Arabia, speaking on condition he not be identified, said ``If there was a doubt in Saddam Hussein's mind about U.S. resolve to use any option required, if it comes to that, this should pretty well clear it up.'' Army Maj. Frank Irons, a logistics expert on the staff of Desert Shield commander Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, said he thought more troops would limit casualties in the event of war. ``I would think the more people, the more firepower we get in here, would enhance our chances if we were to go on the offensive to do a quicker job, therefore saving a lot of people and limiting the casualties that we would probably have,'' said Irons, 40, of Knoxville, Tenn. Army medical supply officer Tony Turner, 39, of Fayetteville, N.C., who was heading home to retire, backed Bush for preparing for war, which he said is the only option. ``I think that should have been done all along. It's just ... they keep bringing more and more people over with no room to put them, and they have to wind up sleeping out in the open. But I guess it's something that they have to do,'' he said. News of the new mobilization was just filtering out to the troops in the field on Friday. The main airbase was operating normally, with no new arrivals among the supply flights on the runway. At the Army's 530th Supply and Services Battalion headquarters, which provides logistics support for thousands of soldiers, there was some concern in the laundry and bakery about the mobilization. ``The only thing I'm worried about is having to make more bread,'' said Spec. Norman Wiemken, 22, of Polo, Ill., who was baking some of the 3,000 loaves of bread produced there daily. ``Just more laundry,'' laughed Pvt. 1 Lawandra Hinton, 20, of Newport News, Va., who was sorting through some of the 12,000 pieces of clothing washed there every day.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Junk Bond King Milken Made Millions More Than Disclosed
DOC.TEXT: Fallen junk bond king Michael Milken received millions more than disclosed from private partnerships set up by the now-bankrupt securities firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a newspaper reported today. The partnerships benefited from investment opportunities made available to no one else and were not disclosed publicly, the Los Angeles Times reported. A source with access to partnership information was quoted in the Times as saying a $1 billion estimate of Milken's gross receipts from the investments is a conservative figure. ``I think you're extremely safe if you estimate a billion (dollars), as weird as that number sounds,'' the unidentified source told the Times. Another unnamed source estimates the value of assets remaining in the partnerships is between $500 million and $600 million, reflecting the sharp drop in junk bond worth. Milken spokesman Ken Lerer said Friday the figures were incorrect. ``The information you gave me is patently false and riddled with misinformation designed to hurt Michael Milken and his family on the eve of his sentencing,'' Lerer said. ``It's irresponsible of the Los Angeles Times to allow itself to be used in this fashion.'' Records obtained by the Times for 12 of the nearly 200 partnerships in which Milken and family members are known to have held an interest show Milken received at least $470 million from 1981 to 1988. Milken, who headed Drexel's Beverly Hills-based junk bond department, resigned in June 1989. Drexel went into bankruptcy proceedings in February 1990. Milken pleaded guilty in April to six felony counts of conspiracy, aiding and abetting the filing of a false statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, securities fraud, aiding and abetting net capital violations, mail fraud and assisting the filing of a false tax return. Milken agreed to pay $600 million in penalties and faces up to 28 years in prison. Sentencing is scheduled for next week. Federal prosecutors revealed that Milken received direct compensation from Drexel of $1.1 billion in 1984-87, including $550 million in one year. Documents obtained by the Times include a study done by the General Accounting Office at the behest of a House subcommittee. It lists 30 partnerships with total estimated payouts of $2.04 billion to all partners from 1981-89.

DOC.HEAD: General Strike Against Ershad
DOC.TEXT: Protesters demanding the ouster of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad went on strike today, jamming traffic and shutting down shops. Police used truncheons to break up a demonstration and 10 people were injured. Groups of 100 to 500 demonstrators marched through the capital shouting ``Down with Ershad, Down with autocracy!'' and ``Torch the throne of Ershad!'' The president, a former army general who seized power in a 1982 coup, left Friday morning for Bangkok en route to Tokyo to attend the coronation of Japan's Emperor Akihito. The strike was the latest in a recently intensified campaign of protests by opposition parties who have been trying for years to dislodge Ershad. Eight demonstrators were shot to death by police last month when a fresh round of strikes was launched. Government offices opened today in Dhaka despite the strike, but few people showed up. Most businesses in the city of 7 million people shut down. Police and paramilitary troops guarded government institutions and patrolled the city in trucks and jeeps. About 10 people were injured when police used steel-tipped truncheons to disperse about 200 demonstrators. The police charged at the crowd when two small home-made bombs exploded, United News of Bangladesh said. The news agency said railway authorities suspended train service from Dhaka to avoid possible attacks by anti-government demonstrators. Protest leaders said the strike took hold in other major cities. ``We have reports of successful hartal (strike) in Chittagong, Khulna, Sylhet, Rajshahi, Comilla and other major towns,'' said Amir Hossain Amu, a leader of the Awami League, one of the main opposition parties. The Awami League's chief, Sheik Hasina, has joined forces with Khaleda Zia, head of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, to try to oust Ershad. The two opposition politicians insist that Ershad, 60, must resign before the presidential elections he has promised to hold next year. After leading a bloodless coup, Ershad resigned from the army and in 1986 was elected president in balloting that journalists, foreign diplomats and opposition parties said was blatantly rigged. Ershad refuses to step down and plans to run for re-election when his term expires in 1991. Hasina and Mrs. Zia say they will boycott the elections unless Ershad resigns. The president says he is ready to let international observers monitor the vote. In a recent speech, he said he had already invited former President Jimmy Carter to lead an observer team.

DOC.HEAD: Militias Begin Withdrawal from Beirut
DOC.TEXT:
Shiite Moslem militias began pulling out of the city this morning, in line with a 10-day deadline set by the government for creation of a militia-free capital. The government of President Elias Hrawi is trying to take control of the entire capital as part of a plan to end 15 years of civil war that has killed more than 150,000 Christians and Moslems. The Syrians, the main powerbrokers in Lebanon, have 40,000 troops in the country and have pledged Hrawi all the backing he needs to implement the peace plan. This morning, the Syrian-backed mainstream Amal militia withdrew about 200 fighters from its stronghold in the south Beirut slum of Chiyah. Amal fighters in 16 trucks and jeeps armed with twin-barreled anti-aircraft guns, recoilless cannons and machine guns gathered near the militia's headquarters on the Beirut airport highway. The mostly bearded Amal fighters, armed with Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles and rocket-propelled grenade launchers, smiled and made V-for-victory signs with their fingers as the convoy drove to the militia's canton in south Lebanon. ``These are our regular, full-time fighters. Most of them come from villages outside Beirut,'' said an Amal commander, who identified himself only by the code name of Abu Aly. Abu Aly, dressed in camouflage-designed fatigues and armed with a .38-caliber revolver, said the militia pulled out overnight ``our heavy, medium and light weapons.'' Part-time fighters who have homes in Beirut would remain as unarmed civilians, he said. He said the militia leader, Nabih Berri, had ordered ``all our forces in Beirut to withdraw in line with the government plans to create the Greater Beirut.'' A police spokesman said the other Shiite militia, the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, pulled out overnight ``several militiamen'' from its south Beirut strongholds of Hay Mady, Bir Abed and Mouawad, where most of the 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon were believed held. The spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said the Hezbollah militiamen ``left in vans'' that drove before daybreak to the eastern Bekaa valley, where the pro-Iranian militia maintains bases. ``We have no estimate of the Hezbollah militiamen who have already pulled out of south Beirut,'' the spokesman said. The conservative newspaper Ad-Diyar, in an unattributed report, said kidnappers of Western hostages ``moved the captives out of south Beirut to unknown hideouts two weeks ago.'' The move by the kidnappers was prompted by the government's determination to create a militia-free capital covering Beirut and its environs, the paper said without further elaboration on the remark. Earlier reports said the hostages were moved prior to the Oct. 13 crushing of rebel Gen. Michel Aoun by Syrian and Lebanese army forces. The 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon are six Americans, four Britons, two Germans and an Italian. Most of them are believed held by pro-Iranian fundamentalists Shiite factions affiliated with Hezbollah. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The police spokesman said the rightist-Christian Lebanese Forces militia of Samir Geagea also was gathering its fighters in east Beirut's districts of Ashrafiyeh, Nabaa and Karantina for the pullout from the Greater Beirut. The Lebanese Forces militiamen would go to the Christian hinterland of Kesrouan province north of the capital, the spokesman said. Hrawi is trying to rebuild the Lebanese army, for years fractured along sectarian lines. At present, military sources said he has an effective combat force of only about 9,000 Moslem troops under his army commander, Gen. Emile Lahoud.
Until he can reunify the army, which had a nominal overall strength of about 42,000, Hrawi will be dependent on the Syrians for his military muscle. A peace plan approved by Lebanon's Parliament in October last year aims to give equal political power to Christians and Moslems. That would effectively shift power to the Moslem majority.

DOC.HEAD: Historian Finds Civil Rights Leader Lax on Doctoral Sources
DOC.TEXT: Martin Luther King Jr. plagiarized frequently in a college dissertation, but his standing as a giant in the civil rights movement will not be diminished, a history professor and other supporters say. Stanford University professor Clayborne Carson said Friday the apparent 1950s graduate school plagiarism was a small blot on the record of a great man. ``King's historical importance was based not on his work as a student, but on his achievements as a leader of a social movement that changed the course of American history,'' said Carson, whose King family-supported project revealed the copied work. ``That can't be taken away.'' Boston University, where King went to graduate school, set up a committee of four scholars to review King's 343-page dissertation, ``A Comparison of the Conceptions of God in the Thinking of Paul Tillich and Henry Nelson Weiman,'' which he wrote in 1955. School officials made it clear that even if evidence shows King liberally borrowed from another student's papers without adequate citations as claimed, the civil rights leader's legacy won't be destroyed. ``The stature of Martin Luther King Jr., as the preeminent leader of America's civil rights movement does not depend upon the truth or falsity of the charges now being raised,'' the university said in a prepared statement. ``...His great and lasting contributions to American society and to humanity rest upon the life he made after he left the university.'' Coretta Scott King didn't immediately comment, but Carson said King's widow was comfortable with the idea that his research revealed the borrowed ideas and passages. She founded the Martin Luther King Jr. Papers Project in 1984 to gather his papers from locations around the country and produce a multi-volume collection. Carson was picked to direct the project, which he said is now 16 months behind schedule because the past three years have been devoted to substantiating the plagiarism. Ralph Luker, associate editor of the project, said the group will insert all footnotes in King's works where they quote others' material and write a separate paper explaining the original omissions - a plan approved by Coretta Scott King. The questions about King's academic work surfaced in late 1987 when evidence was discovered by a Stanford graduate student working for the King Papers Project. In some parts of the dissertation, King lifted passages nearly verbatim from other texts without using any quotation marks or footnotes. The Wall Street Journal reported Friday the discovery was kept secret for three years, as it stirred much debate and anguish. Several students working on the project wondered why the finding should be investigated, some resigned, and at least one broke down in tears when she found out. King, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964, was assassinated at age 39 on April 4, 1968, in Memphis, Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: Former Contras Attack Police in Eastern Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: In one of the mostviolent anti-government clashes in months, former Contra rebels attacked a police station, leaving three guerrillas dead and 35 people wounded, a Cabinet official said. The attack on the police station followed a week of protests in eastern Nicaragua over the economic policies of President Violeta Chamorro and the continued high-profile role of leftist Sandinistas in her government. The former rebels are also demanding that Mrs. Chamorro deliver the resettlement aid she promised to demobilized Contras, who waged a nearly 10-year guerrilla war with U.S. backing against the Sandinistas. The Contras were officially disarmed over the summer, after the Sandinistas handed the government to Mrs. Chamorro's coalition on April 25. There had been few reports since of gunplay by the former rebels. Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado said nine of the wounded in Friday's attack were police officers in Nueva Guinea, a small town about 190 miles southeast of Managua. Identities of the other wounded were not immediately known. In the pre-dawn attack, the attackers fired AK-47 assault rifles at the station, then fled to a nearby church where they surrendered, Hurtado said. He said a commission made up of Roman Catholic and Protestant church representatives and officials of the Organization of American States mediated the surrender. Twenty-one people were arrested. Hurtado said the attack was not linked with ``the movement of town mayors.'' More than a dozen mayors in eastern towns have formed a Civic Committee for the Defense of Democracy. They support the protests of the former Contras and are demanding the Sandinistas be stripped of their control of security forces. Last week, ex-Cotras began erecting blockades on the only road connecting the southeast with other parts of the country, causing losses for many farmers. Armed forces chief Gen. Humberto Ortega has threatened to use the army to clear the Rama road, but so far the military has taken no action. Dissident leaders, including more than a dozen town mayors in Chontales and Zelaya provinces, are demanding the removal of Gen. Ortega, a holdover from the Sandinista administration and brother of former President Daniel Ortega. The protesters are also seeking withdrawal of all Sandinista-controlled security forces along the Rama road and the dismissal of Hurtado and Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law, Antonio Lacayo. Lacayo is Minister of the Presidency and holds most of the behind-the-scenes power in the administration. Mrs. Chamorro's fractious 14-party coalition, ranging from communists to conservatives, easily won Feb. 25 elections. But the Sandinistas remain the biggest political party.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Elder Blesses Winter at Colorado Ski Resort
DOC.TEXT: In Colorado, where skiing is big business, resort operators aren't about to leave snowfall to chance if they can nudge Mother Nature along a bit. That's why the Copper Mountain ski resort called in Marcellus Bear Heart Williams, an elder with the Muskogee Creek Indian Tribe of Oklahoma, to offer a winter blessing on Friday. Williams, who worked in private, said he burned sage to do away with negative feelings, cedar to ensure a long life and sweet grass to nurture good feelings. It was the third consecutive year he was asked to bless Copper Mountain's slopes. In 1988, a dry winter was predicted, but the flakes began falling as Williams chanted. The snow fell for 39 hours straight, said Kelley Davidson, the resort's vice president of marketing. This year Copper Mountain predicts it will open Friday, nearly a week ahead of the area's Thanksgiving Day schedule. Early snowfall has also benefited other Colorado ski resorts. Keystone, Vail and Loveland are already open; Aspen and Winter Park plan to open Wednesday; and Breckenridge is scheduled to open Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Prime Minister Assigns New Cabinet Posts
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's new Cabinet brings back nearly a dozen veteran politicians with links to the late military dictator Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. The 18-member Cabinet was sworn in Friday night by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan. The ministry portfolios were announced today. Defense was the only portfolio that was not assigned. But analysts say Sharif probably will keep it, following the tradition of his predecessors. The new Cabinet is dominated by veterans of the Muslim League, the largest of 18 parties in the right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance that swept into power in the Oct. 24 parliamentary elections. Sharif, a 41-year-old industrialist who launched his political career during Zia's rule, was sworn in as prime minister Wednesday to head the country's fifth civilian government in 43 years. Sharif's Cabinet is one of the smallest, especially compared to the record 58-member Cabinet of his predecessor, ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Two of the most important portfolios will remain with veteran politicians who have links to the Zia era. They were also members of the caretaker government handpicked by the president after he dismissed Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government Aug. 6 on charges of corruption and mismanagement. Sahabzada Yaqub Khan will remain foreign minister and Sartaj Aziz will stay as finance minister. Political analysts said there was only one surprise in the lineup - the establishment of a Narcotics Control Ministry. Rana Chandar Singh, a Hindu minority member of Parliament, was appointed by Sharif to head the ministry. Pakistan is one of the world's largest heroin-producing countries. The United States heavily finances its anti-drug program, which several Western diplomats have criticized as sluggish. Pakistan's poppy crops are concentrated in a lawless tribal belt in the Northwest Frontier Province, bordering Afghanistan. It is a stronghold of traditional orthodox Moslems and several Pakistani observers questioned Singh's ability to penetrate the area. Since its creation in the 1947 partition of the Indian subcontinent, Pakistan has been ruled by the military for more than a quarter century. Zia, many of his top generals and U.S. Ambassador Arnold L. Raphel died in a mysterious plane crash in August 1988, clearing the way for Pakistan's first free elections in more than a decade and resulting in Ms. Bhutto's election Nov. 16 of that year.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Stabbed By Palestinian Teen-ager In East Jerusalem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An 18-year-old Palestinian stabbed an Israeli policeman repeatedly in the chest today in Arab east Jerusalem and then was shot by two of the officer's colleagues, police said. The stabbing was the latest in a rash of violence in Jerusalem, and Israel radio described it as a revenge attack for the slayings of 20 Palestinians by police gunfire on the Temple Mount on Oct. 8. The policeman was brought unconscious and in extremely critical condition to the Hadassah Ein Kerem Hospital, spokeswoman Ruth Mekel said. Doctors performed emergency surgery on the victim, she said. The assailant, who is from Nablus in the occupied West Bank, was hospitalized with gunshot wounds in his legs. The policeman, whose name was not released, was attacked by the Arab youth on the Street of the Prophets near the Damascus Gate leading into Jerusalem's walled Old City. The stabbing was near the Green Line that separated east and west Jerusalem before the 1967 Middle East war, when Israel captured the Arab sector from Jordan and annexed it. Tensions in the city were further aggravated this week with the slaying of extremist Rabbi Meir Kahane by an Egyptian-American on Monday in New York. Hundreds of members of Kahane's anti-Arab Kach movement broke away from his funeral in Jerusalem Wednesday to attack Arabs, journalists and police. Two Palestinians were stabbed, two were beaten and several police and journalists also were injured. A day later, a group of Palestinians tried unsuccessfully to grab a policeman's gun, and one of the assailants was shot. The Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began its 35th month Thursday. At least 773 Arabs have been killed by Israeli troops or civilians in the revolt. Fifty-two Israelis have died. In addition, 296 Palestinians have been killed by other Arabs since the uprising began Dec. 8, 1987. Most were accused of collaboration with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Overripe Vegetable Repeatedly Phones Sheriff's Emergency Line
DOC.TEXT: These are hardly salad days for Montgomery County law officials. Deputy sheriffs last week received an emergency call to Linda and Danny Hurst's home. They entered, their guns drawn, searching for whomever had called dispatchers 10 times. The time: 1 p.m. The suspect was spotted hanging over the telephone in a wire basket, dripping juice into the couple's answering machine. The caller? A bright, red, overripe tomato. ``I didn't know the answering machine could even dial out,'' Mrs. Hurst said. ``It's just supposed to take messages.'' Police were testing the county's 911 system, scheduled to begin operating at the end of the month, when the dispatcher began receiving calls that were traced to the Hursts' home. She called back, but the line was busy. When she hung up, she received another call. And another. Deputies tracked down Linda Hurst at her mother's house. ``I told them I'd locked my house and there shouldn't be anyone in there,'' she said. Police, concerned that someone had broken in, asked Mrs. Hurst to meet them at her home. She parked in front of the house and walked up to the front door. ``But they said, `Ma'am, step back please.' I looked back and they had their guns drawn. They were serious,'' Mrs. Hurst said. ``They went through the house, but they couldn't find anybody so I went inside.'' It was her brother who finally found juice dripping from the tomato into the answering machine. Chief Deputy Milton Graham said the tomato juice apparently got into the telephone's dialing system and caused it to dial the sheriff's office. ``We're not sure how. Maybe they had speed-dialing and it shorted out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Says Actor Afraid if He Visits Daughter He'll Be Held in Tahiti
DOC.TEXT: Actor Marlon Brando will not go to Tahiti to console his ailing daughter because officials there may not allow him to return to the United States to testify at his son's murder trial, a lawyer said. Brando, 66, is torn by the dual dilemmas of his offspring, said Robert Shapiro, an attorney for the actor's son, Christian. ``It's beyond wrenching,'' Shapiro said Thursday. ``It's an impossible decision for a father to have to make.'' Christian, 32, is charged with first-degree murder in the May shooting death of Dag Drollet, the Tahitian lover of his half-sister, Cheyenne. Cheyenne, 20, fled to Tahiti a month later and gave birth to Drollet's son. She was reported hospitalized last week for an overdose of tranquilizers and anti-depressants and is under Tahitian court order to remain on the island. Brando had made plans to fly to his daughter's bedside, but Shapiro said he advised against it without assurances from Tahitian authorities that he would be allowed to return. Unable to obtain such guarantees, Brando remains secluded at his Hollywood Hills estate, Shapiro said. French authorities on the island want to question Brando about the death of Drollet, the son of a prominent Tahitian. Christian Brando's trial has been postponed indefinitely by a state appeals court pending a ruling on prosecutors' attempts to secure Cheyenne as a witness. He remains free on a property bond posted by his father.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Rejects Iraqi Offer of Jet Swap
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government today rejected an Iraqi offer to trade a captured British Airways jumbo jet for engines and spare parts. ``There is a whole raft of sanctions in place, so any trade with Iraq is out of the question - and that includes this suggested exchange,'' a British Foreign Office spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Iraqi Airways chief Nouredine Safi was quoted in today's Iraqi Defense Ministry newspaper al-Qadisiya as saying the plane cannot leave ``before engines for Iraqi Airways planes and other technical equipment in Britain are returned to us.'' The Boeing 747 being held was the last plane to land at Kuwait airport before the Iraqi invasion of the emirate on Aug. 2. Many of the estimated 350 passengers found themselves caught up in the crisis and held captive as ``human shields'' to deter an attack by U.S.-led forces. British Airways says 162 passengers and crew members who landed in Kuwait are still being held in Iraq and Kuwait. British Airways described the offer by the Iraqi Airways chief as ``bizarre.'' ``Obviously there can be no negotiations as long as sanctions are in place,'' an airline spokesman said. ``In our view there could be no deal that did not include the release of our passengers, crew and staff.'' Britain observes the United Nations trade embargo against Iraq that was imposed after the invasion.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead of PALM SPRINGS, Calif.-dated item to CORRECT spelling of accommodate.
DOC.TEXT: Too many people said, ``I want you, babe,'' when it came to pictures of Sonny Bono, so Palm Springs and its mayor decided to accommodate them. To satisfy the cravings of tourists who want to have their photo taken with Bono, the council voted this week to spend $1,550 to create four life-size standup photos of the mayor. Bono, 55, who rose to fame with his then-wife, Cher, in the 1960s as half of the pop singing duo Sonny and Cher, agreed as long as he keeps control over how the photos are used. One of Sonny and Cher's biggest hits was ``I Got You Babe.'' Councilman Chuck Murawski said he came up with the idea after attending a recent trade show for travel agents in Minneapolis. ``Everybody wanted one of our posters with Sonny on it,'' Murawski said. The city's promotion staff also distributes T-shirts and postcards with Bono's picture. Officials will take the cutouts to trade shows where people can spin a wheel of fortune to win a chance to have their picture taken with the mayor's picture. ``The spin wheel is OK, but darts are out,'' quipped Bono.

DOC.HEAD: You Need Pi To Calculate Area, Win Pizza
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Pi, the...', to CLARIFY that value given for pi is approximate. Corrects spelling of `flier' in 2nd graf. Letter `r' in lede, math symbol for radius, is cq.
DOC.TEXT: You can eat for free at the Happy House of Pizza, but first you have to understand that some pies are round and some pis ``r'' squared. ``Back to school with a free large cheese pizza for the correct answer,'' reads the flier Happy House of Pizza began mailing to Annapolis-area households in September. ``If a 15-inch pizza costs $8.75, how much should a 16-inch Happy House pizza pie cost?'' Owner Ryan Belen said he came up with the promotion to prove how much bigger his pizzas are than those of a nearby Domino's outlet. Both restaurants sell a large cheese pizza for $8.75. Most Happy House customers come up with the half-baked answer of $9.33, by incorrectly applying the ratio 15-to-16 to the price, he said. The actual solution lies in finding the area of each pie using the formula for deriving the area of a circle - pi times the radius squared. The ratio of the two areas is then used to find what the price would be if Happy House charged accordingly. The larger pie gives roughly 25 square inches more pizza and would cost $9.96 if Happy House charged the same amount per square inch as Domino's. Pi, the 16th letter of the Greek alphabet, is the mathematical term for the ratio between the circumference of a circle and its diameter, which is always approximately 3.14159265. The letter ``r'' is the math symbol for radius. Nine out of 10 customers come up with the wrong answer, but Happy House has given away 86 pizzas, Belen said. Many students and even some teachers have come up with the wrong answer, but all love the promotion, he said. ``One teacher called long distance from the Eastern Shore to say she heard about it,'' he said. ``She said she was going to put the problem on the blackboard and buy her students pizza if they got it right.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Appeals For Aid To Soviet Union, More Meetings Today
With PM-Soviet-Outlook, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev meetings today, comments on gulf; Pick up 6th pvs, `Speaking at...'; edits to trim
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev wrapped up a two-day visit to Germany today after discussing the Persian Gulf crisis with German leaders and appealing for financial aid for his country's crippled economy. The Kremlin leader held separate talks today with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and with Social Democratic Party chief Hans-Jochen Vogel. Vogel said later Gorbachev insisted that all means must be ``exhausted'' to reach a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis, sparked by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Asked what Gorbachev said about military intervention, Vogel told reporters: ``He did not rule that out.'' Genscher, meanwhile, urged all Western nations to be ready to aid the Soviet Union financially and preserve its stability. ``Stability in the Soviet Union is important for stability in all of Europe, and therefore ... deserves our support,'' he told Deutsche Welle radio after meeting with the Soviet leader. Gorbachev had been scheduled to meet today with former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt, who returned Friday night after a hostage-release mission to Iraq. But Brandt cancelled the meeting, saying he was too tired. The Soviet president ended his stay with a trip to Speyer, famous for its majestic 11th-century cathedral, a stop at a wine-making village and a private visit to the home of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. In Speyer, more than 5,000 Germans welcomed Gorbachev, hailing him for helping reunite Germany. Several people held up signs lettered in Russian saying ``Thank you Gorby'' and ``We wish you happiness, Mikhail.'' On Friday, Kohl and Gorbachev signed a non-aggression treaty that lays the foundations for expanded economic, cultural, technological and political relations between the two nations. Speaking at a state dinner in his honor Friday night, Gorbachev made a strong appeal that the Germans be generous with financial aid badly needed to rescue his nation from economic collapse. ``From you, we would like courage, generosity ... and a healthy readiness for risk,'' he said. Kohl responded positively, but without being specific. ``In view of the painful but unavoidable transition, we are prepared with words and deed to help further,'' said Kohl. Under Gorbachev, the Soviet Union is moving toward a market economy following decades of Communist central planning. The economy is plagued by shortages and low production. After the state dinner, the head of Daimler-Benz, Germany's largest company, said emergency deliveries of food and clothing to the Soviet Union might be needed this winter. ``Everyone is awaiting a very difficult, terrible and hard winter,'' Daimler-Benz chief Edzard Reuter said of the situation in the Soviet Union. ``There must be immediate help.'' Such aid would likely include ``necessary items such as clothing, food ... we all must jointly organize that,'' said the head of the auto and electronics giant. Earlier in the evening, German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann told his Soviet counterpart, Stepan Sitarjan, that Bonn is willing to help the Soviet Union increase its natural gas exports through improved technology. Germany is a major customer of Soviet natural gas. Haussmann also said German banks are interested in helping Soviet foreign trade organizations that are behind on their payments to German firms. Kohl has said repeatedly he wants to help Gorbachev overcome the Soviet Union's enormous problems, partly in gratitude to Gorbachev for letting the Berlin Wall fall and partly out of worry about Soviet stability. Gorbachev's visit came exactly one year after East German officials opened up the Wall, spurring the revolution that ended Communist rule and led to reunification on Oct. 3. In the treaty, initialed in Moscow on Sept. 13, both nations pledged not to attack the other and to honor the borders of all European nations. After a short-lived alliance, Nazi Germany attacked the Soviet Union at the start of World War II. About 26 million Soviets were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents Say Felony Conviction Should Bar Mayor-elect From Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to correct category code.
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of Mayor-elect Vincent A. ``Buddy'' Cianci Jr. say his political comeback shouldn't count because of his conviction six years ago for attacking a man he thought was involved with his wife. On Friday, the state Board of Elections said a recount determined Cianci, a Republican, defeted independent candidate Frederick Lippitt by 248 votes in Tuesday's mayoral election. Three Providence voters who say they aren't connected to Lippitt filed a challenge stating that a 1986 amendment to the state constitution bars Cianci from taking office. The law states that a convicted felon is not eligible to hold political office until three years after his sentence and probation have been served. Cianci pleaded no contest on April 24, 1984, to assaulting a man he thought was having an affair with his estranged wife. His wife testified that Cianci went after the man with a fireplace log, a lit cigarette and an ashtray. In Rhode Island, a no-contest plea is recorded as a conviction. Cianci, 49, received a five-year suspended sentence, but the felony forced him from office. He went on to become a popular radio talk show host. Cianci said his campaign researched the constitutional amendment and concluded that it couldn't be applied to him because his conviction came before the amendment was adopted. ``The people have spoken,'' he said. ``I think the people would rise up if anyone tried to steal the election.'' The city Board of Canvassers said it would certify Cianci's victory on Tuesday and take up the voters' challenge after that. Cianci's previous 10 years in office were tainted by scandal. Although Cianci himself was never accused of any crimes, 22 people connected to his administration were convicted of various charges. Lippitt, 73, declined to congratulate Cianci when he conceded defeat Friday. ``Not everyone is given a second chance and this time I hope he really will be different,'' he said. ``I said during the campaign I didn't see this change. I didn't say that falsely. I meant it.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Says Three Americans Returned From Iraq In Good Condition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs on arrival of former hostages in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: Three Americans examined by U.S. doctors after being freed by Iraq are in good physical condition, a U.S. military spokesman said today. U.S. Air Force spokesman Capt. Tom Gilroy said Americans Miles Hoffman and Don and Brenda Swanke had undergone checkups at the U.S. Air Force Regional Hospital in Wiesbaden shortly after arriving in Frankfurt late Friday. ``They are all in good condition,'' Gilroy said. He declined to provide any further details or to speculate on hen the three might be released from the hospital. The three arrived along with more than 170 other former hostages, most of them Germans, after former Chancellor Willy Brandt traveled to Baghdad to intercede with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Hoffman, of Columbus, Ga., was working in Kuwait with a private company when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. He was shot in the arm on Sept. 5 by Iraqi soldiers searching for foreigners. Swanke, of Westlake Village north of Los Angeles, worked as a construction engineer at Kuwait University. He and his wife were also taken hostage on Sept. 5. Swanke said he lost 33 pounds during his captivity. Mrs. Swanke appeared in good health and commented on their captivity upon arriving at Frankfurt. ``I was worried but I was not afraid,'' she said. The U.S. Air Force hospital has often been used in the past to treat or check the conditions of Americans held hostage in the Middle East before they are returned to the United States. In Belfast, Northern Ireland, four Irish construction workers released by Iraq were greeted today by friends and family. The four were among those whose freedom was won by Brandt, and they flew to Belfast via Frankfurt and London. Grenville Redmond said he and his three colleagues - all from Northern Ireland - had been well-treated because they had been working on the presidential palace, but he expressed concern for other workers still in Iraq. ``We are very happy to be back and we suffered a lot of mostly mental tension while we were out there, but I am very distressed about those left behind,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Allies Are Laying Groundwork For War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 11 grafs to add Baker comments on war preparations; edits to conform
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III wound up a long diplomatic journey today saying the United States and its allies were making preparations to go to war with Iraq if its forces were not withdrawn from Kuwait. ``I don't see how the message can be any clearer,'' Baker said after holding what he described as ``a very positive and successful meeting'' with President Francois Mitterrand of France. ``We have built a consensus, we have increased the pressure on Saddam Hussein,'' Baker said in a review of his seven-country trip. ``We have isolated him, but we haven't yet succeeded in reversing his aggression.'' As a result, Baker said,``we must heighten the pressure further. Indeed we have to lay the foundation for the use of force should that become necessary. Clearly, one way to do that is to get ready militarily.'' Earlier, a senior U.S. official said Baker would fly home without having run into any opposition to a U.N. resolution to authorize force to liberate Kuwait from Iraqi invaders. Baker, at a news conference, cited President Bush's announcement of another buildup of U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf as evidence the United States was getting ready to use force against Iraq. Baker said he had taken steps during his trip to sort out questions of troop command and how the troops would be supplied. The stop here was critical. U.S. officials had said it was not clear whether French troops would go into combat. Baker declined to say directly whether Mitterrand and Foreign Minister Roland Dumas had told him they would fight. But he hinted as much. He said the meetings here ``were very productive.'' ``We believe we are totally united,'' he said. As for Saddam Hussein, Baker said the intention of the anti-Iraqi coalition was to ``send a clear and unmistakable signal to Baghdad that we are serious.'' Baker said after an 80-minute meeting Saturday with Mitterrand at Elysee Palace that the international consensus against Saddam Hussein ``is solid and unified'' and will remain so. A senior American official a day earlier had expressed doubts over France's commitment to the Western alliance against Iraq. ``It is clear that the unprecedented international coalition brought together to counter the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait is solid and unified and will remain solid and unified,'' Baker said after meeting with Mitterrand. The French leader told Baker that France's position ``consists of the strict application of the resolutions of the United Nations Security Council voted since the beginning of August,'' presidential spokesman Hubert Vedrine said. Baker also met with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, who had said Friday that ``the effort of France is real and second-largest after the U.S.A. ... This is very clear between the Americans and us.'' A senior U.S. official had said earlier today that Baker was winding up his seven-nation trip without encountering opposition to a United Nations resolution to authorize force to liberate Kuwait. None of the leaders with whom Baker dealt in the eight-day trip opposed a resolution backing offensive military action against Iraq, said the official, who insisted on anonymity. A few, particularly British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, took the position that a new resolution was unnecessary while other views ranged from seeking Security Council action now to letting additional time pass to keep pressing for a political solution, the official said. Baker said Friday the administration had not authorized the drafting of a resolution. But sources at the United Nations said discussions about a text were under way. The official said Baker had not sought a decision from the leaders with whom he met during the trip. The governments he consulted were Britain, France, the Soviet Union, China, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey, Bahrain and the overthrown Kuwaiti regime. Baker's meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand could be critical to the Bush administration's campaign to prepare the American public and the world for war over Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Mitterrand has tried to convince Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces with the expectation that a reversal of the Aug. 2 invasion could produce negotiations over Iraq's territorial claims against Kuwait and dividends for the Palestinians in their struggle with Israel. A senior U.S. official told reporters with Baker on Friday in Moscow that it was not clear ``where the French would be'' if U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf attacked. Meanwhile, on Friday, Iraq's government-run newspaper said Iraq and France had conducted secret talks that led to the release of more than 300 French hostages from Iraq. The paper, Al-Juminhouriya, said the talks between Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and former French Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson were endorsed by the French government. France has denied any deals were struck for the hostages. This is Baker's last stop on his journey. Before his arrival, French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said the effort by his government to reverse Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion was second only to the United States. ``This is very clear between the Americans and us.'' Baker meets with Manfred Woerner, the secretary-general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, before flying home to Washington to report to President Bush.

DOC.HEAD: New Cabinet Sworn In
DOC.TEXT: President Ali Hassan Mwinyi swore in 23 ministers today, hours after taking office for a second five-year term. Presidential and parliamentary elections were held in the East African country last month. Foreign diplomats and local politicians described the new Cabinet as being dominated by supporters of Mwinyi's policies of economic reform. Since taking over the presidency in 1985, Mwinyi has steered Tanzania away from the policy of central economic control pursued by Julius Nyerere, Tanzania's only other president. Mwinyi added six newcomers to 17 politicians who held similar posts in the previous Cabinet. He also appointed John Malecela, who had been Tanzania's ambassador to Britain, as the new prime minister. President Salim Amour of the semi-independent Zanzibar island also joined the 26-member Cabinet. Tanzania gained independence from Britain in 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Two Grenades Fired At U.S. Embassy; Military Plans Alert
DOC.TEXT: Two grenades were fired at the U.S. Embassy compound today, but only one exploded and no injuries were reported, an embassy spokesman said. The attack came a day after American and Philippine officials ended the latest round of talks on the future of six U.S. military bases in the Philippines. There was no immediate claim of responsibity for the attack, and it was not known if it was linked to the negotiations. The attack on the U.S. Embassy compound is the latest of at least 40 bombings in the Manila area since August. Most were believed carried out by renegade soldiers seeking to topple President Corazon Aquino. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said one grenade landed in Manila Bay behind the compound and exploded. The other landed in front of the chancery building but did not explode. One of two men in a passing car apparently used a grenade launcher in the attack, Police Patrolman Antonio Garcia said. A similar attack last December in a mostly American residential area was blamed on Communist rebels. It caused no injuries and minor damage. At the end of talks Friday, there were reports the bases' future would be linked to U.S. aid to the Philippines. The next meeting was set for December. Spokesmen for both sides predicted the talks would be completed by January. The talks center on the status of Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay Naval Base and four smaller facilities whose lease expires on Sept. 16. Most Philippine politicians have called for phasing out the bases, although U.S. officials say they want a ``residual'' American military presence here. Also today, in the Manila suburb of Mandaluyong gunmen ambushed a police patrol car, killing three officers, Mayor Benjamin Abalos said. In Maguindanao province south of Manila, unidentified gunmen massacred a family of eight apparently over a land dispute, police said. A 9-year-old boy survived the attack by playing dead, they said. Late Friday, two men on a motorcycle lobbed an explosive device in front of a building housing the China Airlines office in Manila's Chinatown district of Binondo, shattering windows and slightly injuring two passersby, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Macedonian Vote Seen Crucial Test for Yugoslav Premier, Unity
DOC.TEXT: The nation's poorest republic of Macedonia holds its first free elections in four decades on Sunday. The polling is a key test for Yugoslavia's reformist Premier Ante Markovic, whose Alliance of Reformist Forces is contesting elections for the first time. Opinion polls in Macedonia indicate the Alliance is in close competition with the reformed Macedonian Communist Party. Together they are expected to win an outright majority in the new Parliament. A successful showing in the Macedonian ballot would significantly boost the Alliance's electoral chances in the republics of Bosnia-Hercegovina, Montenegro and Serbia, which hold votes in the coming weeks. Markovic's reforms and have been undermined by political squabbling and rising ethnic tensions in the six constituent republics. The reforms, including sweeping privatization, lifting of import and foreign investment restrictions, and the promotion of free enterprise, have set him at odds with the hard-line Communist leaders of the largest republic, Serbia. The Alliance was not formed in time for Yugoslavia's first multiparty elections in 45 years last spring in Croatia and Slovenia. In that polling, center-right parties ousted the ruling Communists. Macedonia is a poor, mountainous region that borders Albania, Greece and Bulgaria, as well as Serbia to the north.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Damages Buildings on Hatteras Island, N.C.
DOC.TEXT: A tornado touched down on the southern tip of Hatteras Island early today, ripping roofs off homes and downing power lines and trees. There were no reports of serious injuries. Two people required stitches from cuts suffered in the storm, said a Dare County sheriff's dispatcher who declined to give her name. ``We definitely found tornado damage in the area of the Spencers Woods community of Frisco,'' said Wally DeMaurice of the National Weather Service's office in Buxton. The tornado was part of a thunderstorm packing up to 78 mph winds and heavy rain when it tore through the approximately 10-mile stretch from Avon south to Frisco about 6 a.m., he said. ``It would appear that a single thunderstorm formed up and spawned a tornado that touched down several times from the Frisco area south of Buxton to Avon,'' DeMaurice said. ``There are hundreds of trees down ... and several automobiles damaged, including my own.'' He said he also saw overturned mobile homes and damaged beach homes. Chris Schauer of Bubba's Bar-B-Que in Avon said the twister took off part of his restaurant's roof, blew out windows and tossed cinderblocks and bricks onto a nearby car, crushing it. ``It's a mess,'' Schauer said. Betty Barnett of the Frisco Woods Campground said camper trailers there were blown off their blocks. Authorities were advising travelers to steer clear of the area. Ferry service to the island - the only way of reaching the Outer Banks - has been temporarily suspended because of the storm, said Tabitha Hooper at the Hatteras Ferry Office. The only road linking Hatteras to the mainland via Bogue Island was ripped apart two weeks ago when a dredge broke loose from its moorings in a gale and smashed into the Bonner Bridge, severing the 2{-mile span. Today's storm system knocked out power to an unknown number of residents who got their electricity back only last week. Officials said power outages in the Frisco and Avon areas are temporary. The storm has moved about 30 miles out to sea within the hour and winds had died down to about 25 mph, the weather service said.

DOC.HEAD: Revolution Day Marches Looked Like Funeral for Perestroika
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to restore first reference to Gorbachev; Pickup 4th, `Little work...'
DOC.HEAD: AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Criticism of Mikhail S. Gorbachev from both conservatives and liberals, as well as a man shooting off a gun gave last week's Revolution Day marches in Red Square the appearance of funeral march for perestroika. ``The population is losing faith in the reforms, and in the powers that be,'' two of Gorbachev's two senior economic advisers wrote in a block-busting open letter published last week. Despite winning the Nobel Peace Prize last month, Gorbachev appears increasingly isolated in the Soviet political middle ground. Since September he has wavered in implementing radical economic reform that two months ago he said was urgent. Little work has been done to prepare some of the key reform measures, wrote economists Nikolai Petrakov and Stanislav Shatalin. They previously had refrained from criticizing their boss Gorbachev's on-again, off-again approach to perestroika, as the reform is called in Russian. Conservatives within the huge Communist Party and government apparatus, wary of losing their jobs, have closed ranks against Gorbachev's reform, radical historian Yuri Afanasyev wrote Wednesday in the Moscow weekly Currents. Gorbachev's political problems go deeper. Political violence, economic crime and the threat of a cold, hungry winter have driven Gorbachev's popularity ratings to an all-time low of 21 percent, down from 52 percent last December. That's according to an opinion poll to be released Sunday by the reformist weekly Moscow News. ``If there were democratic presidential elections today, Mikhail Gorbachev would not ... win the right to lead the country,'' the paper reported, quoting a poll by the All-Union Institute For Public Opinion Research. The paper did not disclose the number of people polled or the margin of error, but the institute is considered among the most reliable in the still-developing field of Soviet opinion surveys. Despite his steady slide in the polls, Gorbachev has managed to tighten his hold on power over the past year. He has won a new five-year term as president and changed Communist Party rules to require a full congress, rather than a Central Committee meeting, to unseat him as party general secretary. The Central Committee meets several times a year, but the party holds a congress about every five years. The angst of the Soviet right and left, dimly perceived in the West, welled to the surface during Wednesday's Revolution Day celebrations. For most of the 73 years of Soviet rule the observances had been marked by respectful bows to the national leadership. This year, the reverie was broken in part by two shots fired on Red Square. Plainclothes security men dragged away a man the KGB identified as Alexander A. Shmonov, 38, from the northern Russian city of Leningrad. He was charged with attempting terrorism. Equally ominous was the Red Square parade, organized by the Moscow Communist Party organization. Few of the estimated the 100,000 marchers carried avowedly pro-Gorbachev banners, and some were insulting to the president. Several carried portraits of Josef V. Stalin, probably the first time the dictator's image has been born aloft in Red Square since shortly after his death in 1953. Gorbachev endured the conservative march, but he left before a considerably smaller demonstration of about 5,000 radical reformers threaded into Red Square between rows of police and demanded his resignation. The hard-liners and the radicals appeared to have little in common other than discontent with the present and the president. ``Someone is blamed for every defeat. We have - Gorbachev,'' scholar Nikolai Amosov wrote in a widely read article in the current Literary Gazette. ``He gave us freedom, but the stores are empty. ``What is the most important aspect of perestroika for the people? Democracy? No - a boost in the economy!'' Amosov wrote. The shooting, and the hatred exposed in the demonstrations, were omens the political violence that has erupted around the edges of the Soviet Union could reach the center. Nearly 500 people have died in fighting between the two Soviet republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan, where rocket-propelled grenades and automatic rifles are not uncommon. Equally deadly weapons are beginning to appear on the Moscow black market, the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported Tuesday. ``A situation is quite possible in which people in our endless lines start shooting at each other,'' the paper said. Its reporters were able to find a large variety of imported and Soviet automatic weapons for sale in Moscow's shadier corners. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Bryan Brumley, Moscow bureau chief of The Associated Press, has covered Soviet affairs since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Sees Agreement With France
LaserPhotos DHA1, PAR2,3, NY10
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, seeking backing for possible military action against Iraq, met today with France's president and said later the two countries have no serious differences on Persian Gulf policy. ``I don't see how the message can be any clearer,'' Baker said after holding what he described as ``a very positive and successful meeting'' with French President Francois Mitterrand. Baker declined to say directly whether Mitterrand and Foreign Minister Roland Dumas had told him the French would join in any military action against Iraq. But he said ``we believe we are totally united'' on gulf matters. ``We must heighten the pressure further,'' he said. ``Indeed we have to lay the foundation for the use of force should that become necessary. Clearly, one way to do that is to get ready militarily.'' Key allies in the anti-Iraq coalition, however, talk in reluctant terms about using military force. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in Germany, met today with Social Democratic Party chief Hans-Jochen Vogel. Later, Vogel said Gorbachev indicated use of force could not be ruled out, but that all peaceful means must first be ``exhausted.'' And Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen today stressed the importance of continuing efforts to find a peaceful solution. ``I think an issue such as the use of force requires detailed consultations,'' Qian told reporters in Amman, Jordan, where he was holding talks. Baker met with both Qian and Gorbachev in the course of his trip. The Baker-Mitterrand meeting came a day after a senior U.S. official said it was unclear whether France would support military action against Iraq if it refuses to withdraw from Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. It also came a day after an Iraqi state newspaper reported that Paris had backed secret talks between Iraq and a former French official - talks that led to the release of French hostages. Three American hostages reached freedom Friday, flying to Germany along with 171 other Westerners whose release was negotiated by Willy Brandt, the former West German chancellor. ``Good riddance!'' said one of the Americans, Miles Hoffman, checking in at the boarding counter in Baghdad. A U.S. military spokesman in Germany said the three are in good physical condition, but declined to provide details or say when they might be released from a military hospital in Wiesbaden. There had been doubt about where France would stand if it came to war. The U.S. official said Friday that although troops from Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Arab gulf states would fight alongside U.S. forces, France's participation - as well as that of Syria - was uncertain. But after talks today with both Mitterrand and Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, Baker said there were ``no serious differences'' between Washington and Paris. ``I have no doubt about the unity of the coalition'' facing Iraq, he said, adding that those governments feel ``the option of force can simply not be ruled out.'' The coalition against Saddam ``is solid and unified and will remain solid and unified,'' he said. Iraq's Al-Jumhouriya newspaper reported Friday that Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and former French Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson met for secret talks, endorsed by France. The dailydid not say when or where the meeting between Aziz and Cheysson took place. Arab sources said the talks, set up by the Palestine Liberation Organization, took place in Tunis late last month, one week before Saddam said French nationals were free to go. More than 300 French citizens later left Iraq. France has repeatedly said it made no deal. The government did not, however, deny that the talks took place. The release of the French nationals was interpreted by many Western officials as an effort by Iraq to divide opposition to its occupation of Kuwait. In Frankfurt, the airport rang out with cheers as the German jetliner with 174 freed captives touched down Friday. No reason was given for the release of the three Americans among the other captives. About 1,000 Americans are still held. Hoffman, 33, of Columbus, Ga., was shot in the arm on Sept. 5 by Iraqi forces in Kuwait. Upon arrival in Frankfurt, he was immediately taken to the U.S. Air Force Regional Hospital in Wiesbaden for a checkup. Also freed were Don Swanke, 66, of Westlake Village, Calif., and his wife, Brenda. Swanke lost 33 pounds in captivity. The three had been held along with hundreds of others as human shields at strategic Iraqi sites to deter attack. In another development, the British Foreign Office rejected an Iraqi offer to trade a captured British Airways jumbo jet for engines and spare parts, saying trade with Iraq was ``out of the question.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Questions Cuban Aid
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet newspaper on Saturday questioned the value of continued military and economic aid to Cuba, the latest open criticism of ties Fidel Castro's Communist state. ``How many more years is the Soviet government going to take away the `rations' of poverty-stricken peasants in order to underwrite and maintain the inefficient, militarized economy of this far-off overseas state?'' asked the commentator Alexander Oskin in the labor newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna. Citing the Cuban debt to the Soviet Union from $26.7 billion to $30 billion, the commentator demanded to know how much 30 years of support for Cuba has cost the average Soviet worker and exactly how much the Kremlin gives in military aid. Oskin suggested that Soviet-Cuban economic relations be ``de-ideologized'' and that negotiations be started between the United States, Cuba and the Soviet Union to ``destroy another bulwark of the Cold War.'' The commentary, taking two full-length columns inside the paper, was the latest in a series of attacks on Cuban-Soviet ties that some experts believe may be intended to set the stage for a shift in Soviet policy. The liberal newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda last month published reports Castro, the Cuban president, lives a lavish personal life while employing thousands of body guards to protect him. In reaction, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda quoted officials defending Soviet-Cuban ties and published a letter by the Cuban ambassador to the Kremlin criticizing the expose on Castro. Cuba under Castro has remained committed to hard-line communism, despite the five-year Soviet reform campaign and toppling of hard-line governments in most East European countries.

DOC.HEAD: Military Rulers Confirm Choice of New King
DOC.TEXT: Lesotho's military ruler said Prince Mohato will be crowned to replace the prince's exiled father as king of this African country. King Moshoeshoe II, who lives in exile in London, was dethroned Tuesday by Maj. Gen. Justin Lekhanya, who accused Moshoeshoe of setting unacceptable conditions for his return to the African country. Prince Mohato, whose full name is Prince David Mohato Seeiso, is to be sworn in Monday. He will take the name King Letsie III. The new king will be the constitutional head of state but without executive authority. The 28-year-old prince is Moshoeshoe's eldest son. He studied law and public administration in Lesotho and England and is a member of the 22-member council of chiefs. Lekhanya, who seized power in a 1986 coup that overthrew Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan, fired most of Moshoeshoe's supporters and then sent the king into exile in March. Lekhanya invited Moshoeshoe back last month, but on Tuesday accused the king of making unacceptable demands, such as the dissolution of the current government, and stripped him of his title and powers.
