DOC.HEAD: Brush Fire Destroys Homes in Town Near San Bernardino
DOC.TEXT: A wind-whipped brush fire destroyed or damaged seven homes and forced residents to evacuate dozens of others today. No injuries were reported. About 300 firefighters from San Bernardino County and the California Department of Forestry battled the 300-acre blaze in this town 8 miles northwest of San Bernardino, said county fire spokeswoman Deborah McClellan. Dubbed the Knoll Fire, the blaze was reported about 1 a.m. and destroyed or damaged seven homes and several smaller structures in the neighborhood of Devore Heights, just northeast of Interstate 215, McClellan said. Firefighters had surrounded 35 percent of the blaze early today and expected to contain it by nightfall, she said. ``They're concentrating on the southern edge of the fire and mopping up elsewhere so the winds don't pick it up again,'' she said. The cause of the fire was under investigation. About 400 people evacuated their homes and a nearby campground, McClellan said. North to northeast winds of up to 40 mph fanned the blaze, and wind-borne embers ignited brush on the southern side of the interstate highway.But firefighters snuffed out the flames there, and traffic on the freeway was not affected, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: New Congress Will Have New - More Liberal - Faces
DOC.TEXT: Bernie Sanders, socialist, is coming to Congress. So is Paul Wellstone, a Jesse Jackson-style Democrat who demonstrates on behalf of striking meatpackers and farmers facing foreclosure. They're among the new faces in the Capitol corridors likely to give the 102nd Congress a more liberal tilt than those of recent years. Even some of the newly elected Republicans appear more moderate than some of the people they're replacing. ``We probably have the most liberal Congress there's been in 20 years,'' says Allan Lichtman, a professor of history at American University. He predicted the new House and Senate will be more hostile toward President Bush's policies. ``It's not a brand new mandate to re-create the Great Society, but I think we have a clearly liberal Congress that in particular will make it impossible for any conservative initiatives to get through,'' Lichtman said. ``It's more and more liberal, and the agenda is going to get more polarized,'' said Ed Rollins, the chief House GOP political operative. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., already has vowed to renew the debate over the civil rights bill Bush vetoed this year, and to pursue new initiatives in health care. He also has hinted at a Democratic attempt to pass a surtax on millionaires. Last week's elections will give Democrats a 268-167 edge in the House, a nine-seat increase, and a 56-44 majority in the Senate, a one-seat gain. But the numbers don't tell the full story. Several of the newcomers are unabashed liberals of a stripe not seen lately on Capitol Hill. Sanders, who uses populist rhetoric to push for taxes on the rich and corporations and for national health care, is the leader of a band of Vermont independents known locally as ``Sandernistas.'' In his campaign against GOP Rep. Peter Smith, Sanders ran hard against the Congress he will join, calling it ``hopelessly and pathetically out of touch with the needs of ordinary Americans.'' After gaining election, he said he was proud that Vermonters had the courage to stand up to the ``multinational corporations.'' Near Sanders on the ideological spectrum is the only outsider to win a Senate seat: Paul Wellstone, the Carleton College professor whose firebrand rhetoric and vigorous campaign ambushed GOP Sen. Rudy Boschwitz in Minnesota. Wellstone, 46, was state co-chairman of Jesse Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign and has been a grassroots organizer for liberal causes. Among other certifiable liberals elected Tuesday are Maxine Waters, an activist for black and women's causes who will succeed retiring California Democrat Gus Hawkins; Rosa DeLauro, whose credentials include a crusade against U.S. support for Nicaragua's Contra rebels, in Connecticut; and Neil Abercrombie, who reclaimed a Hawaii House seat for the Democrats. Abercrombie, with his long hair and beard, looks like a holdover from the 1960s when he was a radical activist. He has worked as a pre-school custodian, a probation officer and a college teaching assistant, and was briefly a member of the House in 1986 after winning a special election to fill a vacancy. Once, he recalled, he was presiding over the House, and called upon conservative Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia to speak with the words: ``Ah, here comes Mr. Gingrich once again to take up where he left off yesterday in flailing the liberal Democratic conspiracy.'' Gingrich will be back, after a close brush with defeat. But one of his colleagues in the Conservative Opportunity Society, Chuck Douglas of New Hampshire, lost in his bid for a new term. In at least one district where the Republicans captured a previously Democratic seat, the change also is toward the left: the Maryland Eastern Shore slot wrested by schoolteacher Wayne Gilchrest from incumbent Roy Dyson. Gilchrest is more liberal than Dyson on issues like gun control, the environment, abortion and campaign finance reform. A shy, reflective man who speaks of the country's need for moral commitment by its leaders, he seems unlike most other politicians. Four years ago, he abruptly quit his job, took his three children out of school, and went to spend six months in a cabin in Wyoming's Tetons. And after losing to Dyson in 1988, he spent a year painting houses and doing odd jobs before resuming his teaching position. While most of the movement in the new class of 1990 is toward the left, at least one of Capitol Hill's most liberal groups - the Congressional Black Caucus - will welcome a new member with staunchly conservative views. Gary Franks, a black alderman from Waterbury, Conn., won election as a fiscal conservative and an opponent of the 1990 Civil Rights bill. A 37-year-old real estate developer, Franks is a Yale graduate who worked for two Fortune 500 companies before starting his own business. He is the first black Republican elected to the House since 1932. And a veteran liberal, Wisconsin Democrat Robert Kastenmeier, was ousted by a political novice who ran a populist, anti-Washington campaign. The victor was Scott Klug, a 37-year-old former television anchorman who last ventured into politics to run for student council in high school.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemala: Disillusioned Democracy Faces Another Test
DOC.TEXT: This disillusioned young democracy lurches into a benchmark national election Sunday after a blood-stained campaign waged in a crisis atmosphere. Emotions ran the gamut from weary cynicism to quiet despair as Guatemalans prepared to elect a new president, a vice president, 116 congressmen, 300 mayors and 20 delegates to a new Central American parliament. Street crime and human rights abuses are rampant. The economy is in shambles. The immense power of the army and a wealthy elite is uncurbed. The government is broke and corrupt. After only five years of democracy, Guatemalans are so fed up that some polls show a majority want to return to military rule. While coup rumors flourish, democracy remains an alien weed, without firm roots. ``Whoever wins will have to prove democracy is really better than what we had before,'' said Edmund Mulet, an opposition congressman. ``It's going to be the last chance we have.'' A dozen candidates -- most conservatives and many with ties to past military dictatorships -- are vying for president; none is expected to get the 50-percent-plus-one needed to win outright. Election-eve polls, taking into account voters' options of spoiling their ballots or casting blank ones as a sign of nonconformity, showed ``Null'' and ``Nobody'' had as much support as anyone. The polls said newspaper publisher Jorge Carpio Nicolle, 58, would probably garner enough votes to go to a Jan. 6 runoff with former Guatemala City mayor Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen, 44, or engineer Jorge Serrano Elias, 45. Both Carpio and Serrano were candidates in 1985. Serrano came in third and Carpio lost the runoff to President Vinicio Cerezo. Whoever wins will make Guatemalan history Jan. 14, the first time an elected civilian will get a chance to pass the presidential sash to another elected civilian. But some see that scenario as a hollow victory for democracy. ``Guatemala is still a no-man's land, a land of impunity, death and desolation,'' journalist Byron Barrera said in an open letter to the army after he was shot and his wife was killed in a daylight ambush last month. At the end of October, the government's human rights ombudsman had logged 264 ``extra-judicial executions'' and 176 disappearances. The dead include a congressman, mayoral candidates and party officials. ``As Guatemala prepares for presidential elections ... the nation is in the grip of the worst human rights crisis since the military turned the government over to civilians in 1986,'' the U.S. monitoring group Americas Watch said in a report released this week. Even more pressing for most people are pocketbook issues and common crime. The candidates are full of vague promises to slash inflation and bring law and order. Most espouse some sort of trickle-down economics. They do not speak of the roots of the poverty and violence that bedevil Guatemala. ``None of them are attacking the real issues: what to do about the army, what to do about the private sector,'' said Richard Millet, a U.S. expert on Latin American military institutions in Guatemala. Guatemala is a sharply divided nation. Half its people are Indians; many do not speak Spanish. More than 70 percent of the population lives in extreme poverty; more than half cannot read or write. A small elite controls most of the wealth. It enjoys one of the lowest tax burdens in the hemisphere and one of the biggest slices - 90 percent - of the gross national product. ``If you want to win an election, you can't confront the army or the business community,'' said Rep. Mulet, chairman of the defense committee. The campaign has done little to enhance democracy's image. ``It's a superficial campaign, a campaign of slogans. The candidates are afraid to touch on the real issues,'' said another prominent opposition congressman, Jorge Skinner Klee. Trustworthy estimates on voter turout are not available, but many observers expect it to be relatively low. One of the early signs of the crisis atmosphere was the candidacy of a former dictator. Retired Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, now an evangelical lay preacher, was leading in the polls when he was ruled ineligible to run. Rios Montt, who presided over some of the worst human rights violations of the army's scorched-earth campaign in the early 1980s, told voters to deface their ballots to signal contempt for an electoral process that excluded him. At the other end of the political spectrum, a small, stubborn band of leftist rebels at war since a U.S.-sponsored coup deposed a liberal president in 1954, urged people not to vote at all. The United States, which has poured nearly $1 billion into Guatemala since 1985 in hopes of creating a Central American showcase for democracy, is bitterly disappointed. ``We expected a lot more for our money,'' said one U.S. official here. Much of the blame is put on Guatemala's playboy president, a Christian Democrat who weathered several coup attempts. His administration's record of corruption, economic mismanagement and failure to act on human rights put his party, the biggest and best organized in Guatemala, far down in the polls. Its presidential candidate, Alfonso Cabrera, one of Cerezo's closest friends, spent the final days of the campaign being treated for pancreatic disease at a Houston hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Slaughter 200 Surrendering Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Moslem guerrillas fighting to topple the leadership of Afghanistan slaughtered more than 200 government soldiers who had agreed to surrender, diplomatic and guerrilla sources said Saturday. The killings occurred last month during battles for two provincial capitals in southern Afghanistan, the sources said on condition of anonymity. Moderate guerrillas blamed Moslem fundamentalists for the massacres. Moderate groups have pulled out of the fighting, aimed at pressuring the Kabul government to negotiate an end to the 12-year-old war, the sources said. ``Everyone is denying responsibility,'' one diplomatic source said. Guerrillas gunned down at least 95 Afghan soldiers who had surrendered and paved the way for the Oct. 4 fall of Tarin Kot, the capital of Uruzgan Province, sources said. About two weeks later, they said, about 125 soldiers were slain by guerrillas negotiating the surrender of Qalat, capital of neighboring Zabul province. The guerrillas had promised the soldiers safe passage if they defected, they said. Another 100 soldiers were holed up in a heavily armed fort overlooking the deserted city until 400 troops were flown in by the Soviet-backed Kabul government, along with food and other supplies, they said. The reinforcements allowed the government to hold Qalat, which sources said was on the verge of falling to the U.S.-financed guerrillas. Qalat is strategically important to the Kabul government because of a highway that links eight provincial capitals. It is the major route for resupply convoys. Shortly before the Soviet Union ended nine years of direct involvement in Afghanistan and withdrew its soldiers in February 1989, many expected that huge defections among government troops would bring down the Kabul government within months. But their predictions proved wrong, largely because of highly publicized massacres of soldiers who surrendered to the mujahedeen. In November 1988, about 70 government soldiers were killed, their bodies cut into pieces and put on display by fundamentalist guerrillas near the town of Torkham on the border with Pakistan. The guerrillas claimed the soldiers were agents of KHAD, the feared Afghan secret police. There have been periodic reports since then of Afghan soldiers being killed after they agreed to surrender. The killings in Tarin Kot and Qalat occurred as guerrillas launched new attacks to break the 2-year-old military stalemate. While government troops have held Kabul and the major cities, they have yet to recapture much of the countryside controlled by the mujahedeen. Both the United States and the Soviet Union want out of Afghanistan and are reportedly close to an agreement that would end the bloodiest and costliest regional conflict of the 1980s. But they still differ over what role Afghanistan's President Najibullah would play in an interim government. Initially, the United States had high hopes for the government-in-exile set up in Pakistan in 1989 to oversee military operations against Kabul and to prepare for a transition to democratic rule. But Washington was forced to re-evaluate its position because of infighting among the seven-faction resistance, disagreements with Pakistan and growing pressure from Congress to cut an estimated $300 million in U.S. aid to the guerrillas. Although at first demanding that Najibullah step down, the United States reportedly has agreed that he can remain as president through elections if he surrenders control over the military and secret police. Both Moscow and Najibullah reject the demand, and most guerrilla groups still insist he must step down beforehand.

DOC.HEAD: Lesson From 1990 Voters: Tax Promises Better Be Believable
DOC.TEXT: Republican John McKernan pledged four years ago not to raise the state income or sales tax if he was elected Maine's governor. But he knew better than to renew that promise when he ran for re-election this year. McKernan eked out a victory last week over a tough opponent and despite a devastating regional economic decline. Analysts said it was because he made three smart decisions: he was specific in his first tax pledge; he didn't waver from it; and he realized voters wouldn't believe him if he made it again. President Bush, who rejoined the no-new-taxes camp last week with the pronouncement that any further tax increases would come ``over my dead veto,'' is taking a different path. But some political experts in both parties believe he's headed in the wrong direction. Voters have seen too many governors - and the president himself - break their promises, said Democratic pollster Mark Mellman. ``No new taxes is not going to be a line we're going to hear very much in the future,'' Mellman said. ``It's basically not credible to the public.'' ``Flip, flop, flip,'' said a Republican operative who insisted on anonymity. Tax hikes played a role last week in the ousting of several governors. Some of them had gone back on anti-tax pledges. Others were associated with parties or administrations that had raised taxes. The message seemed clear enough. Yet there also were victorious candidates in each party who had avoided blanket no-tax pledges or even advocated certain tax increases. Strategists said these candidates won because they were true to themselves and honest with the voters, stressing the services the taxes would support and touting their own efforts to fight waste and abuse. Here's a sampling of the tactics that paid off: -Illinois. Republican Jim Edgar edged Democrat Neil Hartigan for governor in a reversal of the usual party lines. Edgar said a temporary income tax surtax earmarked for education should be retained because there was no state money available to offset a repeal. ``He was dead-set to level with people,'' said Edgar's media consultant, Don Sipple. Sipple said public opinion polls showed 80 percent of the public didn't believe Hartigan would keep his promise to end the surcharge. ``We turned the tax issue into an education issue and a credibility issue. Both served us well,'' Sipple said. -California. GOP Sen. Pete Wilson, the victorious gubernatorial candidate, was another Sipple client. ``He did not take any pledge on taxes. He comes from the school that says never say never,'' Sipple said. ``Being honest worked for both of them,'' he added, referring to Wilson and Edgar. -Oregon. Democrat Barbara Roberts won the governor's race even though she opposed a successful tax limitation initiative and said some taxes had to be raised. As secretary of state, she had developed a performance audit program that helped convince voters she would spend their money wisely. ``There's a way to inoculate against being called a taxer,'' said Mellman, her pollster. ``If you're out there being a watchdog over taxpayer money and people believe that, they are going to be a whole lot less concerned about your tax votes.'' -Florida. Many analysts said GOP Gov. Bob Martinez never recovered from his promotion of a controversial services tax after saying he wouldn't raise taxes. Former Sen. Lawton Chiles refused to rule out new taxes, but his longtime reputation as a straight shooter apparently meant more to voters. ``People are much more interested in the content of a candidate's character than in their positions on the issues,'' said Mellman. ``If you're in favor of raising taxes, it's going to cost you with a certain segment of the electorate. If you flip-flop it's going to cost you across the board, because people will question your fundamental values - your fundamental character.'' Many Republicans still believe opposition to new taxes remains one of their best issues. But they say there are ways to make that point without a 100-percent, read-my-lips, no-new-taxes pledge that can come flying back as ammunition from an opponent. GOP pollster Bill McInturff said McKernan in Maine and Fife Symington in Arizona are two examples. He said Symington made up 10 points at the end of the race by stressing his opposition to a $6 billion education initiative. That was enough to put him in a runoff with Democratic gubernatorial candidate Terry Goddard.

DOC.HEAD: Oh, To Hear John the Baptist Sing `I Ain't Got No Body'
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: It isn't the heavy breathing over Salome's dance of the seven veils that bothers opera singer Michael Devlin. It's being upstaged night after night by his ow disembodied head. ``It's very strange, it's very strange indeed,'' says Devlin, who plays John the Baptist in the Washington Opera production of Richard Strauss' ``Salome,'' and loses his head over a pretty woman. The head, of course, is fake. But a strikingly realistic fake. It lolls on Salome's silver platter, eyes rolled back, blood oozing from beneath its long, matted hair, with a latex face that looks exactly like Devlin's. To judge by the gasps from Kennedy Center audiences, the head almost steals the show. It's a big enough star to command a personal makeup artist and stagehand. The head was made from a life mask of Devlin, a baritone from Seattle, for the original Peter Hall production of ``Salome'' at the Los Angeles Music Center in 1986. The head was bald when it arrived in Washington, so wigmaker Dennis Bergevin spent 40 hours hand-stitching and stapling a three-foot mane of human hair and cotton dreadlocks to the skull. The wig cost about $1,000. Before each performance, a plastic bladder inside the skull is filled with a $37 quart of Nextel Brand Simulated Blood, a urethane-based suspension of red microbeads. It is unplugged shortly before the head is presented to Salome. As soon as the curtain falls, makeup specialist Cynthia Ludwig and the stagehand rush the bloody head to a janitor's sink and wash it clean with cold water. Then it is carried downstairs in an elevator and put under a hair dryer for two or three hours. Shortly before its next stage appearance, the face gets a fresh layer of greenish white pancake makeup with dark shadows here and there, bright red lipstick on the mouth and a coating of glycerine to make it look sweaty. For much of the 90-minute opera, John the Baptist or Jokanaan (the prophet's Hebrew name) sits in a dark cistern where Herod has imprisoned him. He shouts dire warnings to the sinners above and emerges briefly to scorn seductive Salome's advances. ``I'm sitting down there on a chair, singing into a microphone and watching (conductor) Gerry Schwarz on a little television set,'' says Devlin. ``And two feet to the right is my head, lying in a bucket of blood. It's quite disconcerting.'' Jokanaan doesn't get the girl, and who can blame her? After all, he denounces her as a ``daughter of Sodom'' and refuses even to look at her. So she strikes her bargain with Herod: she dances her veils away to total nudity before the leering king, and she wins Jokanaan's head on a platter. After the executioner's ax falls in the dungeon, Devlin sneaks to the wings to watch soprano Maria Ewing, who plays Salome, make steamy love to his head. She cuddles it, nibbles it, showers it with kisses. ``I will bite it with my teeth as one bites a ripe fruit,'' she sings. Jokanaan might be forgiven for asking himself, ``Did I say something wrong?'' Devlin has appeared a dozen times or more in this production of ``Salome'' in the past four years, but says he's still fascinated by his severed head. After the ax falls, he said, ``I always stand offstage and watch the rest of the show. It's never lost its power, seeing the executioner lift my head out of the cistern. It's my face. It's a chilling sight.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Force Troops Ready to Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th pvs, `Bush announced...' to RESTORE first reference to Iraqi president. Pickup 8th pvs, `The addiiton...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY15,DHA1
DOC.TEXT: Long before President Bush increased gulf troop strength in the Persian Gulf and raised speculation of war, U.S. officers on the front lines were prepared to take the offensive. They say they were thinking about combat before Secretary of State James A. Baker III spoke of a ``new phase'' of operations and before the chain of command was set if fighting spreads outside of Saudi Arabia. ``We're ready to fight now. We're just waiting for somebody to tell us which way to go,'' said Lt. Col. Bill Chamberlain, 39, commander of the 2-18th Infantry Battalion of the 197th Infantry Brigade, which is attached to the 24th Mechanized Division. ``Our mission was to defend Saudi Arabia. That hasn't changed,'' said Chamberlain, a fourth generation Army career officer. ``But we've got to have offensive and defensive capabilities.'' But these days - with about 230,000 U.S. troops and a 140,000-member multinational force in Saudi Arabia - political leaders are talking more emphatically about going in to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait. That could entail hitting strategic targets and supply lines in Iraq. Bush announced Thursday that he's beefing up the U.S. force, originally deployed to protect Saudi Arabia and its oil fields after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The addition of four more armored divisions, plus more aircraft carrier battle groups and possibly more combat jets, could push the U.S. force to 430,000 troops within weeks, American military officials said. Bush has insisted on dislodging Iraq from the conquered emirate, by force if necessary, to demonstrate that aggression cannot pay. If the U.N. trade embargo and 10 U.N. Security Council resolutions don't force Saddam out, Bush can play a military card that gets stronger by the day. For the troops hunkered down for the past three months in the Saudi sands, at least half of their training and war games are geared for attack. They practice assaulting bunkers built the way the Iraqis build them. They practice house-to-house fighting, the kind of combat they would presumably encounter in an assault to liberate Kuwait City. They charge their tanks in old-style cavalry formations against trenches and the type of obstacles they think the Iraqis would throw in their way. Marines rehearse amphibious assaults in the northern Arabian Sea and maneuver their assault vehicles on a sea of sand once ashore. Supply depots have built up a 45-day stockpile of ammunition. ``We've always had a combat focus. We're a fast-reaction force,'' said Col. Glynn Hale, 46, commander of the 505th Paratroop Regiment of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division. ``These guys know any day we can get thrown into combat.'' Elements of the 82nd were the first American ground troops to feel the desert's blast-furnace heat when they arrived Aug. 7. The 30,000 Marines deployed in the desert and the 10,000 more primed on assault ships off the Arabian peninsula say they've got enough firepower to take on Iraqi strongpoints even without reinforcements. ``Offensive operations, that's our bread and butter,'' said Maj. John Bates, 44, executive officer of the 1st Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment of the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force. ``We defend for only one reason, so we can regroup and counterattack,'' Bates said. The Americans know the Iraqis have been girding for war as well. In Kuwait and southern Iraq, an estimated 430,000 soldiers are dug in behind layered minefields, 15-foot-high earthen barricades and anti-tank ditches. U.S. official have said the Iraqis have also filled trenches along the Kuwaiti coast with oil and flammable liquids that would be turned into a ``wall of fire'' to block an assault from the sea. ``It's going to be tough, any war is,'' said Brig. Gen. Tom Draude, 50, assistant division commander of the 1st Marines Expeditionary Force. ``It ain't all going to be perfect. You have to be prepared for that.'' The Air Force took an aggressive posture from the start. The U.S. and multinational forces have a clear advantage in top-of-the-line combat aircraft of about 2.5-to-1 over the Iraqis, the respected Jane's Defense Weekly has reported. The U.S. force includes about 20 F-117 stealth fighters. Those radar-evading warplanes would play a key role in a U.S. offensive, attacking command and communications centers in addition to key military targets in Baghdad. The U.S. Navy also has more than 50 warships to control the Red Sea, Arabian Sea and the Persian Gulf, the waters on three sides of the Arabian peninsula. They're ready to attack if the confrontation turns to war, said Capt. Louis Harlow, commander of the guided missile cruiser USS Biddle.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Approves Measures to Battle Organized Crime
DOC.TEXT: The Cabinet on Saturday recommended new measures to combat organized crime, including stiffer prison terms, a witness protection program and increased controls over the awarding of public contracts. The reforms were made following a report by Premier Giulio Andreotti that indicated a sharp rise in criminal activity by the Sicilian Mafia and crime syndicates in Naples and Calabria. The government is also drafting new legislation aimed at making it more difficult for crime gangs to export money. Under the proposed measures, judges can lengthen prison terms for conspiracy, drug trafficking and kidnapping if the defendant is a member of an organized crime gang. Penalties for inducing children under 14 to commit crimes can also be increased. Also, companies bidding for public contracts would have to submit to tests to determine whether they have criminal connections. The Cabinet presented legislation for a witness protection program aimed at convincing more criminals to turn state's evidence. Crime experts have criticized Italy for failing to provide adequate guarantees to witnesses and their families. The measures must be approved by Parliament. The report last month said the number of crimes attributed to organized crime rose from 740,000 in 1980 to more than 2 million last year.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Submarine Scrubbed After Costly Refit
DOC.TEXT: A nuclear submarine near the end of a $190 million reburbishing will be scrapped because of a tiny crack in its reactor system, the Royal Navy announced Saturday. Nevertheless, the decision to decommission the HMS Warspite is regarded as a cost-saving move, a naval spokesman said. ``There was no point in spending time and effort finishing the refit only to scrap her in a few years time,'' said the spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The spokesman also said the Valiant class submarine was being decommissioned as part of government defense cuts, but he did not elaborate. The crack was found February in the 23-year-old vessel's reactor primary cooling system during the refit at Devonport Dockyard in Plymouth, about 180 miles southwest of London. The vessel's nuclear fuel will now likely be removed and the Warspite could remain at Devonport for years to allow the radioactivity to decay, said the spokesman. Warspite becomes the second nuclear submarine to be mothballed in Plymouth. In September, the Churchill class submarine HMS Conqueror, which sank the Argentine cruiser General Belgrano during the Falklands war, was towed into the shipyard.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Given Temporary Shelter in Malaysia
DOC.TEXT: Forty-six Vietnamese refugees whose boat sprang a leak were allowed to land and repair the vessel, news reports said Saturday. The group, which included women and children, were believed headed for Indonesia when their boat began leaking in stormy weather, the national news agency Bernama reported. They were peritted to come ashore near Bahru, about 250 miles southeast of Kuala Lumpur. A police official quoted by the news agency said the State Security Committee decided to allow the Vietnamese to remain until they completed repairs to the boat. Tens of thousands of Vietnamese have fled their Communist nation on boats since the mid-1970s.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Prepares To Launch First of Two Overhauled Shuttles
DOC.TEXT: After months of struggling with dangerous fuel leaks on two of its three spaceships, NASA will try to launch the space shuttle Atlantis this week with a spy satellite. It will be Atlantis' first flight since March, when it placed another spy satellite in orbit. It will also be the 37th flight of a shuttle and the fifth flight this year. ``We've been through a lot of interesting times over the past few months to say the least,'' said Conrad Nagel, a NASA official in charge of Atlantis' pre-launch operations. ``Now that it's here, it's real exciting.'' Atlantis is scheduled to blast off Thursday evening, sometime between 6:30 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. EST. The exact time will be kept secret until nine minutes before liftoff because the Pentagon mission is classified. The flight is expected to last about four days, during which Atlantis' five astronauts will release a satellite that reportedly will spy on Iraq. Experts believe it is either a photographic imaging or an eavesdropping spacecraft. Information about the mission will be kept secret as with the six previous Defense Department shuttle flights. Pentagon officials say this should be the last classified shuttle flight because of the expense of maintaining secure operations. Two military missions planned for next year have unclassified cargoes. Atlantis' upcoming mission is four months late. In June, a month after Columbia sprang hydrogen leaks, NASA discovered Atlantis also had holes and its July mission was put on hold. Atlantis' military cargo reportedly was modified for gathering information in the Persian Gulf while the ship was repaired. Atlantis' external tank, fuel lines and valve seals were replaced by late September. NASA had scheduled the mission for Nov. 9 after Atlantis' fuel tanks were tested, but the Air Force delayed the flight because of satellite problems that were corrected last week. Columbia's leaks also have been sealed and it is scheduled to make a flight in early December. The successful mission of space shuttle Discovery last month with a sun probe was NASA's first shuttle trip in nearly six months. That success lifted spirits throughout the space agency, Nagel said, adding that successful flights for Atlantis and Columbia will move everybody ``up one notch on the morale ladder.'' ``Once we seem them flying and have this behind us, we're going to look back and mark this year ... as one of our tough years for the space program,'' Nagel said. ``We'll also say the last part of the year we were able to get three flights in three months.'' John Pike, director of the Federation of American Scientists' space policy project, said launching Atlantis and Columbia by the end of the year will help boost NASA's sagging image. But he said the agency had a long way to go ``in terms of getting back in the saddle.'' In addition to tracking hydrogen leaks, NASA has spent much of the past few months investigating the Hubble Space Telescope's flawed mirror - which went unnoticed until it was in orbit. There also have been a series of accidents involving shuttle equipment. The latest mishap occurred Wednesday when a technician knocked a metal pan from a work platform into the astronomical observatory aboard Columbia. A protective blanket over a star tracker was torn, but officials said the instrument was not damaged. ``Even if these two guys lift off by the end of the year, all they've demonstrated after a sustained period of grounding is that they were able to fly all three in a sudden little spurt.''

DOC.HEAD: Jackson, Miss., Zoo Hails Arrival of Baby Cheetah
DOC.TEXT: Jackson Zoo workers are keeping their fingers crossed for their ``precious baby'' - a newborn cheetah cub. The cub, little more than a pound of hungry, dappled baby fur, has been in an incubator at the Jackson Zoo since it was born last week, after his mother rejected him. He's called Ty, the initials for 10 years, ``because that's how long we've been exhibiting cheetahs and trying to breed them,'' said curator Jim Schnormeier. ``He's a precious baby,'' said zoo director Barbara Barrett. Two cubs were born to Jimba, 2{, early Thursday, but Ty's sibling was dead when zoo workers arrived, Schnormeier said. The mother rejected Ty by putting him outside her box, so zoo workers took the cub to the zoo's animal hospital for bottle-feeding and a warm incubator. Thirty-six U.S. zoos have 237 cheetahs and have reported at least four births this year. Cheetah births are rare because the wild population is declining, which fosters inbreeding and can result in genetic defects. Ty's father, Mwemdo, was acquired in late 1989 from the Cincinnati Zoo.

DOC.HEAD: New Japanese Emperor Is Product of Postwar Age
With AM-Japan-Entronement
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito has long lived in the shadow of his father, the late Emperor Hirohito, and the memories of Japan's headlong march into the Pacific War that Hirohito's name evoked. But as Akihito on Monday officially inherits the throne left by his father's death, many Japanese are looking to him as the symbol of a new age - that of the generation who experienced war as children and rebuilt the nation in peace. Akihito was 11 years old at the end of World War II, during which Japanese militarists urged the nation to battle in the name of his father. The impact of surrender and reform under the guidance of U.S.-led occupation forces deeply affected his youth. Before Akihito turned 13, Hirohito made his historic renunciation of imperial divinity. The occupation troops left Japan after seven years in 1952 and left behind them a democratic constitution that renounced war and defined Japan's monarchs as ``symbols,'' not the priest-kings of bygone days. That imperial role seems to fit Akihito, who in one of his first duties after assuming the throne upon the death of Hirohito in January 1989 promised to uphold the constitution ``along with the people.'' ``Most grieved by his late majesty's passing, I have succeeded to the imperial throne in accordance with the constitution of Japan,'' he said. ``Shrouded in sorrow and overwhelmed by the responsibilities I undertake, I stand humble before you.'' Akihito, born on Dec. 23, 1933, bears a strong physical resemblance to Hirohito, and has inherited his father's short, almost frail, build. He also has his father's passion for science, and is a respected scholar in the study of gobies, a type of mud-sucking fish. Akihito speaks fluent English and is Japan's most widely traveled emperor. He hasa made official visits to 37 countries, his first to England for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II in 1953. Reflecting the circumstances of his upbringing, Akihito is often described by former schoolmates and palace officials as a more democratic, warmer person than the quiet, reclusive Hirohito. He has also been far more prone to set his own precedents. Just three years after completing his education - Akihito was the first emperor schooled alongside commoners - the royal heir chose a commoner for his bride, making another break from the past. The woman, Michiko Shoda, was the daughter of one of the nation's wealthiest businessmen, but their marriage in 1959 sent shock waves through Japan's former nobility. To the rest of the nation, however, the wedding was welcomed as none before. About 500,000 people lined the streets for a chance to see Akihito and Michiko in their horse-drawn carriage during a parade after the ceremony. The royal couple again broke with tradition by raising their own children, a decision prompted in part by Akihito's desire to have the family life he was denied as a child, according to Minoru Hamao, a former imperial chamberlain. Taken away from his parents at an early age to be raised by strangers, Akihito at times complained of the loneliness he felt when his classmates would talk to him about their homes, said Hamao, who served Akihito for two decades. Akihito's first child and heir, Crown Prince Naruhito, was born Feb. 23, 1960. They have another son, Prince Akishino, and daughter, Princess Nori. Though the crown prince remains single, Prince Akishino earlier this year wed Kiko Kawashima - who, like the empress, had no royal lineage.

DOC.HEAD: Opposing Forces in the Persian Gulf
With AM-Gulf Offensive, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S.-dominated multinational force in the Persian Gulf, the biggest such force since the Korean War, is to be reinforced with another 200,000 American personnel by mid-January. That will raise U.S. strength in the region to around 430,000 soldiers, Marines, airmen and sailors. They are supported by a 25-nation force of about 150,000. Saddam Hussein has an estimated 430,000 troops in occupied Kuwait and southern Iraq. Here is a breakdown of the forces confronting each other in the gulf: ---

UNITED STATES: Operation Desert Shield is the biggest U.S. military deployment since the Vietnam War. About 230,000 troops, including those aboard ships, are in the region. Ground forces in Saudi Arabia include the 82nd Airborne Division, the 101st Airborne Division, the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade, 197th Mechanized Infantry Brigade, the 1st Cavalry Division and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment. When the armored deployment is complete, U.S. forces will have around 2,000 tanks. The current force will be joined by as many as four armored divisions, three aircraft carrier battle groups, the battleship USS Missouri, more air force units and the 45,000-man 5th Marine Expeditionary Force. Current amphibious capability is provided by 45,000 men of the 1st, 4th and 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigades. When deployment is complete, virtually the whole of the U.S. Marine Corps will be committed to Desert Shield. There is a Special Forces contingent from the 1st Special Operations Command. About 55 Navy ships are now in the gulf, the Arabian Sea and the eastern Mediterranean. They include the aircraft carriers Independence, Saratoga and John F. Kennedy, the battleship Wisconsin with 32 Tomahawk cruise missiles, five missile cruisers, four destroyers, several frigates, plus supply ships and an estimated 6-8 nuclear submarines. The aircraft carriers now in place have a combined strike force of 180 A-6 Intruder, FA-18 Hornet fighters and F-14 Tomcats. The Marines have some 60 AV-8B Harrier jump-jets. Among the 800 tactical combat aircraft deployed so far are 22 F117A Stealth fighter-bombers and as many as 38 long-range F-111F bombers. There are an estimated 150 F-16s and F-15s, more than 70 A-10 tank-killing Thunderbolts and unspecified numbers of F-4 Wild Weasel air-defense suppression jets and other combat aircraft deployed at 30 airbases in the region. A squadron of 6-8 B-52G strategic bombers is on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia. ---

BRITAIN: Has a three-ship flotilla permanently in the gulf and has beefed this up to 12 ships, including two missile destroyers, four missile frigates and three minesweepers with support ships. Four squadrons of Tornado and Jaguar interceptors and ground attack jets are in Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Oman. Three Nimrod maritime reconnaisance aircraft are in Oman. The 7th Armored Brigade, successors to the famous ``Desert Rats'' of World War II, with 120 Challenger tanks and 9,500 troops, is attached to the U.S. Marine force on the ground in northeastern Saudi Arabia. British strength will reach 15,000. ---

FRANCE: Has about 14 ships and 13,000 men in the region. The warships include a guided-missile cruiser, two missile destroyers, four frigates and a corvette with support vessels. Has sent three squadrons of interceptors and fighter-bombers. Its 4,000-man Rapid Action Force is deployed with Arab forces in the northeastern Saudi desert. A company of 190 paratroopers equipped for chemical warfare is in the United Arab Emirates. ---

ITALY: Three frigates and a support ship are in the gulf. Two corvettes are in the eastern Mediterranean, replacing U.S. units assigned to the gulf. A squadron of eight Tornado fighters is based near Abu Dhabi, U.A.E. No ground force deployment planned. ---
CANADA: Two destroyers and a supply ship are heading for the gulf. A squadron of 18 CF-18 fighter jets and 450 military personnel is in Saudi Arabia. ---
NETHERLANDS: Two frigates in the Gulf of Oman with a combat supply ship. ---
SPAIN: A frigate in the Gulf of Oman, two corvettes in the Bab el Mandeb Strait in the southern Red Sea. Replacement ships en route. ---
AUSTRALIA: Two guided-missile frigates and a supply ship in the region. ---
BELGIUM: Two minehunters and a supply ship in the Gulf of Oman. The Belgians have also commited four C-130 military transport planes. ---
ARGENTINA: Destroyer and frigate in the gulf region, armed with anti-ship Exocet missiles. A 100-member army unit will also be sent. ---
SOVIET UNION: A destroyer and an anti-submarine in the Gulf of Oman. Moscow has indicated it would send ground forces, but only under U.N. command. ---
GREECE: Greece's most advanced frigate; merchant ships for the U.S. sealift. ---
GERMANY: Merchant ships being provided to transport U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia; $2 billion for the multinational force. Germany's constitution bans the deployment of military forces. ---
DENMARK: A corvette in the gulf region; merchant ships helping U.S. sealift. ---
NORWAY: Coast Guard cutter supporting the Danish corvette, and has offered anti-chemical warfare equipment. ---

PORTUGAL: The naval support carrying equipment and supplies to the British force; has allowed U.S. aircraft to refuel at its airbases. --- CZECHOSLOVAKIA: Has sent a 200-man army unit with anti-chemical warfare equipment. ---
HONDURAS: Sending 150 troops to Saudi Arabia and possibly 350 more, in the country's first foreign military deployment.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: NICOSIA: military deployment. Here is a breakdown of the Allied Arab Forces facing Iraq: ---
DOC.TEXT: GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar and, until Aug. 2, Kuwait): Rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops based at Hafr al-Batin, northeast Saudi Arabia, forming first line of defense. The force has been beefed up with some 7,000 soldiers of Kuwait's 20,000-member army who escaped their country when Iraq invaded. Most of their heavy weapons were captured by Iraq, but some combat jets, naval attack craft and tanks were saved. The GCC and other gulf Arab forces total around 144,500 men, 330 combat aircraft, 800 tanks and 36 major naval units, although not all are likely to be involved in Desert Shield. They are supported by: ---
EGYPT: Has pledged up to 20,000 troops with tanks and heavy artillery. About 14,500 troops in Saudi Arabia, several thousand more expected. Five hundred troops in the U.A.E. ---

SYRIA: 4,000 troops, mostly elite Special Forces units, in Saudi Arabia. First elements of the 15,000-man 9th Armored Division, with some 270 T-72 tanks, have arrived. The rest should be in place by the end of November. Some troops are based in the U.A.E. ---

PAKISTAN: Has pledged to send 5,000 troops, with 2,000 already in Saudi Arabia and 2,000 in the U.A.E, along with 1,000 advisers. About 5,000 advisers are already attached to the Saudi armed forces. ---
MOROCCO: 1,200 troops in Saudi Arabia and 500 in the U.A.E. ---
BANGLADESH: 2,000 troops, including engineering and infantry units, in Saudi Arabia. ---

Facing the Arab and other multinational forces: --- IRAQ: Seven corps totalling 55 divisions. There are 555,000 regular troops and 480,000 reserves. Regular forces include six divisions of elite Republican Guards. Iraq claims a militia called the Popular Army has 5 million men. Saddam Hussein has 5,500 tanks, including some 500 high-quality T-72s and 1,000 medium-quality T-62s; 3,500 artillery guns; 200 multiple rocket launchers; an estimated 500 surface-to-surface missiles; more than 330 surface-to-air missile launchers, including captured Kuwaiti systems; 500-plus combat aircraft, including Soviet-supplied long-range Su-24 fighter-bombers and advanced MiG-29 interceptors, spread around an estimated 25 airbases. Its main naval units are a training frigate with anti-submarine torpedoes, an estimated eight Soviet-built missile-attack craft and six torpedo boats. In Kuwait, Iraq has an estimated 10 divisions, four of them armored, totalling 170,000 troops, 1,500 T-55 and T-62 tanks and 800 artillery pieces in defensive positions. A further 250,000 men, including the seven Republican Guard divisions with up to 1,800 tanks and 750 guns, are dug-in in southern Iraq as a tactical reserve. There is a large strategic reserve, including elements of the 3rd and 7th Army Corps, further north. Silkworm anti-ship missiles are believed to have been deployed to counter any U.S. amphibious landing in Kuwait. FROG-7 battlefield missiles have also been deployed, including batteries captured in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Pulling Together Against Iraq, Except When Use of Force Is Raised
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT typo in Mitterrand
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Raise the possibility of confronting Iraq with military force and the alliance against Saddam Hussein turns far less cohesive, Secretary of State James A. Baker III has found. Give diplomacy more time, they said. At the same time, they acknowledged that a military confrontation may be unavoidable. Baker has rallied the leaders of eight governments to demand the liberation of Kuwait, strengthening the alliance in some ways. With virtual unanimity, Baker found the leaders of the Soviet Union, China, Britain, France, Turkey, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and the exiled Kuwaiti regime in unanimous agreement that Saddam Hussein's invaders must depart. On top of that, they endorsed the Bush administration's judgment that partial solutions - anything short of the unconditional and total withdrawal from the oil-rich emirate - was unacceptable. But the alliance was far less cohesive when Baker brought up the use of force even as a last resort to evict Iraqi forces. The Soviet Union, probably the most vital member of the coalition apart from the United States, clearly prefers to give political diplomacy at least two more months before pulling the trigger. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze gave force a very reluctant endorsement Thursday in Moscow, saying ``probably this could not be ruled out'' under certain circumstances. Similarly, Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, who huddled with Baker for two hours Tuesday at Cairo airport, gave assurances Beijing would not veto a U.N. resolution authorizing force. But like Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Shevardnadze, the Chinese official urged the pursuit of a diplomatic settlement. The same message was delivered by Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, whose troops U.S. officials said would fight alongside American forces in the event of war. Mubarak also would like at least two more months of diplomacy before considering a war against Saddam Hussein. The trouble is, the Bush administration detects no sign that the Iraqi leader is in a mood to yield to United Nations demands that he release Kuwait from his grip. ``We've seen no evidence in all of the diplomatic activity that's taken place on the part of Saddam Hussein to even begin to comply with the United Nations resolutions,'' a senior official said Friday in Moscow. Besides, Baker said, the Soviets agreed with that appraisal - despite hopeful statements Gorbachev and his emissary to Baghdad, Yevgeny Primakov, have made on occasion. ``I don't think the Soviets are any more optimistic than we are about the willingness of Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait,'' Baker told reporters who traveled with him to seven countries in eight days. In fact, a senior U.S. official said Primakov ``was basically stiffed'' during trips to Iraq in September and October. Even so, the Bush administration is holding off on a resolution in the U.N. Security Council. Baker said none was being prepared - despite reports from New York that the United States was ready to call for force against Iraq if peaceful political measures fail. By contrast, however, President Bush on Thursday ordered another 200,000 American troops to the Persian Gulf to provide enough military muscle for a war against Iraq. Bush said the buildup, potentially to about 430,000, was intended ``to ensure that the coalition has an adequate offensive military option should that be necessary to achieve our common goals.'' Unquestionably, Baker found common goals on his trip, the primary one being that Iraq should quit Kuwait. But when a senior U.S. official was asked Friday in Moscow who would fight alongside the United States, he could only guarantee Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the ousted Kuwaiti monarchy and the small Persian Gulf states. Britain probably can be counted on as well. ``Obviously, we stand absolutely together in supporting the great international coalition that has been built up to see that aggression does not, cannot and will not pay. Absolutely together,'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said after talking to Baker on Friday at 10 Downing Street. ``The peaceful solution would be for Iraq to get out of Kuwait,'' she said. ``We hope they will do it. If not, we shall have to take the military option and see that Iraq does leave Kuwait.'' On the other hand, Syria and France were listed as question marks in the session with reporters under rules that barred identifying the official. After meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand and Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, Baker on Saturday declined to say directly whether they had told him they would fight. But he hinted as much, saying, ``We believe we are totally united.'' It remains to be seen what impact the mixed message will have on Bush when Baker returned with it to Washington on Saturday night. It could give the president reason to bide his time a bit, at least to hold off until he makes his own Thanksgiving holiday visit to the gulf. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Barry Schweid has covered diplomacy for The Associated Press since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles Arrives For Japanese Ceremony, Quayle Attending
LaserPhoto HAN14
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prince Charles and delegations from more than 50 other nations arrived Saturday for Emperor Akihito's coronation. Police began blocking Tokyo streets to try to prevent terrorist attacks. Scores of foreign VIPs, including Vice President Dan Quayle, will attend the ceremony, which begins Monday. The coronation is the first Japan has feted since Akihito's father, the late Emperor Hirohito, was enthroned in 1928. Representatives from 28 countries, most of them ambassadors to Japan, attended that ceremony. Akihito's coronation also will be the largest international gathering here since Hirohito's funeral in February 1989, which drew top-level dignitaries from 163 nations. Police have been particularly tense over the past few weeks because of increased violence linked to leftist radical groups, which have threatened to ``annihilate'' the coronation and kill the emperor. Radicals, who claimed responsibility for a blast that killed a police officer and injured six other people in Tokyo on Nov. 1, are suspected of involvement in more than 60 incidents this year. In the past week alone, three Shinto shrines and one Buddhist temple associated with the imperial family were razed by fires believed set by radicals. Police on Saturday reported the latest fire had destroyed a shrine in Shiogama, northeast of Tokyo. No injuries were reported. Charles and his wife, Princess Diana, disappointed a throng of photographers by being quickly whisked away from the airport for some rest before beginning a full schedule Sunday. To assure the foreign dignitaries a smooth ride to their hotels from Tokyo's two main airports, strict controls on city freeways and major thoroughfares were put into effect. The precautions are part of Japan's largest security mobilization ever, involving nearly 37,000 police in Tokyo alone. Railway employees shut down 5,000 rental lockers and began removing trash cans and large ashtrays from dozens of train and subway stations to make it harder for terrorists to hide bombs. Since commuters no longer have anywhere to throw away their empty soda cans, station workers also taped up the coin slots of vending machines, which have been temporarily turned off. Hundreds of thousands of well-wishers are expected to brave the restrictions Monday and line the streets for a parade to take place soon after the 30-minute coronation ends. Among the foreign dignitaries arriving Saturday were King Baudouin and Queen Fabiola of Belgium, German President Richard von Weizsaecker, Prince Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands, Spain's Prince Don Felipe and Kuwait's foreign minister, Shaikh Nassar Muhammad Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah. Quayle, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Austrian President Kurt Waldheim are among those scheduled to fly in Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Americans Divided Over U.S. Buildup in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Jawad George was excited about his engagement party. But the family affair turned into a family feud over - of all things - Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Jawad, a second-generation Arab American, opposed the invasion; his father and uncle didn't. The invasion has been a wrenching experience for Americans of Arab origin, torn between reluctant pride at President Saddam Hussein for standing up to the West, and feelings of loyalty for their adopted homeland - America. A new survey, one of the very few conducted among the estimated 2.5 million Arab Americans, found a community split between supporters and opponents of the Aug. 2 invasion. Of the 692 respondents surveyed by The Arab American News, 41 percent said they supported Saddam's move, 47 percent said they didn't, and 12 percent were undecided. The poll, conducted in Detroit, which has a large concentration of Arab Americans, also found 86 percent didn't like the deployment of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia at all. Some Arab American leaders dispute the findings - a survey conducted by the Arab American Institute, for example, found only 60 percent opposed the deployment and 70 percent opposed the invasion. But all agree the crisis has presented members of the community with a painful conflict. ``When your government could be involved in war with Arabs, it causes great consternation,'' said George, executive director of the National Association of Arab Americans, a lobbying organization which counted John Sununu, who is of Lebanese descent, as one of its most active members until he became President Bush's chief of staff. George, like a majority of Arab Americans, was born here. So were his parents. Their parents came here from Palestine early this century. His father Fred, a retired carpet store owner from New Jersey, is rooting for Saddam. When George went home to his parents for his engagement party, a vehement argument broke out between the younger and older generations. ``My father feels pride. He thinks Saddam is standing up to the United States. He feels that very strongly,'' said George. Many Arab Americans share that niggling pride in Saddam for, in their view, paying back the Western powers which humiliated the Arabs for decades. Like many Arab Americans, Fred George also believes Saddam is championing the cause of Palestinians under Israeli occupation, his son said. But George and many of his contemporaries, while sympathetic to such views, also feel Iraqi atrocities in Kuwait must be stopped. The largest group of Arab Americans are descendants of immigrants from Lebanon, Palestine and Syria. Arabs from Iraq, Kuwait or other Persian Gulf countries account for a small minority. The largest group among more recent immigrants are Palestinians, many of whom fled Israeli occupation. ``The newer arrivals distrust U.S. policy as blindly siding with Israel,'' said Tony Mansour, chairman of the American Arab Heritage Council, an anti-discrimination group in Detroit. Indeed, 57 percent of those polled in the newspaper survey said the decision to send American troops to the Persian Gulf would ultimately benefit Israel. And 90 percent of those asked by the AAI, a lobbying group which encourages Arab Americans to run for political office, accused the administration of a double standard - one toward its ally, Israel, and another toward Iraq. ``There has to be a recognition that there's no difference in Iraq occupying Kuwait and in Israel occupying the West Bank, Gaza'' and other lands it captured in its wars with the Arabs, said Mansour. ``Many feel it's hypocritical to get riled up about one and not the other.'' The administration rejects such parallels, arguing that while Israel must eventually give up occupied territory in return for peace, the lands were captured in wars of self-defense. Community leaders have encouraged debate about the gulf crisis and about worry that a war with Iraq will result in a backlash against Arab Americans. Many Arab Americans feel the discrimination they encountered in the past has been intensified by the conflict with Iraq. ``The issue is to feel comfortable with America,'' said James Zogby, executive director of the Arab American Institute. ``I keep telling people: this is your country, even if you disagree with what the administration is doing.'' Mohamed Hallaj, editor of the quarterly Palestine Perspectives, thinks most Arab Americans oppose the deployment of U.S. troops because ``they can't understand what American interest justifies a possible catastrophic war.'' But that doesn't call their loyalty into question, he says. Just like opposing the decision to send U.S. troops to Vietnam in the 1960s, he says, ``didn't make those people any less American.''

DOC.HEAD: Hope for Fair Elections After Duvalierists Barred
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd pvs to fix typo in word ``forced''
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Keeping holdovers from the Duvalier regime out of the presidential race has kindled hopes of fair elections, but many Haitians fear the candidacy of a leftist priest will provoke violence. The Electoral Council disqualified 12 of 26 candidates from running in the Dec. 16 election. Many were officials of the brutal Duvalier family dictatorsip that ruled this Caribbean nation for 29 years. Some of those rejected said they would challenge the council's decision in court, but there was no immediate violence. A similar prohibition in 1987 led to an army-supported rampage that forced the election to be canceled. This time the army appears to be doing its job, perhaps encouraged by the presence of about 300 election observers from 30 countries. The observers are part of a team from the United Nations and Organization of American States that will monitor the vote. Soldiers guard the Electoral Council headquarters, city intersections, banks and supermarkets. ``The army has decided it does not want to sit down and eat at the table of the hard-line Duvalierists,'' said Louis Roy, president of the Council of State, a quasi-legislative body that shares power with interim President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot. Theirs is the fifth government since President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France in February 1986, ending the dynasty begun by his father, Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier. In less than five years, there have been three military coups and a canceled election, in 1987. The last election, in 1988, is widely believed to have been rigged by the army. This time, a central question is whether the army and Duvalierists will tolerate the candidacy of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a populist priest who became presidential candidate at the last minute. ``He upset everyone's calculations,'' Roy said. ``The army must now decide whether or not it can swallow the morsel on the table set by Aristide.'' Two candidates rejected by the electoral commission were among the dictatorship's most notorious officials. Roger Lafontant, head of the private Duvalier militia, the Tonton Macoutes, and Claude Raymond, who was believed to be involved in the 1987 election massacre, were disqualified for technical reasons. Roy said Aristide ``may lose votes with the drop in social tension, but he remains the leading contender because he enjoys the backing of the impoverished masses.'' The 37-year-old Roman Catholic priest was dismissed from the conservative Salesian Order in 1988 for being a ``protagonist of destabilization.'' His outspoken pulpit oratory made him a favorite of the masses, but an enemy of the establishment. Aristide often is accused of being a communist and has survived at least three assassination attempts, most recently in September 1988. Thugs supported by the army invaded his church during Mass, killed 12 parishioners and wounded dozens more. Followers shielded Aristide and he escaped unharmed. ``What is essential to me is not being a priest, but being a Christian,'' he said in a recent interview, when asked whether politics and the priesthood conflicted. He believes in liberation theology, a grass-roots movement that has taken hold in Latin America among priests and lay workers who advocate church involvement in the causes of the poor. Aristide describes his calls for protest as ``active non-violence.'' The priest's candidacy may have contributed to the high number of registered voters. About 3 million people have registered, at least 85 percent of those eligible in this nation of 6 million, compared with 75 percent for the aborted 1987 election. When election officials disqualified Duvalierists in 1987, a plague of violence began that took hundreds of lives in nightly shootings. On election day, gangs of thugs shot and hacked 34 voters to death. ``We do not provoke violence, we suffer from it,'' said Aristide, who remains a priest but cannot officiate at Mass. Many middle-class Haitians are skeptical of his administrative abilities and wary of his populist politics. Aristide also has detractors in the influential Catholic hierarchy, which has condemned his ``Church of the Poor.'' The church ``may go so far as to unfrock Aristide, lest people think it endorses his demand for urgent social transformation,'' said Jean-Claude Bajeux, a human rights activist. Some supporters of Aristide think the United States also would block him from the presidency because of his radicalism, but the U.S. Embassy denied it. ``We have lived with worse,'' a high-ranking embassy official said on condition of anonymity. ``We can learn to live with Aristide, provided he is the choice of the Haitian people. We only insist on the honesty of the electoral process.''

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Reports Terror Among Red Army Troops in Germany
With AM-Germany-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is deeply worried about Red Army troops in former East Germany, and a magazine said extortion, terror and mysterious deaths are rampant among Soviet forces on German turf. Speaking at a dinner late Friday night, the Soviet president appealed for Germans to be patient with the huge Soviet army that is to be pulled out of former East Germany over the next four years. Gorbachev spoke of ``painful tones, even an anti-Soviet flavor'' among people in former East Germany. He said ``this remains a sensitive side'' of German-Soviet relations. People in eastern Germany have been showing growing intolerance with the continued - if temporary - presence of the Red Army troops. That's not the only problem confronting Red Army troops on German soil. Hundreds of Red Army troops are believed to have fled into the German woods in recent months, escaping bleak garrison lives. Soviet troops desperate for German marks have reportedly been raiding their units' weapons depots and base exchanges, selling everything from missiles to pornographic videos. In its most recent editions, the German magazine Stern painted a baleful picture of desperation, suicides, mysterious deaths and extortion among Soviet troops in Germany. ``Terror, murder and corruption reign among the troops,'' Stern reported. ``A hated occupier, the 380,000-strong Red Army has become an army of bandits.'' Stern said its information came from Soviet soldiers it has interviewed. It quoted one former Soviet officer, identified as Eduard Melnikov, as saying that at pay time every month older soldiers force younger ones to hand over ``protection money.'' ``If you refuse to pay, you'll be thrashed nightly,'' Stern quoted him as saying. Extortion has spiraled in recent months because of Soviet soldiers' access to German marks since July 1, the magazine reported. Stern said there are growing numbers of cases where soldiers land in Red Army hospitals with broken bones and other injuries caused by beatings. Stanislav Kaminski, another Soviet soldier who fled his unit, was quoted as saying: ``Officially, it's called service accidents. But everyone knows that they were beaten up by their superiors.'' Suicides among theps have risen dramatically because of such treatment, it quoted one former soldier as saying. Soldiers have hanged themselves, cut their wrists, or poisoned themselves to end the misery they experience in garrison life, said Stern. The magazine reported one case in which a 19-year-old recruit, identified as Valery Grischin, refused to pay extortion money and was found dead a month after reporting for duty at a barracks near Potsdam. The official cause of death was suicide. But when the soldier's parents opened his coffin in the Soviet Union they found his throat had been cut and the wound sewn back together, said Stern. In addition, his skull had a deep gash and his left arm was broken, said the magazine.

DOC.HEAD: From the Sands of Saudi Arabia: Happy 215th Birthday, Marines
With AM-Gulf-Offensive, Bjt
LaserPhoto DHA2
DOC.TEXT: Leave it to the U.S. Marines to find novel ways to celebrate their 215th birthday Saturday in a liquourless desert. Marines delivered as much pomp and ceremony as they could. At the main party, a band from the 1st Marines Expeditionary Force slung rifles and gas masks with their trumpets and tubas, escorts carried a birthday cake on a stretcher and a color guard adorned in desert camouflage instead of dress blues paraded with the U.S. and Marine Corps flags. ``We'd have to be up to our ears in firefights to keep us from celebrating,'' said 1st Sgt. George Spear, 40, of Coleman, Ala. Spear recalled a time 21 years ago when he was pulled off Hill No. 41 near Da Nang in the Vietnam War and put on duty in the rear as a cake carrier. ``No matter where we are, we're going to take time out to celebrate who we are and what we are,'' said Spear. According to one unconfirmed report, a Marine had called to make dinner reservations for 30,000 at a hotel in Kuwait City. That's how many Marines are on the ground in Operation Desert Shield. Marines in the remotest desert foxholes took time from their duties to mark the day in 1775 when the Continental Congress authorized the formation of two battalions to fight on land and sea. Since then, the Marines have fought storied battles at the Argonne, Guadalcanal, Iwo Jima, Chosin Reservoir and Khe Sanh. The Marines have been called on more than 240 times to charge ahead on foreign shores. Every Marine in the world celebrates the birthday. At the main desert celebration, they ate a three-tiered yellow cake with white icing from disposable plates. Some units toasted themselves with non-alcoholic beer. ``Marines, you're a special breed. There are no others in the world like you,'' said Lt. Gen. W.E. Boomer, commander of the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force deployed in Saudi Arabia. Boomer then cut the cake with a saber. The traditional drink of rum was missing because alcohol is taboo in conservative Saudi Arabia. The Marine band was flown by helicopter to 18 desert stops in the past two days to entertain their ranks. Elsewhere, the Marines gave a special reception to Brig. Gen. Patrick Cordingly, commander of the British 7th Armored Division, or ``Desert Rats,'' who are under Marine command here. As Cordingly spoke, the Marines barked and grunted - a tradition passed on when they were called ``Devil Dogs'' by the Germans for the ferocity in which they fought in World War I. ``You've frightened me,'' Cordingly told the troops. ``Heaven knows what you'll do to the other side.''

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Surrender After Hijacking Thai Plane Carrying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with students surrendering; Pickup 3rd, `The Bangkok...'
DOC.TEXT: Three Burmese students who Saturday hijacked a Thai Airways jetliner with 221 people aboard demanding the release of dissidents imprisoned in Burma, later surrendered to Indian officials, police said. The last of the passengers and crew were released unharmed eight hours after the Thai Airways plane landed, a senior police officer said on condition of anonymity. The hijackers had already released about half the passengers. Press Trust of India also quoted government officials in New Delhi as saying the hijackers had surrendered after freeing all their hostages. No details of the surrender were available immediately. The Bangkok-to-Rangoon flight was commandeered shortly after takeoff by three young men armed with hand grenades and guns, according to Manish Gupta, home secretary of West Bengal state. Indian police had surrounded the plane but stayed 200 yards away after the hijackers warned them not to approach the plane. Most of the police carried no visible firearms. Once on the ground, the hijackers gave freed passengers a two-page letter outlining their demands, an airport control tower source said on condition of anonymity. He said the letter, handwritten in English, demanded the release of a half-dozen members of the Burmese Liberation Front who have been imprisoned by Burma's military government. The hijackers also demanded a meeting with representatives of the governments of Burma, Thailand and India, the control tower source said. Thailand's consul general in Calcutta came to the airport, but there was no sign of Burmese officials. The Burmese government crushed a pro-democracy movement two years ago and continues to detain large numbers of people for political reasons. Shortly before news of the hijacking emerged, reports circulated in Bangkok that students opposed to the Burmese government planned to hijack a plane today. Swedish journalist Bertil Lintner, who has written books on Burma, received a statement from a group calling itself the Warrior Operation, outlining the hijackers' plans and demands. ``Do not worry for the hostages,'' it said. ``We have no desire to harm the passengers and crew... We just want the world to hear our pleas for justice and human rights.'' The group's demands included the release of pro-democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi - who is under house arrest in Rangoon - an end to martial law, and cancellation of all sentences passed by military tribunals. Pro-democracy forces in Burma overwhelmingly won elections in May, but the military government has refused to turn over power. The Airbus 320 landed in Calcutta, 650 miles northwest of Rangoon, before sundown. The air conditioning on the plane was either cut off or broke down after the plane landed, and some passengers became ill in the stuffy cabin, another state official said on condition of anonymity. A senior police official said the passengers were freed in a steady stream throughout the night, some because they became ill. A Thai Airways international traffic officer in Bangkok, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 205 passengers and 16 crew members were aboard. The pilot had radioed Calcutta that he needed to make an unscheduled landing because of a technical malfunction, the control tower source said. Upon landing, the pilot manipulated the airplane's flaps in a way that tipped off the ground crew to a hijack, the source said. As the pilot taxied close to the international terminal, he made a hand gesture that confirmed a hijacking was under way, the control tower source said. On Oct. 6, 1989, two Burmese students hijacked a Burmese F-28 airliner with 83 people on board. They surrendered peacefully to Thai police after a 12-hour siege.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Links Gunman to Democratic Group
DOC.TEXT: A conservative newspaper said Saturday a gunman who fired shots in Red Square during this week's Revolution Day parade was an activist for a leading liberal political group in Leningrad. Alexander A. Shmonov was seized by plainclothes agents Wednesday on the square after he allegedly fired two shots from a sawed-off hunting gun 80 yards from the reviewing stand where President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other leaders were standing. Shmonov, 38, an unemployed worker from Leningrad, has been charged with ``attempted terrorism.'' Sovietskaya Rossiya, in a short article on its back page, said Shmonov had worked for a voters' association in 1989 that was linked to the nationalist Leningrad People's Front. It reported he later was seen selling newspapers of the Democratic Union, one of the country's largest and most active left-leaning organizations, in front of factories and department stores in the northwestern Russian city. ``Participation in this `democratic' propagandizing ... had prepared him for committing this terrorist act,'' the newspaper paraphrased a former co-worker as saying. Shmonov had labored at the Izhorsky metal working plant. Olga Lipovskaya, who was a leader of the Democratic Union group in Leningrad until August, said Saturday that Shmonov did not belong to the group while she was involved. Current leaders of the Leningrad group could not immediately be reached for comment. There also was no answer at the KGB public relations center Saturday, which has offered information on the man in recent days. KGB officials have said they believe the gunman was insane and did not suggest a political motive for the shooting. The daily Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper reported Saturday that psychiatric tests on the suspect have not been completed and officials still were unsure whether he had been trying assassinate anybody. It made no mention of alleged past activism by Shmonov.

DOC.HEAD: Mail Bomb Probe Seemed to Drag, But Agents Had Suspect in a Month
DOC.TEXT: The 11-month federal investigation of the mail bomb killings of a federal judge and a Savannah alderman appeared to start slowly and bog down in a junk store in a little Alabama town. But out of the public eye, agents had zeroed in on their prime suspect less than a month after the bombings. Documents in the case of accused mail bomber Walter Leroy Moody show federal agents began staking out the Rex, Ga., man Jan. 11, almost two weeks before highly publicized searches of the home of another man, a junk dealer in Enterprise, Ala. On Dec. 16, 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance was killed by a mail bomb in suburban Birmingham, Ala.; two days later, Savannah alderman Robert Robinson was killed. Agents safely intercepted two other bombs and began investigating threatening letters connected with the killings. Moody, a self-employed editor convicted in 1972 of possessing a pipe bomb, was charged with the bombings Wednesday. But the first public development in the case came in Alabama, when FBI agents descended upon Enterprise on Jan. 22, searching the home and even the septic tank of junk dealer Robert Wayne O'Ferrell. Camera crews followed the agents' searches and O'Ferrell became something of a minor celebrity in the southeast Alabama town, selling souvenirs as he preached his innocence. Publicly, the FBI was searching for typewriters. It was widely reported that there were similarities in the typeface of critical letters O'Ferrell had written the 11th Circuit in Atlanta and the bomb-related letters. Privately, agents with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms were already monitoring Moody's movements and obtaining his telephone records. Although it would be Feb. 8 - when ATF first searched Moody's home - before the media discovered Moody, he knew he was being watched.
