Bases supporters are cautiously optimistic, however, that some senators may ultimately support an agreement if the government can convince them that a sovereign Philippines is simply hiring the Americans to run the bases. Also, all senators must face re-election in 1992, and some of them may be reluctant to face a generally pro-bases electorate on a platform of sending the Americans home.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Resumes Radar Mapping of Venus
DOC.TEXT: Magellan ended a two-week hiatus Saturday and resumed its radar mapping of the surface of Venus. The lull in the spacecraft's $744 million mission was necessary because Earth, the sun and Venus were lined up in a way that hindered communication between Magellan and controllers at National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Magellan engineer Cynthia Haynie said the orbiter began bouncing radar waves off the cloudy planet at 4:11 a.m. PST. The radar echoes are collected by Magellan for transmission to Earth, where they are assembled into maps and pictures. ``Everything went great,'' Haynie said. The mapping had been suspended since Oct. 26. Engineers used the time to work on figuring out how to fix a computer programming glitch that caused Magellan's twin solar panels to wobble. A new program to stop the wobbling will be radioed to Magellan and activated next week, said Ed Sherry, technical assistant to Magellan's project manager. The panels are essential for charging Magellan's batteries, but the vibration hasn't prevented them from gathering solar energy. Magellan uses radar because the thick Venusian clouds prevent optical cameras from photographing the planet's surface. The spacecraft was launched from space shuttle Atlantis in May 1989 and went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10. Mapping began in September. Magellan has made pictures of volcanoes, huge solidified lava flows, extensive quake faults, city-sized meteorite craters and 600-mile-wide, mile-high bulges created as molten rock pushes upward from inside the planet. It also found evidence that ocean-sized floods of molten rock once inundated more than half the surface.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Parched, Disaster Area Declared: Signs of Coming Famine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with other region declared disaster area, MINOR EDITING elsewhere, no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON2
DOC.TEXT: Drought has laid waste to the once-lush Tokar delta on Sudan's Red Sea coast for the first time this century, and the government has reportedly declared a famine-struck western region a disaster area. Both developments are signs the country faces a famine that Western relief agencies say could affect millions. The Tokar delta's 400,000 acres - once expected to be East Africa's breadbasket - have turned from rich farmland into a gray expanse of baked clay. ``This is the first year since 1899 where there is absolutely nothing,'' said the delta's chief administrative officer, al-Fadil Abdalla al-Mahdi. The delta, normally irrigated by floods from the Ethiopian plateau, was chosen by British colonial rulers in 1899 for one of three major Sudanese agriculture projects. It has long been a showpiece, spared the drought conditions that have ravaged much of Africa's largest nation. In recent weeks, the 16-month-old military government has said the nation of more than 25 million is experiencing only a ``food gap'' and predicts the coming harvest will be sufficient to prevent widespread hardships. It blamed the 1 million ton grain shortage largely on relief agencies' panic buying. Officials have seized stocks from merchants and agencies to sell at subsidized prices. But the U.S. Agency for International Development and most other major relief organizations fear a famine beginning early 1991 comparable to the mid-1980s when hundreds of thousands of Sudanese and Ethiopians perished. Another 250,000 to 500,000 Sudanese died in later years as southern rebels blocked food shipments and clashed with government troops. Last month, U.S. relief officials said as many as 8 million to 11 million Sudanese are threatened by starvation, but Sudan's government is blocking international food deliveries. ``If the actual level of need is as high as some people fear, and the donor community is not allowed to respond, we are looking at an apocalyptic situation worse than in Ethiopia in 1984,'' said Andrew Natsios, director of the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, said at the time. Unless the government changes its policies, ``there is little chance of anything happening in the near future to avert a famine,'' Richard Graham wrote for the Britain-based charity Oxfam. There were signs of concern even in government circles Saturday. Col. Faisal Medani Mukhtar, member of the nation's ruling military junta and governor of the region, was quoted Saturday as saying that news of an imminent famine in the western region of Kordufan was true. He said the situation could be even worse next year. He said there is an 80 percent crop failure in the region this year due to lack of rains. The governor was quoted as saying Kordufan has been declared a disaster area. Earlier last month, Mukhtar said his region need 300,000 more tons of food. ``People there have started to leave their homes in the area heading for Omdurman and some other major towns in the region,'' he was quoted as saying in the weekly newspaper New Horizon on Saturday. The governor was quoted as saying his government had ``approached international agencies to provide relief aid for the affected people.'' He did not say whether he received any response. Unofficial reports from the region say acute malnutrition has begun to spread. Some reports speak of deaths in the towns of Sodary and Um-Bader. In places such as Tokar, 400 miles northeast of Khartoum, signs of a famine are unmistakeable. Herdsman Hussein Mohamed Gassim has taken a job drawing water from a well to sell at up to $1.25 a barrel. He said he's sent some of his goats to relatives inland in hopes they survive. ``This is not a desert. It's the drought,'' said Gassim, who looks much older than his 45 years. ``This place was once as green as paradise itself.'' Sorghum, the staple grain for Sudanese and their animals, has become so scarce in Tokar that feeding a sheep for three days costs more than the animal will bring at market these days. The sell-off of livestock has lowered the price of a sheep to below $3.50. At that price, a sheepherder would have to sell 50 to buy a 198-pound sack of open-market sorghum. Even a government-subsidized bag, if it can be found, costs 6{ times the selling price of a sheep. A trickle of families, mainly members of the delta's Beja and Beni Amir nomadic tribes who live off raising sheep, goats and camels, have begun arriving at Tokar, a town of 32,000. Correspondents brought by the U.N. World Food Program visited about 30 families living in a cluster of hovels made of sticks and sacks. Sheik Adam Safafay, a white-bearded Beja chieftain, said another 7,000 of his people are living with relatives in or around Tokar. Fatima Nabulsa, World Food Program field coordinator, said 80 percent of the area's livestock has been lost since 1985. Thousands of other refugees from vast western Sudan have congregated in camps on the outskirts of Khartoum. The central government's policy, however, has been to play down threats of a possible disaster. Agriculture Minister Ahmed Ali Genaif said in early October the harvest would be ``satisfactory and promising.'' The military ruler, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, has said recently he believes foreigners have exaggerated the problems in Sudan to undermine his government.

DOC.HEAD: Lack of Repair Capacity Could Delay Airline Safety Program
DOC.TEXT: America's efforts to make aging airliners safer could go into a stall for lack of repair capacity, the General Accounting Office says in a report. The congressional investigative agency says federal regulations requiring stepped up maintenance over the next four years may strain the industry's limited capacity. The report, which became available Saturday, is to be formally presented to Congress in a few days. ``According to the airlines and repair stations we contacted, this increased demand for repair services may not be matched by corresponding increases in capacity in the immediate future,'' said the report. The study was requested by the House Public Works and Transportation Committee's aviation panel, headed by Rep. Jim Oberstar, D-Minn. Recent safety regulations are likely to sharply increase demand for short-term repair services over the next four years, the study said. It said the changes could affect 1,400 of the 4,100 planes in the U.S. fleet. Increased costs are expected to total $2 billion over the next four years. The amount is equal to all of 1988 expenses to repair airframes. It would raise by about 9 percent the current $5.7 billion cost of repair and maintenance for America's airliners. The report said the stepup is all but guaranteed to put a squeeze on repair capacity. It said some airlines then would have to ground airliners, ask for permission to delay repairs or fly them abroad for servicing. The GAO surveyed five airlines, Alaskan, American, Continental, Trans World and United. They account for about 39 percent of the U.S. fleet. It also studied four independent repair stations, in Everett, Wash.; Santa Barbara, Calif.; San Antonio, Texas, and Mojave, Calif. According to the report, four of the five airlines expect to be operating near 100 percent of their hangar capacity this year. It did say that three of the four independents expect to have excess capacity totaling 5 percent to 19 percent this year. But independents represent only about 20 percent of the industry and that could mean excess repair capacity around 2 percent overall, the GAO said. And it said even that slim margin could be squeezed. One repair station serviced 139 large transport craft in 1989 while turning away 153 others.

DOC.HEAD: Latvia To Punish Holiday Observers; Lithuania Issues Pasports
DOC.TEXT: In another step away from Moscow, Latvia says it will punish people who did not go to work on Revolution Day, a major holiday throughout the Soviet Union, a newspaper reported on Saturday. Another Baltic republic, Lithuania, plans to issue its own passports, according to reports. According to Soviet Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin, more than 9 million people took part in parades in various cities on Wednesday in observance of Revolution Day, the anniversary of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. However, in the Baltics and some other republics pushing for independence from the Soviet Union, local authorities tried to squelch celebrations of the holiday, which they see as a symbol of Soviet power. Latvia's justice minister announced Friday that workers who stayed home on Wednesday will be subject to disciplinary measures and some industrial bosses may be prosecuted, the Soviet government newspaper Izvestia said. Regardless of the burden on prosecutors, the republic will find a way to handle the cases, Izvestia quoted Justice Minister Viktor Skudra as saying on Latvian television. The newspaper said it was not clear how many cases there were. Izvestia also reported that Lithuania, which in March became the first republic to declare independence, has designed a new passport that meets international standards for size and shape. By decision of the republic's parliament, Soviet passports gradually will be replaced by the Lithuanian ones, the newspaper said. Izvestia did not say when the passports would be issued, or whether Lithuanians would be required to carry them. It did say that morally, a Lithuanian should give up his Soviet passport before accepting a Lithuanian one, which would mean he could not travel abroad unless the Lithuanian document is accepted by other countries. Nearly all 15 Soviet republics have launched some kind of movement for autonomy or independence from central authorities in Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Three British Women Meet Husbands; U.S. Activist Arrives
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Three British women who ignored their government's admonition not to travel to Iraq met with their captive husbands Saturday. In another development, U.S. peace activist Ramsey Clark arrived here to talk with Iraqi officials. The three British women were among 10 who arrived Friday at the invitation of Iraq to meet with male relatives held at strategic sites. The other members of the group were to meet later with their men. Iraq refers to the estimated 600 foreigners - mainly Americans, Britons, Germans and Japanese - that it holds at strategic sites as guests. The rest of the world calls them human shields - an attempt by Iraq to ward off an attack in the wake of its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Iraqi government said the women could stay to celebrate the Christmas and New Year's holidays if they wished. The women said they hoped to eventually win the release of their husbands, sons and boyfriends. One of the British women, who was not identified, arrived in Baghdad to discover that her fiancee, Miles Hoffman, 44, of Columbus, Ga., had flown to Germany with about 180 hostages released with former West German chancellor Willy Brandt on Friday. Zeinab Kelly, an Egyptian-born Briton, met Saturday with her husband at the downtown Mansour Melia Hotel. ``I am really very happy to be reunited, and I hope that he will be released,'' she said. She would not say where her husband had been held or give other details about him. The British Foreign Office had called the British womens' trip ``risky'' and advised them not to go. The women paid their own way. Meanwhile, a heartbroken British father flew home to London from Iraq Saturday night with the body of his son, who died in an auto accident on his way to freedom. Bruce Duncan and another son, Rory, 19, flew to London's Heathrow airport on a Royal Jordanian Airlines flight from Amman, Jordan, with the body of 20-year-old Alex Duncan. Alex Duncan died in a car crash on his way from Kuwait to Baghdad on Oct. 23. He and other family members had been on their way to join a group of Britons freed through a mercy mission to Baghdad by former British Prime Minister Edward Heath. The elder Duncan declined to speak to reporters but his brother Hedley, who was at the airport to meet them, said: ``My brother wants to say that although he is happy to be back his happiness is tinged with a certain amount of sadness with the loss of Alexander. ``But he hopes very much that the death of his son will lead somehow to the release of all of the hostages in Iraq and Kuwait.'' The Duncan family had been living in Kuwait when the Iraqi invasion occurred. Ramsey Clark, a former U.S. attorney general, arrived in Baghdad on a scheduled flight from Jordan for a two- to three-day visit at the invitation of the Iraqi Friendship, Peace and Solidarity Organization. Clark told reporters he had three basic goals for his trip, a personal visit during which he was to meet with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and other officials. He said he wanted ``to secure peace and avert war in the region,'' to ``alleviate the suffering of refugees and others'' and to ``open up communication with Iraqi officials.'' Clark has an extensive history of dealing with figures that the U.S. government keeps at arm's length. He met the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini during Khomeini's exile in France, but was rejected as an envoy when he tried to fly to Tehran to discuss the release of hostages seized at the U.S. Embassy in November 1979.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Warns Americans In Peru
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Saturday warned Americans in Peru to avoid areas around embassies, government buildings and restaurants in downtown Lima because of the possibility of violence. The department issued a statement saying that because of violence by the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, Americans should guard their movements around such areas for the rest of the Veterans Day weekend. The department statement did not give further details on what prompted the warning. The department issued a warning in May saying that the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement was believed to be planning to kidnap foreigners, especially Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Four Men Shot and Killed in Northern Ireland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with IRA claiming responsibility, comment from police official; EDITS to conform. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen on Saturday killed two policemen and two civilians who had been duck hunting on the shores of a lake, and the outlawed Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility. Hugh Annesley, chief constable of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, said the slayings were ``repulsive, futile and cowardly.'' ``They will put back rather than hasten any solution to the problems of Northern Ireland,'' he said. The IRA said in a phone call to a local radio station it had carried out the killings. They brought to 70 the number of people slain in sectarian attacks in Northern Ireland this year. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule and unite the Protestant-dominated province with the overwhelmingly Catholic Republic of Ireland under a leftist administration. The bodies were discovered at Castor Bay on the southeast corner of Lough Neagh, 20 miles from Belfast, said a spokesman for the Royal Ulster Constabulary, the province's police force. One of the policemen is believed to be an inspector and the other a reserve constable, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. He said none of the men had been identified. Three of the men were found still in their car and the fourth was discovered close by, said the spokesman. He said the party had set off on the duck-hunting trip shortly after 2 a.m. Police said they believed a car found burned out at nearby Craigavon was used in the ambush.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rains Soak East, Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains soaked the Northeast and the Pacific Northwest on Saturday, causing the threat of flooding in various areas. A storm that produced downpours across the Carolinas and Middle Atlantic States crept up the coast, dumping more than 2 inches on Cape Hatteras, N.C., Washington, D.C., and Baltimore. Flood watches were posted Saturday for all of southern New England, northern New Jersey and for southeastern New York state. A winter storm warning was posted for upstate New York, where 4 to 8 inches of snow were expected. A mixture of snow and rain fell over that area early Saturday afternoon. Up to 4 inches of snow had accumulated in higher elevations. Increasing winds in southeastern New York gusted to 47 mph at LaGuardia airport Saturday, and gale warnings were in effect along much of the Atlantic Coast from Virginia to Maine. Strong northwest winds also blew through the Southeast. High winds and heavy rain wracked western Washington state, with nearly 3 inches of rain falling in the Seattle-Tacoma area. Unofficial totals in Whatcom County ranged up to 9 inches. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunny skies from California to the lower Mississippi Valley. The low for the Lower 48 Saturday morning was 11 degrees at Grand Forks and Devils Lake, both in North Dakota.

DOC.HEAD: Founder of French News Service Dies
DOC.TEXT: Henri Deramond, founder of the French agricultural news agency Agra-Presse, has died in his hometown in southern France. He was 79. Deramond died Thursday in the town of Pamiers near the Spanish border, his family reported Saturday. No cause of death was given. He was trained at the Institut Pasteur and National Agronomic Institute in agricultural engineering. In 1944, he became director of Farmers' Liberation, an industry journal. Three years later, he founded Agra-Presse, of which he was president until 1978. From 1971-73, he was president of the French Federation of News Agencies and remained affiliated with the organization as its honorary president. He was also honorary president of the Association of Agricultural Journalists. He was married twice and had two daughters from his first marriage. His family made no announcement of funeral plans.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Education Board Approves Books Teaching Evolution
DOC.TEXT: The state Board of Education on Saturday approved science textbooks that teach the theory of evolution despite objections from those who say alternative views get short shrift. Textbooks for Texas schools have long been a point of contention between supporters of evolution theory and creationists, who ascribe the origin of species to acts of God as described in the Bible. Texas, as one of the nation's largest purchasers of textbooks, influences what publishers put in the books. ``These are the best biology textbooks that have ever been presented to the public schools of this state,'' said board member Will Davis after the books were approved, 11-4. But board member Jane Nelson said most of the books offer insufficient evidence rebutting evolution theory or suggesting flaws in the theory. The board had asked publishers to include such evidence, she said. ``I feel that this board's integrity is at stake,'' Ms. Nelson said. The theory of evolution holds that existing species of plants and animals developed from earlier forms, through hereditary transmission of slight variations in successive generations. ``I don't think the issue is that we want to put religion in the biology textbooks,'' Ms. Nelson said. ``I just want to give enough information for the teachers to use to show that we haven't proven the theory of evolution.'' ``I think when we have a 1,000-page textbook ... it doesn't hurt to have a page in there'' presenting alternative theories, said Chairman Monte Hasie, who also opposed the books. The science books approved by the state board are for first through 12th grades. They will be used for six years. The state previously has limited coverage of evolution in biology textbooks, said Michael Hudson, general counsel of People for the American Way. The civil rights group has lobbied for expanded coverage of evolution in science textbooks. ``Students in every state will benefit from the Texas decision,'' Hudson said. ``Adopting science books that adequately present evolution will help reverse the recent trend toward scientific illiteracy among American students.'' Elizabeth Judge, executive director of a Houston-based textbook review group, said the decision ``marks the end of the Dark Ages and the beginning of an enlightenment for science in Texas.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Says He Helped Bury More Than 50 Premature Babies
DOC.TEXT: A Kuwaiti doctor said Saturday he helped bury more than 50 Kuwaiti babies who died after the Iraqis halted their hospital care and, in some cases, pulled the plugs on their incubators. Dr. Ali Al-Huwail, 36, a neurologist and chief of the out-patient department at the Kuwaiti Armed Forces Hospital, said he fled his homeland last week. Iraq has organized two trips to occupied Kuwait for Western media in an attempt to rebut charges that Iraqis have looted the country and abused the Kuwaiti population since the Aug. 2 invasion. Al-Huwail said the trips were a sham. At a news conference organized by the Kuwaiti Ministry of Information in exile, Al-Huwail and three Egyptian doctors who had lived in Kuwait said the Iraqis have destroyed health care, robbed homes and hospitals, and beaten and tortured innocent civilians. Al-Huwail said 60 to 70 children died at the Gynecology and Obstetrics Hospital in Kuwait City after the Iraqis dismantled the premature infant unit. In some cases, the Iraqis pulled the plugs on their incubators, he said. With a colleague who has also left Kuwait, he said he buried more than 50 of the children in the middle of the night at a cemetery. He said this took place about Aug. 20, less than three weeks after Iraqi troops invaded. During one trip organized by Iraq, Western reporters were allowed to walk into the supposedly sterile premature baby unit, where three babies were in one room and two in another, the doctor claimed. ``The rest of the incubators were just jammed on one side, thrown ... in one corner in a storeroom,'' he said. ``It doesn't take much to realize why these are not connected.'' Al-Huwail said the Iraqis forced him to speak with the reporters, telling him it was not in his ``best interests'' to remain silent. He said he spoke in vague terms. One of the Egyptian doctors at the news conference, Samir Motawy, chairman of medical oncology at the Kuwait Cancer Center, said chemotherapy drugs, blood components and whole blood were almost non-existent in mid-October. As a result, he said, leukemia and other cancer patients were dying.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Says Discharged Reservist Only Beginning
DOC.TEXT: An Illinois Army reservist was discharged Saturday and excused from duty in the Persian Gulf after saying she was a conscientious objector, officials said. Spc. Stephanie Atkinson ``is the first reservist that's been placed on active duty who has refused to report,'' said her attorney Tod Ensign, director of New York-based Citizen Soldier. Atkinson, who had been interned since Nov. 2, was released from house arrest at Fort Knox on Saturday, said Master Sgt. Ken Distler, a base spokesman. Atkinson's mother picked up her daughter and they left, he said. Military authorities on Friday approved Atkinson's discharge under ``other than honorable conditions,'' the most adverse of the three possible discharges in such circumstances, said Fort Knox spokeswoman Laurie Viggiano. The Army, however, does not recognize Atkinson as a conscientous objector. Instead, they allowed her to be discharged in order to avoid a lengthy and costly court martial, the spokeswoman said. The 23-year-old Murphysboro, Ill., resident was a postal clerk with the 300th Adjutant General Postal Company. The unit got notice Oct. 15 that it was to go on active duty, but Atkinson was not with the group when it left for the Persian Gulf on Oct. 30. She said she thought the U.S. military was in the Persian Gulf solely for economic reasons. The Army formally charged Atkinson earlier Friday with desertion and missing movement to an overseas assignment, Viggiano said. In order to avoid a lengthy proceeding, Atkinson requested a ``discharge for the good of the service.'' If she had been convicted at a court martial, Atkinson could have faced a dishonorable discharge, a five-year prison sentence or demotion to the Army's lowest rank. Other groups are rallying behind the resistance. Last week, the National Conference of Vietnam Veterans Ministers met in Washington, D.C., to denounce the military buildup in the gulf. The Rev. R. Michael Stuart, with the Presbyterian Church USA Global Mission Unit, was in Louisville to support Atkinson. He handed out a statement from the ministers group that read: ``War does cruel violence to humanity. War dehumanizes both ourselves and our enemies. War thrusts upon us the low morality of mere survival.'' Atkinson's case is similar to one in Hawaii in which a Marine is awaiting court-martial for refusing to go to Saudi Arabia. Cpl. Jeffery Paterson is seeking conscientious objector status and has been charged with unauthorized absence and disobeying orders. He has been restricted to the Kaneohe Marine Corps Air Station since a federal judge ordered him released from the brig on Sept. 21.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Bring Flooding to Northwest, Accidents in Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf, `The National ...' to correct number of rivers to seven, sted eight.
DOC.TEXT: The ``Pineapple Express'' swelled rivers in northwest Washington state to near record floods levels Saturday, causing hundreds of evacuations, and a tornado skipped across Hatteras Island off North Carolina, knocking out power. The Gulf Coast also got walloped as wind-whipped seas caused offshore accidents from Texas to Alabama. Despite the pounding from disparate weather systems across the nation, just one death was reported. An unidentified crewman on Friday died after he fell off a ship in the Gulf. Near Biloxi, Miss., wind-driven seas threw a double barge into the Walter L. Nixon Bridge, knocking a few pilings loose. Officials said the bridge, which connects a coastal highway with Interstate 10, will be closed indefinitely. Wind kicked up Friday morning across the Louisiana coast. Offshore, winds ran up to 40 mph and gusted higher. By Saturday, the winds had slowed and seas were subsiding. A 98-foot shrimper lost power about 10 miles south of Gulfport, Miss., and was wedged underneath an oil platform in 10-foot seas. Four crewmen were rescued Friday, and the ship was anchored in a nearby gas field. At the mouth of the Mississippi River, a 75-foot trawler was pounded to splinters as its crew watched from a passing pleasure craft that picked them up. In Washington, the downpour began to subside. But hundreds of people were evacuated, unable to reach their homes or isolated by floodwaters in rural areas from the Snoqualmie Valley east of Seattle to southwestern British Columbia, more than 100 miles to the north. A helicopter was called in to pluck one elderly woman from her trailer home, said Mike Razey, an emergency services spokesman. National Guard amphibious vehicles were being used to get people out of Sumas on the Canadian border, said Bill Quehrn, a spokesman for the Whatcom County Department of Emergency Services. ``There's about 200 people in Sumas who feel they're not safe there and who want to get out,'' he said. Numerous highways were closed by high water, slides and washouts. County officials estimated the number of people evacuated, unable to reach their homes or isolated by flooding at 300 to 500 in Whatcom County, 150 in Skagit County 50 to 70 in Snohomish County and 10 in King County No injuries or major damage was reported, but officials were keeping a wary eye on dikes, levees and a few key bridges. ``It looks like we could get through with minimal damage, depending on the next weather system we get,'' said Dave Brookings, assistant flood control engineer in Skagit County. If dikes along the Skagit River become soggy and unstable, ``the whole lower basin is going to be vulnerable,'' Brookings said. ``If we have a dike failure, that could be a disaster.'' The National Weather Service reported seven rivers cresting within a foot of flood levels - the Cedar at Renton, the Skykomish at Gold Bar, the Snoqualmie at Carnation, the Snohomish at Snohomish, the Stillaguamish at Arlington, the Skagit at Concrete and the Nooksack at Deming. The deluge resulted from what forecasters call the ``Pineapple Express,'' a fall storm track that carries warm, moist weather systems from Hawaii to the Pacific Northwest. The North Carolina twister ripped roofs off homes and downed power lines and trees. But no serious injuries were reported, said Graham Wilson, spokesman for the state Division of Crime Control and Public Safety. Ferry service to the island - the only way of reaching the Outer Banks - had been suspended because of winds gusting up to 78 mph, said Tabitha Hooper at the Hatteras Ferry Office. Service was restored about noon. The only road linking Hatteras to the mainland, via Bogue Island, was ripped apart two weeks ago when a dredge broke loose from its moorings in a gale and smashed into the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge, severing the 2{-mile span. ``It's something every week. If it's not tornadoes, it's hurricane warnings,'' Ms. Hooper said. About half the island's 5,000 residents lost electricity after Saturday's storm, just about a week after getting power restored following the bridge collapse. Officials said power should be back on by Sunday afternoon. Wilson said the bridge accident could have helped emergency management authorities cope with this weather-related accident. ``We already had those generators over on Hatteras, so that could at least be one positive thing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Temblor Shakes Peru's Northern Coast
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake rolled through Peru's northern coast Saturday, but no injuries or major damage were reported, the Geophysical Institute said. The quake registered 4.7 on the Richter scale, the Institute said. Its epicenter was 40 miles southeast of the coastal city of Chiclayo, 410 miles northwest of Lima. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 4 on the scale can cause moderate damage. One measuring 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Cuts Industries' Energy in Conservation Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The government announced Saturday it will cut off energy to some inefficient state industries and reduce power supplies to others as Romania braces for a harsh winter on low oil reserves. The government also reassured the public - deprived of winter heating for years under the dictatorship of the late Nicolae Ceausescu - that homes would not be cold this season. ``All these measures will be carried out without affecting the supply of electricity and heating and other fuel to the population over the winter,'' it said in a statement broadcast on state television. The statement said the government had to cut off other supplies, however, because ``the country's hard currency resources can no longer support the current levels of energy consumption.'' It said construction sites and some mines and other money-losing enterprises would not receive any winter energy supplies, effectively closing them down. The government did not say whether the industries would have to continue to pay their workers. Unemployment is currently estimated at 10 percent. Other industries, such as transportation services, would receive 10 percent less energy than planned, the government statement said. Saturday's announcement came after Premier Petre Roman called an emergency meeting of ministers and state bank officials to discuss the worsening energy situation. Officials blamed the situation on a 20 percent drop in electricity production and depleted oil supplies due to the Persian Gulf crisis. The statement also cited widespread ``fuel pilfering'' from industrial sites.

DOC.HEAD: Meeting on Cambodia Ends With General Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Representatives from 12 countries Saturday ended a conference on Cambodia with a general agreement on a plan to settle that country's 12-year-old civil war. A statement at the end of the meeting said the participants asked Indonesia and France to prepare a comprehensive draft of the peace plan for the group's next meeting in Paris later in the month. The agreement is being worked out along the lines of a blueprint developed in August by the United States and the other four permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. Foreign ministers from the participating governments hope to sign it in December. The plan would create a mechanism for governing Cambodia during a transitional period before U.N.-monitored elections. It also involves human rights guarantees, arrangements for an end to fighting, and measures to guarantee compliance with the accord. No timetable has been set. The Vietnamese-backed Cambodia government has sent a memorandum to the French and Indonesian foreign ministers saying the U.N.-administered transition period should last no more than nine months. The memorandum from Cambodia Foreign Minister Hor Nam Hong, made public by the Cambodia news agency SPK, said the U.N. force in Cambodia ``should not be a fighting unit armed with heavy weapons and it should not have the character of a peacekeeping force.'' A U.S. diplomat has said the U.N. force could involve as many as 10,000 peacekeeping troops and 10,000 administrators. But the memorandum said the U.N. role should be defined by Cambodia's Supreme National Council. The council consists of six members of the Phnom Penh government and six of the three-faction guerrilla coalition opposing it. It has not met since September because of a dispute over who will chair the council. The memorandum said the U.N. administration should have authority ``to organize elections in a neutral political atmosphere.'' But the newly elected government alone should resolve any remaining military problems, it said. Neither the Cambodian government nor its three guerrilla enemies were present at the Jakarta meeting. Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas said the Cambodians were absent ``because we in the preliminary stages need more input, suggestions and recommendations from those who have been actively engaged in the preparation'' of the U.N. plan. The 12 nations meeting in Jakarta called on the Cambodians to renew their talks to make sure the Paris meeting is fruitful and leads to the signing of a final peace plan. Participants in the Jakarta meeting included a U.N. representative, the permanent members of the U.N. Security Council - the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France - and Indonesia, India, Canada, Laos, Malaysia, Australia and Japan. China and the United States have backed the Cambodian guerrilla factions, while the Soviet Union supports the Cambodian government, installed by Vietnam after it invaded Cambodia in 1978 to oust the extremist government of Pol Pot. The Chinese have supported the communist Khmer Rouge, the most powerful of the three guerrilla factions. Millions have died in war and political violence in Cambodia in the past two decades.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Dies of Gunshot From Another Marine's Weapon
With AM-Gulf-Offensive, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf, ``The victim xxx with identify of dead Marine
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Marine died of a gunshot wound to the head from another Marine's M16 rifle, military officials said Saturday. He was the 46th serviceman to die in Operation Desert Shield. The victim was identified by Marine headquarters in Washington as Lance Cpl. James B. Cunningham, 22, of Glendale, Ariz. He was asleep in a tent camp at the time of the shooting Friday, officials said. They said the rifle discharged a single shot. The incident is under investigation, and two Marines who were in the tent at the time are being questioned, officials said. No other details were available. The dead Marine was a member of the 3rd Marine Regiment based in Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii. So far, 43 other servicemen have died accidental deaths, one apparently died of natural causes and one committed suicide, according to military records.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Walesa Widening Lead Over Mazowiecki
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa has widened his lead over Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in the Nov. 25 vote for the nation's first directly elected president, according to a poll published Saturday. The sample of 1,000 respondents taken Nov. 5-6 showed Walesa favored by 33 percent and Mazowiecki by 18 percent. There were 37 percent undecided voters, and four minor candidates drew the rest of the votes. Of the undecided, 41 percent said they ``most probably'' will vote for Walesa and 23 percent for Mazowiecki, according to the poll published in weekend newspapers. It was conducted by the state television polling agency and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent. An Oct. 29-30 poll showed 33 percent supporting Walesa and 26 percent for Mazowiecki. Mazowiecki and Walesa head rival wings of the Solidarity labor movement, which in June defeated the Communists in Poland's first free elections since the World War II era. Walesa supported Mazowiecki as prime minister, but the two have since grown apart. Walesa favors a quicker transition to capitalism. Mazowiecki, a former journalist, is supported by the intelligentsia. If neither candidate gets 50 percent of the vote, a runoff will be held Dec. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Convicted of Slaying Five Transients in Missouri
DOC.TEXT: A 69-year-old woman was found guilty on five counts of first-degree murder Saturday in the killings of five transients to cover up a cattle-theft scheme with her husband. A Livingston County jury deliberated 2{ hours before convicting Faye Copeland. The nine-day trial's penalty phase is scheduled for Monday, when the jury will decide whether she should be executed or sentenced to life in prison. Prosecutors alleged that Mrs. Copeland conspired with her 75-year-old husband, Ray, to kill the drifters after enlisting them in a scheme to buy cattle using bad checks. After the verdict was read, Mrs. Copeland buried her face in her hands and sobbed, saying, ``I never done nothing.'' ``The families of the victims and the citizens of our state have received partial vindication,'' said Assistant Attorney General Kenny Hulshof. Defense attorneys had no comment after the verdict. Mrs. Copeland's lawyers attempted to paint her as a dominated woman who did not actively participate in the killings, but prosecutors said she was a willing participant. ``Faye Copeland is a victim - of the truth,'' Hulshof said during closing arguments. Hulshof told the jury that a letter Mrs. Copeland wrote to her jailed husband shortly after their arrests in October 1989 pointed to her guilt. Referring to police using bulldozers in a search for bodies on their 40-acre farm near Chillicothe in rural northwest Missouri, she wrote, ``Nothing found, nothing gained.'' She added later in the note: ``Things will cool down.'' Ray Copeland is scheduled to go on trial Jan. 24. Authorities acting on a tip from a drifter who once worked for the couple found four of the bodies in shallow graves and the fifth in a well. All had been shot in the head. Livingston County prosecutor Doug Roberts described the Copelands as ``20th century cattle rustlers.'' He said the Copelands made a $32,000 profit from cattle purchased by the men, most of whom were hired by Ray Copeland at missions. Many of the victims' clothes and other personal items were seized from the farm couple's home. Authorities said Mrs. Copeland made rags and quilts from the clothing. Mrs. Copeland, looking thin and frail, frequently dabbed at tears with a tissue and seldom looked up during the trial. She took the stand Friday but said she did not wish to testify. The trial drew large crowds to the Livingston County Courthouse, including more than 200 people on Friday. Some brought pillows to ease the discomfort from the hard wooden benches. ``People are talking about the trial all over town,'' said Leon Dennis, 74. ``My daughter lives in St. Louis and they're talking about it there. Murders like these just don't happen around here.''

DOC.HEAD: Lord Caccia, Former British Ambassador to Washington, Dead at 84
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS last graf to CORRECT that widow named Anne Catherine sted Nancy. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Lord Harold Caccia, a former British ambassador to Washington, has died, the Foreign Office confirmed Sturday. He was 84. The cause of his death on Oct. 31 in Builth Wells, Wales, was not given. Caccia, described by contemporaries as one of the most skilled and effective British diplomats of his generation, was sent to Washington in 1956 to restore confidence after the crisis over the short-lived invasion of the Suez Canal. Britain was severely criticized over the Anglo-French-Israeli invasion that same year, a response to Egypt's nationalization of the strategic waterway. ``In spite of arriving at a difficult moment ... he established himself and was able to make many new American friends,'' wrote Sir Roderick Barclay, a former ambassador to Belgium, in an obituary in The Independent newspaper. ``He exercised discreet diplomacy with which he skillfully helped to restore a climate of confidence between Washington and London,'' a Daily Telegraph obituary said. The Caccia family originated in Tuscany - it is mentioned in Canto 29 of Dante's Purgatory - and settled in England in the early 19th century. Caccia was born on Dec. 21, 1905 in British-ruled India where his father was a senior official in the Indian Forestry Services. After Eton and Trinity College, Oxford, he entered the Foreign Service in 1929. His first foreign posting, in 1932, was to Beijing. Returning to London in 1935, he spent some time as assistant private secretary to Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Lord Halifax. In 1943 he became an assistant to a senior envoy in Algeria, Harold Macmillan, who in 1957 became Britain's prime minister. The two men established a close rapport. Caccia returned to Greece during the civil war in the late 1940s and narrowly missed death when his jeep was destroyed by a rebel shell. During his posting to Washington, which lasted until 1961, he was a champion of the so-called ``special relationship'' between Washington and London. Upon his retirement in 1965, he was made Baron Caccia and became director to a number of companies. He also became provost of Eton College, responsible for the day-to-day running of his old school. He is survived by his wife, Anne Catherine, and two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Newspapers Set Strike Deadline
DOC.TEXT: Union newspaper workers have set a strike deadline of 5 p.m. Friday, Nov. 16, against the San Francisco Chronicle, the San Francisco Examiner and the San Jose Mercury. The Conference of Newspaper Unions, which represents 10 unions and 4,500 employees, set the deadline on Friday. The unions have been working without a contract since Feb. 2 and the action was taken in an effort to move talks from non-economic to economic concerns, conference officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MANAGUA
Protest Movement Spreads In Nicaragua, Fourth Shooting Victim Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with former Sandinista official held, quotes, color, RAISES attack on police station; picks up 5th graf pvs, `But Ortega's ...
DOC.TEXT: A protest movement demanding the removal of leftist military commanders spread Saturday with protesters occupying public buildings and holding hostage a former Sandinista official and four other people. Former Contra rebels attacked a police station Friday with AK-47 assault rifles in Nueva Guinea, 190 miles southeast of Managua. Four people were reported dead and 34 wounded. Members of President Violeta Chamorro's United National Opposition coalition seized the government telecommunications office and staged sit-ins Friday night and Saturday at several police stations in La Concepcion, 20 miles southeast of Managua. It became the 17th town to join the Civic Movement to Save Democracy, which remains largely confined to the eastern and southeastern parts of the country. With the outbreak of protest in La Conception, the movement came the closest yet to Managua, the capital. The protesters in took hostage Socorro Galan, who headed the Committee of Friendship with socialist countries under the Sandinista government, along with Galan's brother and three policemen. They blocked the entrances to the town with huge felled trees and were demanding to speak with Chamorro, Vice President Virgilio Godoy or Archbiship Miguel Obando y Bravo, said Oscar Melendez, a spokesman for the demonstrators. ``We have no weapons, only rocks and machetes and the power of God,'' said Felix Pedro Calero, a young man manning a barricade. The protesters were demanding a local military base be closed here and that guns be taken away from about 150 Sandinista cooperative farmers ``who have provoked the people'' in the area, Melendez said. Like demonstrators around the country, the protesters in La Concepcion want Mrs. Chamorro's conservative, U.S.-backed government to take control of the military away from the Sandinistas. Mrs. Chamorro defeated former Sandinista President Daniel Ortega in February elections. But Ortega's brother, Gen. Humberto Ortega, also a Sandinista, is still commander of the military and the demonstrators want him fired. Friday's firefight in Nueva Guinea left three former rebels dead and 35 people wounded, including nine policemen. Authorities later said one of the wounded died Friday night, but the victim was not immediately identified. Five of 21 people arrested in Nueva Guinea were held on weapons charges. The rest were released for lack of evidence. Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado said the shooting incident was not related to the Civic Movement to Save Democracy. But members of the group began acting 10 days ago to back demands by the former Contras for land and economic aid the Chamorro administration promised them when they demobilized earlier this year. The U.S.-backed rebels fought for a decade to overthrow the Sandinistas. Contra leaders had demanded that the Sandinistas be removed from command of the armed forces, police and other security agencies, but Mrs. Chamorro refused after she took office. Some observers said she allowed the Sandinistas to maintain some authority to mollify them as the new opposition and keep them from trying to take power again by force. Mrs. Chamorro pressured the Contras into disarming and demobilizing, promising them land and other economic aid but this has been slow in coming. The former rebels last week set up barricades on the Rama Road - the main highway linking eastern and western Nicaragua - to demand promised assistance. The roadblock remained in place Saturday. Mrs. Chamorro has been trying to get the 17 town mayors to come to Managua to talk matters over - so far without success. The protest movement also continued Saturday in Bluefields, Nicaragua's main port on the Caribbean, where demonstrators controlled the regional government building, the local television and a radio station. In Boaco, 60 miles east of the capital, protesters were also holding the telecommunications office and the agency that regulates aqueducts, running water and sewage services. The demonstrators this week also demanded the removal of Antonio Lacayo, Minister of the Presidency, whom they accuse of cozying up to the Sandinistas. Lacayo is Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law and her private secretary, and is considered the man who wields most power in the government. Nicaragua's 11 Roman Catholic bishops issued a statement Friday supporting the protest movement. The country's largest association of business leaders is also backing it.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Ends Visit With No Clear Commitment of Germany Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev, Kohl comments and chancellor's home, Gorbachev returning home; EDITS to conform. No pickup. ^LaserPhotos NY4,OGG1
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, transformed from Eastern Europe's liberator to a leader in desperate search of rich benefactors, wrapped up his visit to Germany on Saturday with no clear reply to his pleas. Thousands of Germans cheered the Kremlin chief as he toured German wine country with Chancellor Helmut Kohl. They gave him lavish thanks for letting the Berlin Wall fall and Germany unite. At one point on the tour, Kohl pledged that Germany would help Gorbachev's troubled nation as it tries to avoid economic collapse. But Kohl gave no specifics, and there did not appear to be a change in German caution about increasing the financial assistance already promised. ``We wish you success in your reform policies,'' Kohl said in remarks outside his home in the town of Oggersheim near the end of Gorbachev's visit. ``We will help within the framework of our abilities.'' Gorbachev in turn thanked Kohl and mentioned the ``long and difficult'' road both countries had traveled to reach their current state of increasingly warm relations. Earlier, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the German foreign minister, said Germany must help the Soviet Union but that aiding Moscow is not solely a German responsibility. Gorbachev returned to Moscow late Saturday. At home, he faces ominous problems, including huge losses in popularity, but thousands of Germans gave him a hero's welcome as he wrapped up a two-day visit. ``Thank you, Gorby,'' read one placard in the cathedral town of Speyer, which Gorbachev and Kohl visited. Another man held up a sign written in Russian saying, ``We wish you happiness, Mikhail.'' Still another read, ``Good luck, Gorby.'' Gorbachev, his wife, Raisa, Kohl and Kohl's wife, Hannelore, toured Speyer's 11th century Imperial Cathedral, where eight German emperors are buried. Gorbachev plunged into the crowd several times, accepting flowers and shaking hands with the crowd, which chanted ``Gorby! Gorby!'' and ``Helmut! Helmut!'' ``He did a lot for us, and we are grateful to the Germans, too,'' said Adolf Fries, a Soviet-German who was allowed to emigrate from Kazakhstan two years ago and now works as a driver in Speyer. Earlier in the day in Bonn, Gorbachev met separately with Genscher and with Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of the opposition Social Democrats. Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt, like Gorbachev a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, canceled a meeting with the Soviet leader, saying he was too tired after a hostage-freeing trip to Baghdad. Vogel said he talked with Gorbachev about the Persian Gulf crisis, which began with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. He said Gorbachev insisted all means must be ``exhausted'' to reach a peaceful solution to the crisis. Vogel was asked whether Gorbachev said he thought military action might be needed. ``He did not rule that out,'' Vogel told reporters. So far, there has been no indication from Moscow that Soviet troops would definitely take part in such an action, although Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said last week that force was acceptable as a last resort. During the tour through Rhineland-Palatinate, Kohl renewed his pledge that Germany would help the Soviet Union with badly needed financial assistance. But Kohl named no sums and gave no timeframe. ``We know that on this difficult path to (German) unity you were with us, you helped us, and we are grateful,'' Kohl said in a brief speech in the village of Deidesheim, where the two leaders ate lunch. ``Within the scope of our possibilities we will help you,'' Kohl told Gorbachev as the Deidesheim townspeople, dressed in folk costumes, cheered. Gorbachev drew strong applause when he kissed the local wine queen. ``I'd like to say we are very touched by the feelings and hospitality you have shown us. We want to develop relationships with the great German people now so together we can resolve those problems that time has put before us,'' Gorbachev said. The Soviet leader congratulated the Germans on unity, which they declared on Oct. 3, and called for greater cooperation between the two countries. Both Speyer and Deidesheim were covered with Soviet flags and campaign posters for Kohl, who is up for re-election on Dec. 2. After meeting with the Kremlin chief, Genscher appealed for all Western nations to be ready to financially assist the Soviet Union and preserve its stability. ``Stability in the Soviet Union is important for stability in all of Europe,'' Genscher told Deutsche Welle radio. One day earlier, leading German industrialist Edzard Reuter said emergency deliveries of food and clothing to the Sovet Union may be necessary this winter. Some have predicted that famine could hit parts of the Soviet Union this winter, and the current unrest there could spread even further. Shevardnadze, who accompanied Gorbachev to Bonn, on Saturday went with Genscher to the former East German city of Halle, Genscher's hometown.

DOC.HEAD: Peru to Make Payments To International Lenders, Revamp Tax System
DOC.TEXT: The government will set aside $500 million in the 1991 budget to make overdue payments to international lenders, Prime Minister Juan Hurtado Miller says. President Alberto Fujimori has sought to restore ties with foreign lenders since he took power on July 28. Relations were suspended in 1988 when former president Alan Garcia cut off payments on Peru's $20 billion foreign debt. Hurtado also said on Friday that the government plans to introduce a new tax system on Jan. 1 that will expand the tax base and simplify rates. The overdue debt payments will go to the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank, said Hurtado, who also is economy minister. Peru hopes the payments will allow it to obtain about $750 million in new loans from the institutions, he said. The 1991 budget is expected to be approved by Congress this week. About 30 percent of the budget will go to service domestic and foreign debt. As part of the tax reform, Peru's 68 tax brackets will be reduced to no more than seven, and millions of Peruvians who now pay no taxes will be included in the system, Hurtado said. Only about 2 million of Peru's 22 million people currently pay taxes. Hurtado said the tax reform is designed to collect about 15 percent of the country's gross national product for the government. Do largely to hyperinflation, the tax system under the previous government often collected less than 5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Libyan Strongman Says He Has Right To Make Poison Gas
DOC.TEXT: Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi says his country has a right to produce poison gas, a German magazine reported Saturday. The weekly Der Spiegel also said Gadhafi is asking for restitution for mines planted by the German Army on Libyan territory during World War II. ``Gadhafi wants to soon demand restitution for the countless mines that (Gen. Erwin) Rommel's Afrikakorps planted in the desert, which still today kill and injure Libyan people,'' Spiegel said. ``We need you (German) experts to finally free us of this plague,'' Spiegel quoted Gadhafi as saying in an interview that will appear in its Monday editions. Excerpts of the interview, which were provided early to other news media, did not say how many Libyans had been reputedly killed or injured by the mines. Gadhafi in the past has also demanded restitution from Italy for mines planted along the Mediterranean coast of Libya during the war. Italy has refused to pay. Spiegel asked Gadhafi about allegations his country has produced poison gas. ``Why are Americans and Israelis allowed to produce chemical weapons and nuclear bombs, but not Libya? Doesn't Libya have the right to defend itself,'' Spiegel quoted Gadhafi as saying. The United States in late 1988 accused German companies of helping Gadhafi build a poison gas plant in Rabta, 60 miles south of Tripoli. Germany at first denied the charges. But in May 1989, Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, head of the Imhausen-Chemie company, was arrested for his links to the Rabta plant. Hippenstiel-Imhausen was tried and found guilty of violating German export laws for helping Libya build the plant. He was sentenced to five years in prison in June. Gadhafi's government has repeatedly denied the plant was for production of poison gas. It said the facility was for pharmaceuticals. Despite the denials, U.S. officials said in March that Libya is producing limited amounts of mustard and nerve gases, apparently intended for use as chemical weapons. Spiegel also said Gadhafi predicted ``catastrophic results'' if war breaks out in the Middle East. It quoted Gadhafi as saying that to prevent such a conflict, Iraq should withdraw from Kuwait, and the United States should pull out of Saudi Arabia. A U.N. force made up of Arabic military units should be used to secure the area, the magazine quoted Gadhafi as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Injunction Barring CNN from Broadcasting Noriega Tapes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 17th graf, ``That remains ...' Picks up 18th graf pvs, `A tape CNN ...' INSERTS 1 graf after 22rd graf pvs, ``It is .. ' to UPDATE with details of men mentioned in tape. Picks up 23th graf, `Other tapes.'
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on Saturday upheld an injunction barring Cable News Network from broadcasting tapes of Manuel Noriega's telephone conversations with his lawyers. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals also called on the Atlanta-based network to produce the seven tapes in U.S. District Court in Miami so the court could decide whether the broadcasts would endanger Noriega's right to a fair trial on drug-trafficking charges. The ruling came after CNN on Friday defied Judge William Hoeveler in Miami, broadcasting excerpts from the tapes minutes after the judge issued an order instructing the network not to do so. CNN said it would appeal Saturday's ruling to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``We will be pursuing an immediate appeal,'' CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said in a telephone interview. Haworth said he didn't know yet if CNN would continue televising excerpts of the tapes. The appeals panel denied CNN's appeal of Hoeveler's 10-day injunction against broadcasting excerpts of Noreiga's phone calls from federal jail. It called on the network to produce the tapes in Hoeveler's courtroom so that the trial judge can determine if Noriega's Sixth Amendment rights to a fair trial have been violated by the U.S. government and CNN. ``The First Amendment interests of the press and public will best be served by immediate production of the tapes held by CNN so that the district court can conduct the difficult balancing of constititional rights,'' the appeals court said. ``CNN has shackled the district court by refusing that court's reasonable request to review the audiotapes it has in its possession,'' the court said. The Justice Department on Saturday morning filed a brief with the appeals court, claiming the tapes could make it difficult to select an unbiased jury for Noriega's trial. Noriega's right to a fair trial and effective counsel also could be compromised if details of the defense strategy are revealed to prosecutors, the brief said. ``The government cannot at this point be more specific with respect to the possible harm that could flow from publication of the tapes because the government, like the district court, does not know the contents of the materials CNN has in its possession,'' the brief states. On Friday, Hoeveler said he would hold CNN in contempt of court if it disregarded his order. But in an unusual interview with CNN outside the courtroom Friday night, the judge said he could not rule on contempt without a prosecutors' motion. On Saturday afternoon, Noriega attorney Frank Rubino asked Hoeveler to find CNN in direct civil contempt and fine the network $300,000 for each time it had televised the tapes and each time it shows them in future. Before Hoeveler could respond, CNN attorney Terry Beinstock asked the judge to disqualify himself, accusing the judge of revealing a personal bias against the network in the CNN interview on Friday night. In the interview, a CNN reporter asked Hoeveler if he planned to find CNN in contempt. ``That remains to be seen,'' the judge said. Asked why, the judge replied, ``Well, somebody's going to have to move for that and they (CNN) obviously are in contempt at the moment. The legal proceedings will take place when somebody moves for sanctions.'' In Miami, federal district Chief Judge James Lawrence King said Saturday the motion seeking to disqualify Hoeveler from consideration of the contempt issue ``will be handled in the orderly manner prescribed for such situations.'' He would not comment further. A tape CNN played Friday contained a brief conversation in Spanish between Noriega and Rubino's secretary, said to be acting as a translator for the English-speaking defense team. CNN provided an on-screen English translation and narration in English that made it impossible to hear the actual exchange. CNN said the secretary told Noriega two people have been arrested in Panama and says he should determine ``whatever they can know about you.'' Noriega says he knows only one of the people. ``It is very interesting because it shows their strategy,'' CNN translated Noriega as saying. ``It says they are trying to induce any of the two of them to testify before the court against me.'' The men apparently referred to in the tape were Felipe Camargo, a Noriega loyalist now imprisoned in Panama who had been the general's top liaison with the Cubans, and Alfredo Sanchez, whom The Miami Herald identified Saturday as a convicted drug smuggler once employed by the U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency. Other tapes played Friday included conversations between Noriega and his supporters, including a discussion with his mistress' mother about the transfer of $4 million, CNN said. Noriega is accused of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel in exchange for letting drugs move safely through Panama to the United States. He has been held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami since shortly after surrendering to U.S. soldiers who invaded his country in December.

DOC.HEAD: Deputies Awarded $2.7 Million In Sexual Harassment Suit
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. District Court jury has awarded $2.7 million to three sheriff's deputies who claimed a male officer demanded sex in exchange for favorable work reviews. In making the award Friday, the court also ruled that the Santa Clara County sheriff's department and several officials did not do enough to discourage the ongoing harassment. The deputies - Zana Murphy, Cynthia Bates and Toni Daugherty - filed the lawsuit in 1985, charging sheriff's officials with failure to investigate their complaints against Deputy Craig Nelson. The three said Nelson made lewd comments and sexual advances while he was their training officer at the county jail. The department suspended Nelson for 14 days, but the harassment continued in the form of anonymous, obscene phone calls and rumors about the women's sexual habits, said Byron Wells, a lawyer for the women. Nelson, who works for the county Department of Corrections, was dropped as a defendant this year after his insurance company agreed to pay $150,000. The county is considering whether to appeal, said Susan Levenberg, chief deputy county counsel. County lawyers had argued that the sheriff's department was not responsible for Nelson's action and that officials ``took quick and immediate response.''

DOC.HEAD: City Catering to Marine Base Expects Economic, Emotional Loss When Troops Go
DOC.TEXT: With most of the Marines from Camp Lejeune headed for the Persian Gulf, residents in this riverside city feel as much a tug on heartstrings as on purse strings. ``As long as they come back safe, we don't care about the beer,'' said Betty Hall, a bartender at the Leatherneck Tavern situated just blocks from the main gates of the Camp Lejuene base. ``The military is probably 80 percent of our business,'' said Joe Thigpen, owner of Lejeune Pawn, a pawnshop near the base. ``It's going to be bad until they get back. But I just hope war can be averted and we get accomplished what needs to be accomplished without any lives lost.'' Camp Lejeune is used by 43,000 military personnel, overwhelming the 20,000 civilian residents who make Jacksonville the biggest city in Onslow County. All told, the military and their families account for more than 94,000 of the county's 130,000 residents. The military is pervasive. It's the county's major business. When people leave the service, they often stay and jump to the other side of the cash register. Jeff Downin, director of the Jacksonville-Onslow Chamber of Commerce, estimated 35 percent to 50 percent of businesses are owned by retired military personnel. The chamber office is bedecked with Operation Desert Shield T-shirts and handkerchiefs declaring support for the U.S. troop deployment in Saudi Arabia. The first Marines from Lejeune were sent to the gulf shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The U.S.-dominated multinational force in the Persian Gulf is to be reinforced with another 200,000 American personnel by mid-January. That will raise U.S. strength in the region to around 430,000 troops. In August, 11,000 Camp Lejeune Marines were deployed. Current plans would take all but 3,500 military personnel from Camp Lejeune and the nearby New River Marine Air Station, said Camp Lejeune spokesman Maj. Jay Farrer. Figures on the military's contribution to the Jacksonville area economy are not available, Downin said. Withdrawal of much of that contribution is just as hard to gauge. ``We're going to lose retail sales, but to try to project where we'd be is impossible,'' he said. ``We've never encountered anything like this before, though.'' If financial losses are hard to measure, the emotional costs are equally uncertain. Gunnery Sgt. Michele Holmquist said the sudden absence of so many Marines might prove beneficial, though. ``They're suddenly going to appreciate us here,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of General Motors Apologizes For Using Slur in Video
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead. Note contents in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. apologized to San Francisco officials for using a homosexual slur in a promotional video poking fun at a Japanese-made vehicle. The San Francisco Board of Supervisors protested to the U.S. automaker last month after learning that the video, made to be shown only to GM personnel, referred to a Japanese-made vehicle as a ``little faggot truck.'' The use of the term violated a city human rights ordinance because it is a slur against homosexuals, the supervisors said. They threatened to cancel a $500,000 city contract with GM. GM Chairman Robert Stempel wrote back, assuring the supervisors that ``this singular unfortunate incident does not reflect General Motors policy toward lesbian and gay people.'' ``The excerpt ... is offensive and, therefore, had no place in any General Motors activities,'' said the letter, which the board disclosed on Friday. The company stopped using thevideo immediately after the supervisors complained.

DOC.HEAD: Shekhar Sworn In As Prime Minister

DOC.TEXT: Chandra Shekhar, a socialist, was sworn in as India's eighth prime minister Saturday. He will lead a country wracked by religious and caste violence with its weakest government ever. President Ramaswamy Venkataraman administered the oath in a 10-minute, midday ceremony on the red-gravel courtyard of the presidential palace. Chandra Shekhar, 63, replaces V.P. Singh, who lost the prime minister's job after a Hindu right-wing party defected from his coalition government because of Singh's opposition to a project to tear down a Moslem mosque. Chandra Shekhar's government controls about 60 seats in the 522-member lower house of Parliament. He will rely on the support of the Congress party, the largest in the house with 195 seats. Congress leader and former prime minister Rajiv Gandhi refused to form a government or join Chandra Shekar in a formal coalition. ``This government will last only as long as Congress wants it to,'' United News of India quoted Singh as saying as he left the ceremony. Gandhi, whose five-year tenure as prime minister was brought to an end by Singh almost a year ago, watched with a smile from the crowd of VIPs during the nationally televised ceremony. Hindu-Moslem violence has wracked the country, which already was reeling under a succession of riots and self-immolation suicides by upper-caste Hindu students angered by Singh's attempts to reserve more jobs for lower castes. Chandra Shekhar and Devi Lal led a breakaway faction of Singh's own Janata Dal party in joining the swelling chorus of opposition. Devi Lal, 76, was sworn in as deputy prime minister immediately after Chandra Shekhar took his oath. No other ministers were appointed. Chandra Shekhar is expected to present his full Cabinet to Parliament for endorsement by Nov. 20. By backing Chandra Shekhar, at least for the moment, Gandhi can wait for less turbulent times before making a fresh election bid to reclaim the prime minister's job his family held for most of the past 43 years. Gandhi's grandfather was India's first prime minister when Britain relinquished colonial rule in 1947, and Gandhi succeeded his slain mother, Indira Gandhi, as prime minister in 1984. Venkataraman, whose job is mostly ceremonial, asked three other parties to try to form a government before turning to Chandra Shekhar. The new prime minister, who dropped his family surname of Singh decades ago because it identified him as upper-caste, is a veteran politician but has never held a top government post. He has been elected to Parliament four times from three different parties in the last 28 years. More than 370 people have died in riots and police shootings in the past three weeks because of the Hindu fundamentalist campaign to replace a Moslem mosque with a temple in the Hindu holy town of Ayodhya. In Karachi, Pakistan, on Saturday, hundreds of Moslem fundamentalists demonstrated near the Indian consulate to protest the Indian government's decision to reopen Ayodhya to Hindu pilgrims last week. Police fired tear gas and charged the crowd with steel-tipped batons, injuring at least one person, authorities said. In another crisis, 150 upper-caste Hindus have committed suicide or died in clashes with police in protests of Singh's decision to reserve nearly half of government jobs for lower-caste Hindus. So far this year, Sikh extremists in Punjab have killed nearly 2,700 people - higher than the annual death toll in any of Gandhi's five years in office. Another 1,500 people have died in Jammu-Kashmir, where Moslem militants was to secede from India. While 82 percent of India's 880 million people are Hindu, Sikhs hold a slight majority over Hindus in Punjab and Moslems make up nearly two-thirds of the population of Jammu-Kashmir.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Leak Forces Hundreds from Their Homes
DOC.TEXT: More than 300 families were evacuated from their homes Saturday after an underground fuel line burst, spilling at least 20,000 gallons of gasoline and filling the air with strong fumes, authorities said. Officials allowed most residents to return home in the evening. James Keane, commissioner of emergency services for Erie County, said those living closest to the break would probably not be allowed to return home until Sunday. Michael McCowan, an assistant fire chief, said he and a volunteer crew were investigating a complaint of a gas odor when they found gasoline gushing from the ground in a bowling alley's parking lot. Gasoline from the 6-inch line that runs from New Jersey to Buffalo was flowing into a nearby drainage ditch that connects to the town's sewer system, he said. About 10 a.m., a crew from Mobil Oil Pipeline Co., the line's owner, cut off the flow and isolated the break, which occurred sometime before 5:30 a.m. in the Buffalo suburb of West Seneca, police and fire officials said. About 300 federal, state and local emergency workers responded to the leak, said Dwayne Lang, a dispatcher with the West Seneca Fire Department. They helped evacuate 300 to 400 families and helped the effort to contain the fuel, which leaked into the West Seneca sewer system, said Lt. John Radwan of the West Seneca Police Department. Police and firefighters started ordering residents to evacuate about 6:30 a.m., officials said. Residents were evacuated within a half-mile radius of the break and traffic was detoured, officials said. More than 100 people took refuge in the nearby Winchester Fire Company in West Seneca and were given food, and several elderly people were given oxygen to treat inhalation of gas fumes, Lang said. An emergency worker at the scene said crews had recovered more than 11,000 gallons of gasoline by about noon Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Stuntmen Injured in Filming Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to CORRECT ages, ADD variant spellings for victims' names, CLARIFY details of accident; ADDS comment from Disney and production executive. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two stuntmen were injured, one critically, when an action scene went awry during filming of the movie ``The Rocketeer'' early Saturday, authorities said. Varying reports said the two fell down an embankment or hit a tree about 3:30 a.m. during filming near the landmark Griffith Park observatory in the mountainous area above Hollywood. Jim Madeiras, 50, was in critical but stable condition from head injuries. He regained consciousness and surgery was canceled, said Adelaida De La Cerda, spokeswoman for County-USC Medical Center. Michael Sarna, 25, was treated for face cuts and discharged, she said. Police had different spellings for the victims' names, identifying them as Jim Maderas, 46, and Michael Sorna, 25. ``The Rocketeer,'' being made by Touchstone Productions, a Walt Disney Co. division, is a period film about a jet-propelled backpack and efforts to keep it from the Nazis, said Disney spokesman Erwin Okun. Disney issued a statement saying the men were filming ``a routine stunt which required the two men to be pulled by a car at approximately 7 mph, through a breakaway fence.'' ``After rehearsing the scene several times, one of the men missed his mark, broke through the fence and fell approximately eight feet. He struck a tree and was knocked unconscious,'' Disney said. ``The Rocketeer'' stars Alan Arkin, Timothy Dalton, Bill Campbell and Jennifer Connelly, according to the Hollywood trade newspaper Daily Variety. Police reports had different details. One man was wearing a prop ``rocket pack'' that, in the film, gets out of control, and the other stuntman was to grab him, Sgt. John Johnston said. The pair were dragged by cable over the ground and were to hit a balsa wood fence. Behind that were crew members and mattresses to halt the pair. ``I guess the speed must have been too great,'' Johnston said. ``It kind of shot them over the top, and they went down an incline.'' He said Sarna tumbled about 25 feet and Madeiras went about 50 feet and hit a tree. ``This was an extremely unfortunate and unforeseeable accident,'' production executive Mario Iscovich said. ``It was a routine stunt that had been rehearsed ahead of time, to be performed by professionals, and all precautions were taken to safeguard these men. We are obviously deeply upset by the turn of events.'' The men were flown to the hospital by a Fire Department helicopter. Griffith Park observatory has often been a location for movies.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Paints Bleak Economic Picture, Urges Harder Work
DOC.TEXT: Albanian Premier Adil Carcani has called on the people of his hard-line communist nation to work harder to pull the country out of economic crisis, the state news agency reported Saturday. According to a dispatch monitored in Vienna, Carcani acknowledged in a natioally televised address that the economy was facing ``numerous difficulties.'' He said the problems were mainly caused by drought and a shortage of energy supplies that will force the government to continue to increase imports. Carcani's admission of problems in the centrally planned economy was another sign of greater openness in the Balkan nation. According to a report by the Albanian news agency ATA, he said Albanians should, ``with a high spirit of responsibility and sharp discipline ... intensify their efforts for the strengthening of the economy.'' Carcani acknowledged: ``There have also been interruptions of work and a considerable number of workers are paid with only 80 percent of their wages.'' Grain and potato production targets had not been reached, he said, but the government will make up the difference by increasing imports. Albania has resisted most of the social and democratic reforms that have swept other Eastern European countries. It has embraced some changes, however. President Ramiz Alia last week told the party's Central Committee that Albania should rethink enshrining in the constitution the communists' guaranteed ``leading role'' and official atheism. But he demanded order in the country and rejected foreign prescriptions for reform. The government said four months ago it would grant passports to Albanians, after thousands stormed Western embassies in Tirana, the capital, and were allowed to leave the country. Alia said recently, however, that rules for passports had not been finalized.

DOC.HEAD: Fans Clash in London and Germany
