DOC.TEXT: About 4,000 rival soccer fans clashed before an English soccer game Saturday, damaging cars and hurling rocks, police said. London ambulance services said three people were hospitalized with minor injuries. The game between Millwall and West Ham, two east London teams, was delayed 20 minutes while police brought the fans under control. There was no word on arrests. In Rostock, Germany, soccer hooligans went on a window-breaking rampage after a game between a local team and Leipzig, police said Saturday. Police said 11 people were arrested when a group of about 30 youths rampaged through the downtown area after a game Friday, breaking windows and looting a liquor store. No injuries were reported. Repeated riots in former East Germany have led officials to consider canceling a planned game in Leipzig on Nov. 21 between the world champion German national team and a selection of former East German national players. Soccer and security officials will meet Tuesday to decide on the game, the German ADN news agency reported, quoting game organizer Rudi Glueckner.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Apologizes For Calling Thatcher a `Cow'
DOC.TEXT: A government minister apologized to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for calling her a ``cow'' during a telephone call with his wife, Mrs. Thatcher's office said Saturday night. Mrs. Thatcher accepted the apology from Richard Needham, minister for Northern Ireland, said an official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Sunday Times reported that an unidentified paramilitary group in Northern Ireland heard the call on a radio scanner and sent a recording of it to a news agency in Belfast. The report said Needham called his wife from his official car and allegedly said: ``I wish that cow would resign.'' Mrs. Thatcher has led the Conservative Party since 1975 and the government since 1979. The party's popularity has slumped, and many Conservatives believe she must resign or they will lose the next election, due by mid-1992.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Company Fined $1 Million for Plant Explosion
DOC.TEXT: BASF Corp. could be fined more than $1 million for alleged safety and health violations at its chemical plant where an explosion in July killed two workers and injured 17. Investigators from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration have recommended a fine of $1,061,100 for 133 citations they issued against the company because of the July 19 accident, which closed the plant. Among the alleged safety infractions were explosive elements stored side-by-side, unmarked exits and a failure to tell workers about potential hazards. The explosion did an estimated $50 million damage to the plant, which handled resins used in paints and coatings for aluminum food cans. The investigation blamed the blast on excessive pressure in a reactor vessel in a resin plant. Part of the vessel fractured, spewing flammable liquid and vapors into the air, said OSHA area director William M. Murphy. BASF has 15 days to contest the citations. If it doesn't, the fine is due 30 days after that. In a statement Friday, the Parsippanny, N.J.-based company acknowledged receiving the citations and said it might contest some of them. If the fine is paid in total, it would be among the 25 bigges ever collected by OSHA in its Midwest region, agency spokeswoman Deborah Crawford said.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Kept Secret Dossier on Picasso, Newspaper Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `It said ...' to CORRECT Hoover's first name. Picks up 9th graf,`Additions to ...'
DOC.TEXT: While Pablo Picasso never visited the United States, the U.S. government kept an extensive secret dossier on him for 27 years because it considered him a possible subversive, The New York Times reported in its Sunday editions. Both the FBI and the State Department kept track of the Spanish-born artist, monitoring what he wrote, said and signed, his whereabouts and his affiliations, the Times reported. The newspaper said the FBI still maintains a Picasso file, although the artist died 17 years ago at the age of 91. Picasso spent most of his life in France. The documents show that U.S. officials worried about the effect Picasso, who joined the French Communist Party in 1944, might have on public opinion in the United States, the newspaper said. The article was written by author Herbert Mitgang, whose 1989 book, ``Dangerous Dossiers,'' examined the FBI's practice of maintaining files on leading writers residing in the United States, including Nobel laureates Sinclair Lewis, Ernest Hemingway, William Faulkner and John Steinbeck. Mitgang said he obtained the Picasso files 2{ years after requesting them under the Freedom of Information Act. He said some pages in the files were withheld and others had paragraphs blacked out. The FBI labeled Picasso as a ``Security Matter - C'' (for Communist) and as a possible ``Subversive,'' the newspaper said. It said FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover initially took notice of Picasso when the artist wrote a statement in 1944 titled ``Why I became a Communist,'' in which he wrote, ``My joining the Communist Party is a logical step in my life, my work and gives them meaning.'' Additions to the Picasso file grew smaller in the 1960s, but his name appeared in FBI references up to 1971, the newspaper said. Mitgang said that to find out more about Picasso's politics, he spoke to a friend of the artist, Dominique Desanti, who was active in the French Resistance. Mrs. Desanti, who teaches at New York University, told Mitgang that Picasso was ``a Communist but not a party-line Communist. He never attended his cell meetings in Vallauris, the little town (in France) where he lived - if there was a meeting, they came to him.'' ``Had he known the FBI was watching him, he would have laughed his head off,'' Mrs. Desanti said. ``He might have put on a mask maker's red nose and made jokes about it. No doubt he would think such an absurd thing was surrealistic.''

DOC.HEAD: Twin-Engine Plane Explodes Over Swamp, Apparently Killing Three
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine plane exploded at 4,000 feet over the Everglades, apparently killing the three people on board, the U.S. Coast Guard said Saturday. The pilot, a 70-year-old man, was traveling with his wife and a friend, who were both in their 60s, said Petty Officer Carl Vitevitch. Debris from the Cessna 421 aircraft was spotted in a mangrove swamp in southwestern Florida on Saturday. The victims' names were being withheld until search crews could reach the wreckage, probably on Sunday, officials said. The private aircraft took off Friday from Key West headed for Naples in southwest Florida, Vitevitch said. Friends waiting for its arrival in Naples called authorities when it failed to arrive. The crew of a commercial airliner reported seeing a fireball in the sky at 2:47 p.m. Friday, and radar tapes show the Cessna's transponder quit sending signals at that time, Vitevitch said. A transponder sends radio signals automatically. The cause of the explosion was unknown, and there were no immediate clues, Lt. Robin Kane said. ``No one talked to them before the crash,'' he said. ``They had no communication with anyone, so we really don't know what happened.'' Officials said a Coast Guard helicopter had spotted a wing and smaller debris in a mangrove swamp about 5 miles north of Cape Sable, which is situated 75 miles southeast of Naples.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Shows Leland Palmer to Be Laura's Killer
DOC.TEXT: Daddy killed the ``Twin Peaks'' homecoming queen. At least that's how it seemed. ABC had promised to solve Laura Palmer's murder in Saturday night's episode, which comes during television sweeps, of its weird and wild series set in a logging town in the Pacific Northwest. Of course, creators David Lynch and Mark Frost didn't make it neat. Leland Palmer was not arrested for his daughter's murder. And he seems about to kill again. In fact, somebody else was hauled off to jail. In fact, FBI agent Dale Cooper and Sheriff Harry S. Truman haven't solved the murder, though there's a chance Cooper will properly interpret a vision he has seen and save Laura's cousin from death at the hands of Leland, who apparently is also the ``Bob'' that fans have known is the killer. Or a spirit who moves the killer. Or something. Earlier in the episode, Benjamin Horn, just minutes after telling his own daughter he was in love with Laura, was dragged off to the sherrif's station for questioning in Laura's murder. Benjamin, the debonaire but dastardly dad, was always a good candidate for killer, what with his ownership of a brothel, his sexual wanderings and dealings with drug dealers. ``Twin Peaks'' could use a boost in the ratings the solution could generate. According to the latest A.C. Nielsen Co. numbers, the series was third in its time period last week, with a 7.9 rating and a 16 share. A rating point equals 931,000 television households. A share is the percentage of television sets in use in the time period that are turned to the show.

DOC.HEAD: First Heart-Liver Transplant Recipient Taken To Hospital With Fever
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf, `Stormie and ...' to UPDATE with comment from family friends. Picks up last graf, `Stormie received ...'
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, traveled to Pittsburgh on Saturday night after spending most of the day hospitalized in Fort Worth with a fever. Doctors at Pittsburgh Children's Hospital will examine Stormie to determine whether they need to adjust her medication, said her mother, Lois Purcell. The 13-year-old girl was taken to All Saints Episcopal Hospital from her home in suburban Fort Worth on Saturday morning complaining of a fever, Mrs. Purcell said. Stormie and her mother left Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport on Saturday evening. A family friend, Teresa Millikan, said Stormie had not been feeling well since mid-week. ``She doesn't feel good, she's tired,'' Ms. Millikan said. ``She hasn't been able to sleep for the past three nights. She's had it pretty rough.'' Stormie received the double transplant at the Pittsburgh hospital in 1984. Hepatitis damaged that liver and in February, she received a second liver. In July, she was again treated for hepatitis, which damaged her second transplanted liver.

DOC.HEAD: Diabetes in Pregnancy Boosts Risk of Obesity in Children, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Children born to diabetic mothers run a significant chance of being severely overweight at age 8, even though they tend to be of normal size at age 1, a new study says. The reason for the childhood obesity is a mystery, Dr. Bernard Silverman says. But the the risk may be reduced if the mother keeps tight rein on her blood sugar levels during pregnancy, he said. About half the 8-year-olds from diabetic pregnancies in the study weighed more than 90 percent of typical American children at that age. ``They're enormously obese,'' said Silverman, a pediatrician at Children's Memorial Hospital in Chicago. ``We assume they are at risk for developing the problems that other obese populations are at risk for,'' such as high blood pressure and heart disease, he said, ``but it will be years and years before we can tell that.'' Most mothers of children in the study had developed diabetes during pregnancy, which is called gestational diabetes. The other mothers were diabetic beforehand. Diabetes is a disorder of high blood sugar. Almost all the mothers who had it before pregnancy had Type 1 diabetes, which means their bodies were not producing enough insulin to control blood sugar levels. The women who developed diabetes during pregnancy generally had the Type 2 variety, in which the body fails to use insulin properly. Silverman spoke in a telephone interview before reporting results Friday at a Chicago meeting sponsored by the American Diabetes Association. The study, done with Northwestern University in Chicago, focused on 124 children who were born of a diabetic pregnancy. The racial mix was similar to the general population in Chicago, Silverman said. They were heavy at birth, as previous studies would predict, but normal size at age 1. The marked obesity appeared between ages 6 and 8. At age 8, 54 percent of the boys and 44 percent of the girls weighed more than 90 percent of typical 8-year-olds. The 90-percent mark for typical children is 68.9 pounds for boys and 69.7 pounds for girls. Another analysis focused on median weight, the point where half the population weighs more and half weighs less. The median for boys in the study was 71.3 pounds, in comparison to 55.7 pounds for typical 8-year-old boys. Half the girls in the study weighed more than 68.2 pounds, while the typical mark is 54.6 pounds. One clue to a possible explanation was that children who were heavier at ages 6 to 8 tended to have had more insulin in the amniotic fluid that surrounded them between the 32nd and 38th weeks of gestation. Silverman said the insulin was created by the fetus, in response to blood sugar from the mother. Because of that process, fetuses in diabetic mothers would pump out more insulin than those in non-diabetic mothers, and long-term exposure to these higher levels might set them up for later obesity, Silverman suggested. Insulin may make fat cells larger or more numerous, or affect areas of the developing brain that control appetite, or have some long-lasting affect on a child's metabolic rate, he said. The possible link to the mother's blood sugar suggests an additional reason for pregnant women with diabetes to control their blood sugar levels as tightly as possible, Silverman said. No child in the study has yet developed diabetes, nor do the children show unusual rates of medical problems, he said. Dr. David Pettitt of the National Institutes of Health called the study important. Similar results had previously been found in the Pima Indians of Arizona, who are unusually susceptible to Type 2 diabetes, but the new study shows ``this is not just a phenomenon of Pima Indians,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sweeps Promise: ABC Says Laura Palmer Killer Will Be Revealed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By SCOTT WILLIAMS
DOC.TEXT: This is sweeps time on television, when sex, violence, intrigue, bad taste, bizarre behavior and unhealthy relationships dominate the TV airwaves. No, it's not ``Geraldo.'' ABC promises to reveal the killer of Laura Palmer in Saturday night's episode of ``Twin Peaks,'' the most written-about, least-watched nighttime soap opera on television. You remember Twin Peaks, the broody little Pacific Northwest lumber town where absolutely nothing is ever quite what it seems. An FBI agent and the sheriff are tracking the killer of homecoming queen Laura Palmer. The sweeps, which come up four times a year, are when viewership is closely measured, so that your local network affiliate can set its advertising rates. The network has extensively promoted ``Twin Peaks.'' Its on-air promotion is tied to ads in TV Guide, The New York Times and other print outlets that declare: ``Find out who killed Laura Palmer. Really.'' Really? ``Yes,'' ABC spokeswoman Janice Gretemeyer said Wednesday. ``I can assure viewers that on the Saturday night episode of `Twin Peaks,' the killer of Laura Palmer will be revealed at last.'' Well, OK, but this isn't the first time ABC has promised to deliver the goods. Last year, an ABC executive told reporters the killer would be revealed in the season finale. It was not revealed. ABC says it showed us the killer in the series' two-hour season premiere on Sept. 30. In the last five minutes, a shadowy sharp-featured, evil-seeming, gray-haired man named Bob, whom viewers have seen only through the characters' visions and dreams, was placed at the scene of the crime. Bob was seen to strike vicious hammer-like blows on what presumably was Laura Palmer. That prompted one TV writer to suggest that Bob's bludgeoning was an attempt to administer CPR. And there's another problem: Subsequent episodes have suggested that Bob may be a demonic force or even extraterrestrial being who requires a human host. Goshawinkies! Hollywood gossips said the series' creator-producers David Lynch, director of ``Blue Velvet'' etc., and Mark Frost were under pressure from ABC to resolve the killing during the November sweeps. Lynch is directing Saturday night's episode, in which he also guest stars as Gordon Cole, the hard-of-hearing boss of FBI Agent Dale Cooper (played by Kyle MacLachlan). Michael Ontkean plays Sheriff Harry S. Truman. As it has in the past, ABC did not release previews of the show to reviwers. Die-hard fans of the show will have to settle for ABC's tantalizing synopsis of the episode: ``The identity of Laura Palmer's killer is revealed after Cooper and Truman's investigation receives some vital help from the one-armed man; finances strain the relationship between Shelly and Bobby; Audrey Horne confronts Ben with what she knows about One-eyed Jack's; and Leland Palmer tries to discourage Maddy from going home.'' The episode is certain to give ``Twin Peaks'' a much-needed boost in the ratings. According to the latest A.C. Nielsen Co. numbers, ``Twin Peaks'' was third in its time period on Nov. 3, with a 7.9 rating and a 16 share. A rating point equals 931,000 television households. A share is the percentage of television sets in use in the time period that are turned to the show.

DOC.HEAD: Fido Has an Attitude; Doc Has an Answer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By ANNE M. PETERSON
DOC.TEXT: Gretchen was highborn, beautiful and intelligent. But the 7-year-old German shepherd just couldn't stand noise - any noise. At night, especially, the slightest sound would send Gretchen running, barking, growling. It got so bad that Gretchen's owner started sleeping on an upstairs couch, as far as possible from the skittish dog. ``The dog always had a phobia of serious thunderstorms, but somehow over the years it ballooned. When she came to us she was a panting, nervous wreck,'' said Dr. Nicholas Dodman, a Tufts University veterinarian. Dodman, an animal behaviorist and associate professor of surgery, is among those who believe animals can be treated like humans for many of the same anxieties: aggression, compulsive behavior and depression. Gretchen, for example, was treated with mild tranquilizers, a new diet and exercise. Her owner was counseled on a ``happy routine'' that would allay some of the dog's anxieties. ``People ask, `Are you a dog psychologist?' But really you can't be, because you can't communicate with animals verbally. You can't ask them about their problems and expect immediate feedback. Veterinarians have to be everything to animals - doctors and psychologists,'' Dodman said. Pets most frequently suffer from types of aggression, phobias and improper elimination due to stress. Dodman said the first step to treat those problems, which also can be manifest in biting and barking, is to look for medical disorders. One of Dodman's patients, a cat named Pepper, overate. But his binges weren't limited to cat food. Pepper would eat anything: parts of sofas, blankets, shoes. He wasn't picky. Dodman ran tests on the cat, and found that Pepper suffered from pica, an eating disorder that causes sufferers to crave roughage. Dodman prescribed a high-fiber diet and Pepper was cured. Dodman said treating emotional disorders in animals can save millions of pets that are put to sleep every year in the United States because owners and neighbors cannot tolerate their poor behavior. About 10 million to 15 million dogs and cats are put to sleep in the United States each year. Penny Cistaro, the director of shelter operations at the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, says many people are ill-prepared to handle their pet's emotional problems. Her group offers training and counseling for pet owners, and has a full-time animal behaviorist on staff. ``People don't bring their dog in and say, `I can't deal with him. Put him to sleep.' They say, `I can't deal with him, find him a new home,' '' Cistaro said. ``Euthanasia isn't a guaranteed ending for an animal brought into a shelter, but it is something pet owners must be aware of. Sometimes it makes them realize that they really don't want to give their pet up,'' she said. Dodman said he became interested in animal behavior when he studied horses, and a habit called ``cribbing.'' Horses with this condition chew at their stalls and swallow air, giving them a kind of high. The high is caused by a chemical in the animal's brain that is released when air is swallowed. Dodman discovered that drugs could block the release of the chemical, essentially curing the horse. Since then, Dodman has become intrigued with the use of drug treatment for animals. He said the pharmacological control of behavior is well developed in human research, but for animals the idea is still in its infancy. Dodman is trying to change that by treating animals with traditionally for-humans-only drugs, like Valium and tranquilizers. Dr. Katherine A. Houpt, professor of physiology at the New York State College of Veterinary Medicine at Cornell University, said it's accepted practice for veterinarians to prescribe psychoactive drugs to animals. It's not usually for treatment of behavioral problems, though. ``After all, you must remember that these drugs were tested on animals before we ever used them on humans.'' Dodman, however, said it was important to look for the cause of the problem first, rather than the solution. ``I've always believed that the root of the problem should be addressed first. Drugs should not necessarily be used to treat everything,'' he said. ``Prevention is better than a cure. That's step number one.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Increase Oil Output, Say War Wouldn't Damage Fields Badly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By MARTIN MARRIS
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia expects to be producing 8.5 million barrels of oil a day soon and is considering expanding its oil industry to put out 10 million barrels a day despite the threat of war with Iraq. Saddam Hussein has threatened to devastate the kingdom's main oilfields in the northeastern desert if the U.S.-dominated multinational force in Saudi Arabia launches an offensive to liberate occupied Kuwait. Saudi officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it was only the fear of war - not any actual shortage in the market - that drove the price of a barrel of oil up from $16 before the crisis to its current $34. But former Saudi Oil Minister Ahmed Zaki Yamani and other Saudi sources said the fundamentals of the market do not justify an oil price much above $20 a barrel - let alone the $40 a barrel touched recently. Yamani said that if Iraq pulls out of Kuwait peacefully and Iraqi and Kuwaiti production is rapidly restored, the price is likely to drop even more steeply, perhaps to well below $15 a barrel, because of doubts about OPEC's ability to cut production promptly. Saudi officials are confident that if Saddam attacked, he would only be able to inflict minimal damage with his missiles and attack jets. ``Our defenses at the oilfields are good and the industry by its very structure is very widely dispersed,'' said one Saudi source, speaking on condition of anonymity. He noted that throughout the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, the Iranians never stopped using their Kharg Island offshore oil terminal despite its proximity to Iraq and almost daily air raids. The Saudis have already raised their oil output to 8.2 million barrels a day, a 10-year high and a 57 percent increase since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. This, along with increases by other producers in the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, has made up for the shortfall of 4 million barrels a day caused by the U.N.-imposed embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The Saudis are not even able to sell all of the oil they are producing now because customers are not buying up all of the inferior grades, petroleum experts say. But a New York analyst said Friday it makes sense for them to have the capacity to pump 10 million barrels a day so they could try to control future price spikes or supply problems with quick jumps in production. ``They don't want to see a situation where the supply would be disrupted,'' said Philip Dodge of Nomura Securities International Inc. ``They'd like to be able to drive the price back to $20 today, but they don't have the capacity to do it, and they don't want to find themselves in that situation again.'' The Saudis, who fear high oil prices will cut back demand, are trying to calm world oil markets by telling reporters about the possibility that they could speed up the expansion, another analyst said. ``What they say and what they achieve could be two different things,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Saudi Arabia has about 255 billion barrels of proven reserves, the largest in the world, equal to the combined reserves of the United States, Soviet Union, China, Mexico and Venezuela. Oil Minister Hisham Nazer said last week that output could reach 8.5 million barrels a day by the end of the year. An expansion plan drawn up before the crisis aimed for 10 million barrels a day by 1995. Although officials stress that no decision has been taken yet to implement the plan, the Saudis are considering accelerating it with 1992 as a possible target date. Saudi authorities have announced at least six oil and gas discoveries over the past year in a previously unexploited desert region between 45 miles and 125 miles south of Riyadh, the capital. The fields are well-placed strategically, with the nearest more than 310 miles from the Kuwaiti border, unlike the existing facilities in the Eastern Province. Nazer has refused to cite specific figures for the extent of the new reserves. He says the area is still under exploration. But a Western oil analyst said ``informed speculation'' was that the area could contain up to 30 billion barrels of oil. Sydney Bowers, a geological consultant for Saudi ARAMCO, said it was too early to provide figures, and analysts stressed it would take years and major investments on infrastructure to bring the fields on stream. Saudi officials express confidence that any war in the region would lead to only a brief surge in oil prices, followed by a sharp drop within a matter of days.

DOC.HEAD: Hirohito's Enthronement Like a `Dream' for Foreign Observer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. EDITOR'S NOTE - The author is the great-grandchild of Ambassador Charles MacVeigh. --- ^By S.L. BACHMAN
DOC.TEXT: When Emperor Hirohito ascended Japan's Chrysanthemum Throne 62 years ago, the mystical coronation rite had ``the magnificence of a dream'' enveloped in eerie silence. So wrote Fanny Davenport Rogers MacVeagh, wife of then U.S. Ambassador Charles MacVeagh and one of the few foreigners invited to Hirohito's enthronement. Hirohito died last year at age 87. His eldest son, Emperor Akihito, will be crowned Monday. In a 29-page letter to her five sons written one month after the ceremony, Mrs. MacVeagh gave a richly detailed account of the 1928 enthronement that is the model for the rites planned for Akihito. ``Count Makino, in the most archaic costume, slowly mounted the steps on the side of the throne away from us and handed the emperor a tightly rolled scroll. The emperor took it, unrolled it ... and read it in a firm but rather low voice,'' she wrote. Prime Minister Giichi Tanaka then ``clambered'' down to a level below the octagonal, purple-curtained throne to lead Japanese guests and foreign dignitaries inside the ancient Imperial Palace of Kyoto in three cheers of ``banzai,'' a wish for long life. ``Then, to my barbaric Western mind, then was the moment for the bells,'' she continued. ``But there were no bells. If the slow, mysterious sound of the temple gongs did float overfrom the city or from the monasteries on the surrounding mountains, I, at least, never heard it. The chief impression was that of the magnificence of a dream.'' The enthronement Monday will include representatives flown in from more than 150 countries, a far cry from Hirohito's coronation, when 100 foreign guests from 28 countries took a 10-hour ride by private train from Tokyo to Kyoto. The foreigners, all drawn from the diplomatic corps in Tokyo, arrived in marble-walled Kyoto station Nov. 2 and were led to a procession of bright red limousines. For Mrs. MacVeagh, the arrival was marred only by photographers' flash bulbs ``exploding continually about us.'' The procession moved silently through crowd-lined streets, past gateways covered with green cypress twigs and torii, the traditional gates to Shinto shrines. ``The few tramcars that were permitted to run were entirely covered with chrysanthemums and other flowers, like floats in a flower festival,'' she wrote. Lanterns lined the streets, each topped with a parasol to keep out the rain. ``The city was spotlessly clean, and because the enthronement is even more a religious than a political festival, and because the Japanese are a distinctly silent people, it was very quiet,'' she wrote. ``There was no one in Kyoto during all that enthronement time who was not known to the police,'' she wrote of the tight security, which also will be in place for Akihito's enthronement. At least 32,000 police are to be deployed Monday. The night before Hirohito's enthronement was spent resting and partying. Then, on a ``sunny morning with a little wind of icy quality,'' the foreign delegations rose early to attend the religious portion of the enthronement ceremony in which the emperor offers prayers to the sun goddess. This year, that segment will be strictly private to conform with the separation of religion and state mandated by Japan's postwar constitution. The formal declaration of ascension to the throne, however, will be broadcast on national television, the first time common Japanese will be able to view the solemn rite. Ambassador MacVeagh, a lawyer from New York and New Hampshire, was in the third of four years as head of the U.S. mission to Japan at the time of the coronation. After the coronation, the delegation returned to Tokyo in a steady rain. The emperor asked for protocol to be broken so people lining the streets could carry umbrellas. The umbrellas, said Mrs. MacVeagh, added ``a note of comfort and well-being to what had otherwise been a most dreary spectacle, while to these humble Japanese people, it was an unforgettable proof of the symapthy and love of their divine emperor.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Unrest Cooling German Excitement over Soviet Investment
With PM-Soviet-Outlook, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By KEVIN COSTELLOE
DOC.TEXT: Once excited by the prospect of huge investments in the Soviet Union, the Germans have grown increasingly cautious in the face of the growing unrest and economic woes plaguing the Communist nation. During a visit to Germany on Friday, Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed a historic non-aggression pact and made his now-familiar appeal for Western cash to make his country's reforms work. Chancellor Helmut Kohl promised to help the Soviet Union in ``word and deed'' and thanked the Soviet president for clearing the way for German unification. However, no further financial aid is expected this year beyond the $19.5 billion already promised by the government and German banks. Financing German unification has strapped the national budget, leaving little room for other major projects. Bankers also noted Soviet political and economic strife. ``Before there was a lot of euphoria,'' said Peter Pietsch, spokesman for Commerzbank, one of Germany's leading banks. ``Now the economic situation has worsened, and German businessmen are much more wary.'' On the economic side, Gorbachev's visit has so far produced only a German promise to look into increasing its imports of Soviet oil and natural gas. These already account for the largest chunk of Germany's purchases from the Soviets. By contrast, during a visit just 17 months ago, Gorbachev was wooed by enthusiastic German businessmen hungry for new markets. Since then, German news reports have emphasized the ethnic and political strife and moribund economy that threaten the Soviet Union with collapse. There have even been predictions that famine could strike parts of the country this winter. As a result, even the mighty Deutsche Bank, which once took the lead in arranging credits for the Soviet Union, has begun sounding the alarm. ``The economic and financial situation, especially the foreign economic situation, is alarming and possibly even critical,'' says Hilmar Kopper, head of the bank, Germany's largest. ``The Soviet Union's internal development is so unclear that it does not create a good climate for investments,'' said Karl-Hermann Fink, managing director of the German East-West Trade Committee. He said the Soviet's problems in developing an economic reform plan has even caused Soviet officials to cancel appointments with willing German investors. One stumbling block to greater investment has been Soviet delays in ratifying a treaty that would protect German investments. The treaty was signed by Kohl and Gorbachev during the Kremlin chief's visit to then West Germany in June 1989, but has yet to be ratified. ``They apparently haven't been able to get it on their schedule because of uncertainty about the economic changes,'' said Economics Ministry spokesman Joachim Romars. German businessmen cite other difficulties in dealing with the Soviet Union, including excessive bureaucracy and insufficient legal guidelines for doing business. Former West Germany imported $3.9 billion worth of Soviet goods in the first eight months of this year, up only slightly from the same period last year. By comparison, West German exports to the Soviets were $5.2 billion in the first eight months of the year. To put the figures in perspective, exports to the Soviets accounted for only 2 percent of former West Germany's total trade for the period. Heavy machinery and equipment were the main import choices of the Soviets, eager to revamp their industry. That was followed by high-tech electronics products. The $19.5 billion promised by the Germans to the Soviets this year comes in various forms of assistance. It includes nearly $9.5 billion in aid to help move 370,000 Soviet troops out of former East Germany by 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives of American Hostages Ponder the Worst: War with Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of Americans trapped by Saddam Hussein's desert stand have reluctantly come to consider the final and most frightening option: war with Iraq. ``He's over there in the middle of it and I'm afraid,'' said Tamara Rinehart of Stover, Mo., whose husband is holed up at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. ``Still, this seems to be what he wants.'' Jack Rinehart is among a number of hostages who, in letters smuggled out of Iraq and Kuwait in recent weeks, have urged their families to make a case for quick, decisive military action. Still, it was with mixed emotions that the hostages' relatives received word that 150,000 more U.S. troops were being sent to the Persian Gulf and that Moscow had consented to the possible use of force there. ``It's terrifying ... but my father is already at risk and the longer he stays, the more at risk he is,'' said Theresa Murphy, whose father is also among the holdouts at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. ``I'm relieved that it appears we're finally going to do something ... instead of letting those people rot over there,'' Ms. Murphy of Fremont, Calif., said Friday. The prospect of war is horrifying to relatives of the estimated 1,000 Americans who could be caught in the crossfire. But increasingly, they said, military action seems the only way to free their loved ones and the tiny country of Kuwait. ``When you read his letters, what becomes clear is that (the hostages) don't have a lot of time,'' said attorney David McDonald Jr., whose friend and client has been hiding in a safe house in Kuwait. ``I don't think military action would be anybody's first choice,'' said McDonald, who asked that his friend's identity be withheld. ``But things are very tight, food supplies are low ... the Iraqis are everywhere. The hostages don't have time to wait for protracted negotiations.'' The situation is trickier still for those Americans and other foreigners positioned by Iraqi forces as so-called ``human shields.'' Hostages held at military installations and industrial plants could be closer to death. ``If the shooting starts, they're in a very scary position,'' said Betty Seago, whose husband, Guy, has been allowed to call home several times recently from unspecified strategic locations in Iraq. She has heard the quiet panic in his voice, and felt utter frustration at her inability to help. ``He's in a different position than those in hiding ... because the Iraqis are right there with him,'' said Mrs. Seago of Johnson City, Tenn. ``The idea of war looks very different through his eyes.'' But Mrs. Seago and others said their hopes for a negotiated resolution have dwindled over the weeks as the political rhetoric and troop numbers have mounted. The hostages' families reluctantly have begun preparing for the worst. ``When I first left Kuwait I thought Saddam might take his toys and go home ... but now I don't see him leaving Kuwait peacefully,'' said Debbie Willis, who with her husband, Jerry, was taken captive by Iraqi troops during an escape attempt. She was among the women and children Saddam later agreed to release. ``I think we have to be prepared for war ... for something long, bloody and ugly,'' said Mrs. Willis, who served four years in the Army before becoming an attorney and moving to Kuwait with her husband, a native of Johnson City, Tenn. ``I think an all-out military exercise is what's going to happen,'' she said. ``But, my God, I hope not.''

DOC.HEAD: Copenhagen to Offer 5,000 Bikes for Free Use in the City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By JAN OLSEN
DOC.TEXT: Officials in the Danish capital believe they've found a way to stop bicycle thefts - let people use them for free. Starting in May, 5,000 bicycles carrying advertising from sponsors will be placed in 900 bike racks throughout Copenhagen. They'll be available for use by anyone who needs them, tourists, shoppers, businessmen late for an appointment or commuters who have missed the bus. ``You take a bike, drive around as long as you want it and put it back in a special-built rack. No charge,'' explained Ole Wessung, a 30-year-old chiropractor and an originator of the Bycykel (City Bike) project. ``I had enough of getting my bicycles stolen. Five of them have disappeared within three months,'' he said. According to police, 101,288 bicycles were reported stolen in 1989 in Denmark, a loss of $1.74 million. Wessung and publisher Morten Sadolin, 30, spent two years developing the project, and hope to make money by selling the advertising space on the bicycles. The Copenhagen city council - interested in reducing air pollution, traffic congestion and bike thefts - has given permission for placement of the bicycle racks on almost every other street corner. A similar plan was proposed for Amsterdam in the 1970s but never caught on the Dutch city. However, a similar free-bike plan is operating successfully at the Hoge Veluwe national park in the Netherlands. In the closed-off area, visitors can pick up a bike for free and drop it off anywhere else on the grounds. Eight companies have put up the first $1.7 million to get the Copenhagen project going. ``They sign a three-year contract and during that period bicycles with their brands and colors will be seen in the streets,'' said Wessung. The clumsy-looking bicycles have big, flat central tubes where sponsors' advertisements will be placed. But the ungraceful appearance also has another purpose. ``They are easily recognizable and were designed so no one would steal them,'' says Wessung. ``Everyone can see it's a Bycycle. If you are spotted 200 kilometers (125 miles) away from Copenhagen, you're either a good rider or a thief.'' Would-be thieves are discouraged from stealing the bike for refitting because standard saddles, wheels and other parts do not fit the Bycycle, which means ``city bike'' in Danish. Wessung says the bikes are easily maneuverable, but have no speeds. They can be obtained in the way travelers get luggage carts at international airports. Users insert a coin worth $3.50 in a slot on the bike, and are then able tounlock it from the stand. A coin of the same value is returned when the bike is relocked into another rack. Wessung and Sadolin plan to test their Bycycle next year in Paris and Rome, where authorities are trying to discourage use of cars in the city centers. ``We hope businessmen, tourists and everyone will borrow our bicycles to get around in Copenhagen. People are screaming about pollution and the Copenhagen municipality wants a car-free city,'' Wessung said. ``So here's the alternative.''

DOC.HEAD: Newsletter Sports Red For Recession
DOC.TEXT: The masthead on a newsletter that follows economic indicators is red for the first time in eight years, flashing a warning that the nation's economy may be headed for a recession. Eighty percent of the 55 prominent economists the Blue Chip Economic Indicators newsletter surveys each month now say a recession will begin before yer's end. Another five percent say the contraction will begin in 1991. But a big majority say that the downturn won't last long and that it will be mild. ``It now seems very likely that America's longest peacetime expansion is about to come to an end,'' editor Robert J. Eggert of Eggert Economic Enterprises Inc., in Sedona, Ariz., wrote in Friday's edition. A recession generally is defined as two consecutive quarterly declines in the gross national product - the nation's total output of goods and services and its broadest measure of economic activity. Throughout the eight-year expansion, the newsletter masthead has been printed in either green or yellow. Green meant the economy was expanding above its long-range growth potential of 3 percent, while yellow warned that growth was lagging between zero and 2.9 percent. The survey found that three-fourths of the respondents expect any downturn to last no more than two or three quarters. ``An even larger majority - 82 percent - anticipate that the recession will be relatively mild,'' the newsletter said. The survey's consensus forecast anticipated a 0.8 percent annual rate of decline during the current quarter, followed by a 0.6 percent drop from January through March 1991. It projected growth picking up 0.8 percent, 2.1 percent and 2.5 percent in the following quarters. ``The outlook for inflation also continued on the gloomy side with the consensus estimate for the annualized rate of increase in the Consumer Price Index for the current quarter jumping to 7.1 percent,'' the newsletter reported. This would push the inflation rate for the year to 5.5 percent. However, the inflation rate would slow to a 5.2 percent increase during 1991. The Blue Chip consensus projects overall GNP growth of 1.0 percent this year. The economy grew 1.7 percent at an annual rate in the first quarter followed by 0.4 percent and 1.8 percent rates in the next two. But expectations for growth in 1991 continued to slide, ``dropping three-tenths of a percentage point to a paltry 0.5 percent.'' Since the last recession, the economy is believed to have grown for 95 months through September, surpassing the previous peacetime growth record of 58 months between 1975 and 1980. The current overall record was 106 months from 1961 to 1969 which included the Vietnam war. The survey participants represent many of the nation's top banks, brokerage firms, corporations, economic forecasting organizations and universities. Other economists, however, still believe the economy can skirt a recession. For instance, economist Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley & Co. told a reporter that while the economy could fall during the current quarter, ``we are not projecting two consecutive quarters of declining GNP.'' Lawrence Kudlow, a top Reagan administration economist now with Bear Stearns & Co., told the U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Thursday he foresees ``no off-the-cliff recession,'' although he would not be surprised to see a negative fourth quarter. Even President Bush acknowledged at his Thursday news conference that ``we're in for some tough times right now,'' but avoided using the word recession. And Michael Boskin, Bush's chief economic adviser, said Thursday the economy could slip into ``negative territory'' this year. ``The economy at best is in a lull but we do expect that lull to be relatively brief and relatively minor,'' Boskin told the American Council for Capital Formation here.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Memorial Ground Breaking Slated For '91
DOC.TEXT: A veterans' panel says it is hoping for a November 1991 ground breaking for a Korean War veterans memorial whose design has raised objections from its original architects. But first, an additional $6 million must be raised through the sale of commemorative silver dollars, said the Korean War Veterans Memorial Advisory Board, created by Congress to oversee the project. The final memorial cost is estimated at $14.9 million. Board spokesman Bill Russell said Friday that organizers hoped construction could begin in a year despite complaints by the original architects that their design has been altered. The National Capital Memorial Commission approved the design, including the revisions, during a hearing Thursday, Russell said. The commission is part of the Interior Department. Four Pennsylvania State University architects beat out 1,018 competitors last year in a $20,000 contest to design the memorial across the Reflecting Pool from the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. The entry was declared the winner by a jury of Korean War veterans. The design called for ``a dream-like'' collection of 38 soldiers moving, some unevenly, across a remote landscape toward an American flag. The architects said the soldiers were to show ``the experience of moving into and through war.'' But last month, they went public with complaints that the design had been turned into a ``GI Joe battle scene'' by placing soldiers in battle-ready positions. The design ``in its current status is not the design that won the national competition,'' said a statement the architects delivered to the White House on Sept. 25. The changes were executed by Cooper-Lecky Architects of Washington based on suggestions from the National Capital Planning Commission and the U.S. Fine Arts Commission, the advisory board said. Those two commissions must still approve the final design. The advisory board says the original architects ``relinquished all rights to their submission in consideration of substantial prize money,'' the board chairman, retired Army Gen. Richard Stilwell, said in a recent statement. Stilwell said the architects were retained as consultants to the final design. He denied that the new design called for a ``battle scene'' but said the statutes would indeed appear ``combat-ready.'' ``Historically, memorial design development is an evolutionary process, the direction of which the Pennsylvania consultants have been opposing,'' said a statement released by the board after Thursday's hearing. But Robert Sokolove, the architects' attorney, said his clients were shut out of the process after they won the money. ``You can't change the rules in the middle,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Displaced Mozambicans Accused of Cruelty to Cattle
DOC.TEXT: Refugees from neighboring Mozambique have been told to stop chopping the tails off cattle from local ranches to make ox-tail soup. John Nkomo, labor and social welfare minister, was visiting Tongogara refuee camp Friday in Chipinge, southeast Zimbabwe, when administrators revealed the plight of the animals. ``Being displaced does not mean you should forget your tradition and self-respect and go around chopping off tails from cattle,'' Nkomo said in a speech to the 42,000 refugees. Representatives of the refugees, who fled to Tongogara to escape Mozambique's 13-year civil war, said the inmates were properly nourished at the camp. Ox-tail stew is simply a favorite of the refugees, they said.

DOC.HEAD: New Greek Law Aims To End Inconclusive Elections
DOC.TEXT: Parliament has approved a new law that seeks to end inconclusive elections and makes it harder for very small parties and independents to win. The conservative New Democracy party, which holds 151 seats in the 300-member Parliament, proposed the law after winning elections in April. Inconclusive polls in June and November led to short-lived coalition governments. The new system, adopted Friday, allows a single party to win a majority in Parliament with about 43 percent of the vote, down from 47 percent, while making it harder for a coalition of parties to win elections. The new law also stipulates that small parties secure at least 3 percent of the vote to be represented in Parliament. This change will effectively bar several small parties and independents who were elected in the past. The socialist and Communist opposition voted against the new law.

DOC.HEAD: McCain First To Appear In Ethics Inquiry
With PM-Keating Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Arizona Republican John McCain will be the first of the ``Keating Five'' senators to state his case when the Senate Ethics Committee begins public hearings next week, according to the committee staff. Until now, the panel has heard testimony and deliberated in secret. But beginning Thursday, it will publicly listen to facts and explanations from the five senators who went to bat for Charles Keating Jr.'s savings and loan. On Friday, the committee held a private drawing to determine the order in which the five senators would appear, said staff director Wilson Abney. McCain drew the leadoff spot, he said. He will be followed by four Democrats: Sens. John Glenn of Ohio, Donald Riegle of Michigan, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Alan Cranston of California. Abney said the committee abandoned its earlier plan to consider the cases in alphabetical order because ``there was some concern that doing it alphabetically was too arbitrary.'' He wouldn't describe the drawing and said only that the order of appearance was determined ``by lot drawn by counsel to the senators.'' McCain's office said he was in Arizona and not immediately available for comment. The fact-finding hearings were ordered after the panel met privately with each senator and then considered a report in which its special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, outlined the evidence and recommended that the committee drop its investigation of McCain and Glenn. The committee is considering whether the five senators violated the Senate ethics code by taking large contributions from Keating and later assisting his collapsing thrift. Keating's thrift, the California-based Lincoln Savings and Loan, was seized by the government last year at a potential cost to taxpayers of more than $2 billion. Before the government acted, the five senators met with federal regulators who were examining Lincoln. All five have said there was no connection between the meetings with regulators and the donations from Keating and his associates. Keating has been charged in California with criminal fraud. The charges relate to the sale of $250 million in high-risk bonds to Lincoln depositors. The bonds became worthless when Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, went bankrupt.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Must Cut Poland's Debt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is under intense pressure to reduce the $3.2 billion Polish debt to the United States as a result of a bill he signed into law this week. The law tells him to delay making the U.S. contribution to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development until Poland's debt and the payments the financially strapped country is expected to make are cut. The United States and 41 other members will own the bank, which is being organized in London to help the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries move to a market economy. The U.S. share of the bank's $12 billion capital will be $1.2 billion, the largest investment of any single country. It will require five annual payments into the bank of $70 million, with an additional $850 million available to the bank if needed. Congress insists in the new law on foreign aid that Bush must first make an arrangement with Poland and its other debtors to reduce the country's debt to something that reflects its actual value. Poland's debt to commercial banks was selling on the market Nov. 1 at about 13 cents on the dollar. At that rate the $3.2 billion debt to the United States would be worth only $415 million. Poland owes its biggest creditor, Germany, $4.8 billion. Germany has already cancelled $513 million of the money Poland owes and has said Poland can pay another $370 million in its own currency. ``We didn't want this country paying into the bank so that the Poles could borrow money to pay Germany,'' said Rep. David R. Obey, who has major responsibility in Congress for international finance. ``Everybody knows the Poles are bankrupt and can't pay. If you look at the administration's budget documents, you'll see they aren't expecting anything from Poland for five years. The question is whether they'll admit that, or keep on playing this phony game of rescheduling - delaying payments.'' Obey, D-Wis., chairs the foreign operations subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee. Poland's debt to Western countries was $40.8 billion at the end of last year, $28 billion of it to individual governments, according to Krzysztof Krowacki, financial counselor of the Polish Embassy. Poland owes France $3.9 billion and Brazil $3.2 billion, Krowacki said. Most of Poland's debt to the United States came from loans to help the country buy surplus U.S. farm products. A smaller part was lent by the U.S. government's Export-Import Bank so that Poland could buy industrial products. Debts owed by governments to other governments are regularly considered at closed-door meetings of creditors known as the Paris Club. A Polish newspaper report on a meeting last month said that U.S. representatives let it be known that they would favor debt reductions for Poland, and that British and Italian representatives had responded favorably. Richard Boucher, State Department spokesman, told a news briefing earlier this week that the United States is not standing in the way of an agreement on Polish debt. ``We have long supported and do still support multilateral efforts such as those in the Paris Club to deal with the problems that Poland faces as a result of its debt,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Beggar Dies, Leaves Fortune
DOC.TEXT: When Dario Cortesi died two months ago, it took public charity authorities three days to locate his sister Lucia for her to take care of a modest burial for the 69-year-old beggar. But when Cortesi's sister went through his tumbledown shack in Capitan Pastene, a small town 415 miles south of Santiago, she found documents showing he had more than $300,000 in savings. He also owned several houses. Cortesi, the son of an Italian immigrant, also had been receiving the equivalent of $2,000 monthly from the state pension systems in Chile and Italy. Cortesi's will leaves most of the money to a local convent. But by law his family is entitled to part of it.

DOC.HEAD: Episcopal Church Plans to Go Ahead With Phoenix Convention
DOC.TEXT: A minister pushing for a state holiday honoring the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. isn't bothered by the Episcopalian Church's decision to hold a convention in Arizona despite voters' rejection of a King Day. ``With the seriousness of our efforts to still obtain the holiday, I'm sure the group will address the issue and encourage the principles that Martin Luther King stood for,'' Henry Barnwell said Friday. ``We know we have their support, we had it prior to the election. There will probably be enough (conventions) canceling as it is,'' Barnwell said, adding that his group has put on hold its boycott strategy until they have exhausted all other means of getting the holiday adopted. Barnwell, pastor of the First New Life Missionary Baptist Church, is chairman of a group called Arizonans for a Martin Luther King Holiday that he said led the movement for the holiday in 1987 when impeached Gov. Evan Mecham rescinded former Gov. Bruce Babbitt's executive order creating a holiday. The Episcopal Church announced this week that it would go ahead with its plans to hold its triennial General Convention in Phoenix even though Arizona voters on Tuesday rejected two ballot measures that would have established a King holiday. Also after the election, National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said he will recommend that the 1993 Super Bowl be moved in protest from Phoenix, but Episcopal Presiding Bishop Edmond Browning said more good can be done by staying. ``The Episcopal Church will go to Phoenix. While we cannot ignore or condone the results of the referendum, I believe that by working with people of good faith who are in Arizona, we can come and together make a vigorous witness for the dignity of all God's people, and against the evils of racism,'' Browning said. In his statement, Browning said he was ``terribly disappointed'' by the decision to reject the King holiday. Browning, spiritual leader of the nearly 2.5 million-member denomination, noted that he had lobbied the Arizona Legislature for a King holiday, but had said at the time ``I was not issuing threats about not coming to Arizona.'' ``I came to say that I believed that they were confronting a moral issue of deep significance, and that is racism,'' Browning said. ``Dr. King brought to us a message of what this country could be if we were able to find racial equality. Observing a holiday in his name goes deeper than honoring him. It reminds us of who we must be as a non-racist society.'' Arizona Episcopal Bishop Joseph T. Heistand said he will continue to struggle for the passage of a Martin Luther King Civil Rights Day. ``I don't believe the majority of citizens of Arizona are racist; I believe they stand for justice and civil rights for all people,'' he said. The head of a lobbying group for South African sanctions that received its start with a grant from a black Episcopal Church leader said the church's decision was ``unfortunate.'' ``The Episcopal Church should be in the front lines here and it is terribly regrettable to find the church lagging behind the NFL,'' said Randall Robinson, head of TransAfrica in Washington, D.C. His organization received its first grant in 1977 from the Rev. Canon Robert C.S. Powell, a black Episcopalian who directed the National Mission in Church and Society. Norman Braman, owner of the Philadelphia Eagles and chairman of the Super Bowl site selection committee, said he expected that the NFL commissioner's recommendation to move the game would be approved. ``I think it would be an affront to our public and our players if the game is played in Phoenix,'' Braman said. Up to 9,000 people are expected to attend the Episcopalian convention July 11-20 in Phoenix, church News Director James Solheim said. Earlier this week, David Radcliffe, president of Phoenix & Valley of the Sun Convention and Visitors Bureau, said he knew of at least four groups that have canceled reservations for conventions or stays at hotels since the propositions failed Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0779 to fix cycle designator
Congressman Shocked By Bush Veto Of `Orphan Drug' Bill
DOC.TEXT: A congressman who sponsored a bill aimed at lowering the cost of some drugs says he was shocked at President Bush's pocket veto of the measure without any previous warnings that he opposed it. The bill, supported by AIDS activists and other advocacy groups, was aimed at lowering prices of ``orphan drugs'' that have limited sales potential when they are first developed. ``Some drug companies have gotten to the ear of the White House,'' said Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif. Waxman said companies don't want to lose the millions of dollars they earn by being the monopoly supplier of drugs used to treat diseases that once were limited to a small population but have spread to thousands of people. He said drugs to treat AIDS, for example, should no longer be considered orphan drugs. Waxman said he was ``really shocked'' that Bush did not sign the bill because the White House had ``never made a fuss'' previously about the legislation. The Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Association opposed the legislation, but said it was not recommending that Bush veto it. The bill applies to drugs used against diseases that affect fewer than 200,000 people. It was designed to foster more competition by eliminating the seven-year exclusive marketing rights granted under current law to companies that develop such drugs. Bush withheld his signature from the bill, killing it through what is known as a pocket veto. ``I have serious concerns about the effect that (the bill) would have upon the incentive of drug companies to develop orphan drugs,'' Bush said in a statement. The White House contends that taking away the exclusivity benefit actually would decrease the willingness of firms to come up with orphan drugs because of the expense involved in the research and development. The new legislation would have cut off a drug's orphan drug status as soon as the number of people who need the drug exceeded 200,000. The Food and Drug Administration has granted so-called orphan status to more than 375 drugs, more than 40 of which have reached the market. Some of the diseases that orphan drugs have been developed to treat include Huntington's disease, Tourette's syndrome, narcolepsy and muscular dystrophy. On a separate matter, Bush on Friday signed a bill requiring food manufacturers to put more nutrition information on the labels of food packaging. The legislation mandates that most bulk food in bins, raw fish and fruits and vegetables be displayed with a sign or brochure providing nutritional information.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Says Czechoslovakia Quickening Reform Pace
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia may soon overtake Hungary as ``the country of choice'' for U.S. investments in the former communist bloc, says a U.S. trade official. The pace of Czechoslovakia's transition from government to market control of the economy is now quickening, said Franklin J. Vargo, deputy assistant commerce secretary for Europe. The central European country provides a $4 billion annual market for Western goods and ``this should double, triple or quadruple in the next 10-15 years,'' Vargo said Friday. For investment, ``Czechoslovakia in the near future could become the country of choice,'' he said. Vargo was the main speaker at the 10th session of the Czechoslovak-U.S. Economic Council, attended by more than 200 business people and government officials from the two countries. The meeting at U.S. Chamber of Commerce headquarters was the council's first since the collapse of communist rule in last year's peaceful revolution. It followed by one day an announcement by General Motors Corp. of an agreement for the Bratislava Automobile Works in Slovakia to build 250,000 automobile transmissions and to assemble GM's Opel cars for local distribution. Czechoslovakia took only $70 million, or less than 2 percent, of its Western imports from the United States last year compared to 40 percent from Germany, Vargo said. But he urged U.S. businessmen to regard the country ``not as a $70 million market but as a future billion-dollar market.'' U.S. businesses tend to pass up all but the biggest markets, Vargo said, in contrast to the Germans, British and Japanese. Vargo said he hopes final approval of long-awaited Most Favored Nation treatment between the United States and Czechoslovakia, providing reciprocal tariff concessions, comes during President Bush's planned Nov. 17 visit to Prague. The concessions are in the new U.S.-Czechoslovak trade treaty, whose ratification was delayed in Congress until last month and still awaits Czechoslovak ratification. Czechoslovak economic reform has lagged in such matters as lifting price control, he said, with 90 percent of prices still fixed by government, compared to 30 percent in Hungary and 10 percent in Poland. Czechoslovakia has set Jan. 1 for launching major economic reforms, including internal convertibility of its currency and stepped-up privatization of industry.

DOC.HEAD: Buildup To 430,000 U.S. Troops In Gulf To End Troop Rotation Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Changes headline to conform to lead; INSERTS new 2nd graf to include time troop buildup likely to take
DOC.TEXT: The new troop buildup ordered by President Bush will push America's fighting force in the Persian Gulf to 430,000 and stop planned troop rotations that could have brought some soldiers home, officials say. Pentagon officials, speaking privately, said the troop buildup would likely not be completed until early next year. The additional 200,000 men and women that Bush ordered to the gulf Thursday will give the United States a clear offensive potential against Iraq which now holds an advantage in numbers of troops in the gulf area. The move also will mean a huge drain on U.S. military manpower elsewhere and thus will kill plans for relieving some weary soldiers in the gulf with fresh troops. Asked by a reporter whether the U.S. forces now in the gulf and those soon to be en route will be there for the duration of the crisis, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said, ``That's correct.'' Pentagon officials had been preparing a rotation plan that they said would improve troop morale, which has suffered in some cases from troops' uncertainty about how long they will be required to endure the gulf's harsh living conditions. By adding about 200,000 forces to the 230,000 already in and around Saudi Arabia, Bush is roughly matching the size of the Iraqi force in Kuwait and southern Iraq. The United States will have fewer tanks in the area than Iraq but more of the most modern models. Bush was out of the public eye Friday at Camp David, Md., but his defense secretary underscored the president's comments of a day earlier by emphasizing the U.S. forces' ability to attack and by making clear their deployment could be long term. Like Bush, Cheney stressed that the new buildup was meant as a signal to Saddam Hussein that the United States was ``preparing the forces necessary to undertake offensive operations, should that become necessary'' to get Iraq out of Kuwait. Cheney's remarks highlighted a fundamental shift in stated U.S. military goals in the gulf, from defending Saudi oil fields to, in effect, giving Saddam an ultimatum: either withdraw from Kuwait within weeks or face a massive U.S. attack. Also Friday, the Navy said it was sending the aircraft carriers USS Theodore Roosevelt, USS America and USS Ranger - plus their battle group components - to the gulf area. That would increase to six the number of U.S. carriers there. The United States has 14 carriers, of which 12 are capable of deploying. Naval authorities in San Diego announced that a Southern California amphibious group would join the extended deployment to Operation Desert Shield. The 13-ship Amphibious Group Three, based in San Diego and Long Beach, consists of the USS Tarawa, USS Tripoli, USS New Orleans, USS Mobile, USS Vancouver, USS Denver, USS Juneau, USS Anchorage, USS Mt. Vernon, USS Germantown, USS Barbour County, USS Peoria and USS Frederick. The 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade from Camp Pendleton will leave along with the Navy task force, officials said, without disclosing when the task force would depart.

DOC.HEAD: Paintings By Turner, Marieschi Stolen From London Apartment
DOC.TEXT: Thieves who stormed a west London apartment have stolen paintings by J.M.W. Turner and Michele Marieschi that are together valued at nearly $2.4 million, police reported. The three thieves gained access to the building Thursday by claiming they were delivering a package, then overpowered the 66-year-old owner and tied him up in the apartment hallway, Scotland Yard said Friday. The thieves then cut the paintings from their frames and took them away, the police said in a statement. Scotland Yard identified the paintings as Turner's ``The Grand Junction Canal at Southall Mill,'' valued $1.9 million; and Marieschi's ``Venice with the Palazzo Pesaro'' valued at $490,000. Turner was a 19th century British landscape artist. Marieschi was an 18th century Italian artist.

DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Walkout Cripples Auto, Steel Industry; Anti-Toxic Protest At Dump
DOC.TEXT: More than a million metalworkers struck Italy's auto and steel industry, and hundreds of thousands of the strikers marched in the capital in a traffic-snarling demonstration. The one-day walkout Friday came as tons of garbage piled up in the capital. The city dump was blocked off by a two-day siege that ended Friday by thousands of demonstrators who protested plans to build a toxic waste incinerator at the site. The metalworkers' strike was called to press for a new labor contract. Italy's three major trade unions organized the rally in the heart of Rome, and it turned out to be one of the largest workers' marches in years. The demonstrators, 200,000 strong, blew horns and whistles as they marched past the Colosseum. Some waved the red flags of the Italian Communist party. Many farmers and factory workers reportedly stopped work for two hours to express their solidarity with the metalworkers, whose contract expired 10 months ago. Negotiations between the powerful metalwork unions and the confederation of industrialists are deadlocked over union demands to reduce the work week from 40 to 37 hours. Local newspapers are calling Rome ``the seven hills of garbage'' because of the protest by thousands of residents from the so-called ``valley of poison,'' the area surrounding Rome's garbage dump. On Wednesday the residents began obstructing the dumping of waste to protest the building of a proposed chemical and toxic waste incinerator at the dump. Government officials promised not to build the incinerator during meetings Friday afternoon with a residents' group which calls itself the ``United Front Against Smokestacks.'' In addition, hospital waste incinerators already on the site will be rebuilt to make emissions safer. Residents halted their vigil but said protests would resume if the government fails to keep its promises.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Complaint Seeks $250 Million From CenTrust Officials
DOC.TEXT: David Paul, the former CenTrust Bank chairman accused of using thrift money to bankroll an extravagant lifestyle, is one of 16 former S&L officials facing a federal complaint that seeks $250 million. The complaint filed Friday by attorneys for the Resolution Trust Corp. stems from the $1.8 billion collapse of CenTrust, once the largest thrift in the Southeast. The RTC is a government agency that oversees failed thrifts. Paul, who has not been criminally charged, also faces an administrative order by the federal Office of Thrift Supervision seeking $30.8 million for what they say was his ``insatiable greed and vanity.'' Friday's complaint charges the defendants with breaches of fiduciary duty, waste and mismanagement. ``If we were to recover $250 million, that is a small portion of what the taxpayers are due,'' Steve Katsanos, an RTC spokesman, said late Friday. Paul has been held up as a symbol of the excesses in the nation's savings & loan crisis. He ranks second only to former Lincoln Savings and Loan owner Charles H. Keating Jr. in terms of the money sought by the OTS for lavish expenditures made by S&L executives at the expense of customers. In Friday's court action, Katsanos cited such CenTrust expenses as the acquisition of a corporate jet and sailboat, $30 million in artwork and opulent headquarters outfitted with gold-plated bathroom plumbing and a marble staircase. The CenTrust Tower, a familiar part of the Miami skyline, is now on the auction block. Federal regulators seized control of Miami-based CenTrust in February, and it was sold in June to Great Western Bank of California.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Aide's Lingering Presence Prompts Bitterness in Home State
LaserPhoto CR1
DOC.TEXT: John Sununu, President Bush's top adviser, is gone but not forgotten in his home state, where bitterness over his lingering political influence is building after this week's election. Gov. Judd Gregg blamed Sununu this week for the stunning upset of a fellow Republican seeking re-election to Congress, while other GOP leaders said it is time for the former governor to butt out of New Hampshire politics. The White House said Sununu, Bush's chief of staff, would have no comment on the controversy. The feud went public when Gregg said Sununu and his wife, Nancy, were at least partly to blame for Democrat Dick Swett's congressional victory over freshman Rep. Chuck Douglas in Tuesday's election. Earlier this year, Mrs. Sununu criticized Douglas' lifestyle - including three divorces - and threatened to run against him in the Republican primary. Swett quoted her in campaign literature, and the Sununus said nothing to counter the remarks. Douglas' defeat cost the Republican party a seat it had held in Congress for 75 years. Gregg's spokesman, Brian Grip, said the governor's criticism of his predecessor only was related to the Douglas-Swett election, but other Republicans said it was symptom of a larger rift between the two. ``For a long time, everybody kept looking to Sununu,'' said former state Republican Chairman John Stabile. But Gregg's overwhelming re-election ``shows he is a formidable force, and I think he wants people to fully recognize that now,'' Stabile said. State Sen. Charles Bass also said a potential showdown is brewing between Gregg and Sununu over who the next chairman of the New Hampshire Republican party will be. He said Gregg is backing state Sen. Rhona Charbonneau, while Sununu's choice is GOP activist Max Hugel. ``I'm fighting the White House for this position,'' Charbonneau said Friday. She added she has been at odds with Sununu since she told him earlier this year that it was time he quit meddling in New Hampshire politics. ``When I told them to stay out of our politics, I don't think they liked it,'' Charbonneau said. ``I think that Gov. Sununu has got to let go of the state.'' She said she was punished by being kept off the stage during a campaign visit by Bush last month. Hugel, who led a national Republican voter drive in 1980 and was a Reagan administration CIA official, said he is surprised at being linked to Sununu. ``I am an ally and friend and backer of Judd Gregg, too, and Judd Gregg knows that,'' he said. ``I have supported Republicans up and down the line.'' Gregg's father, Hugh, a former governor, played down the idea of a turf battle between his son and Sununu, but acknowledged that there is a history of political bad blood. The elder Gregg said Sununu wrongly claimed credit for Bush's key victory in the 1988 New Hampshire primary. ``For 10 years we (the Greggs) had been working for George Bush and set up an organization and campaign and everything else,'' he said. ``Sununu never gave any credit to anyone but himself, but it wasn't a single-handed effort by any means.''

DOC.HEAD: New Indian Prime Minister Sworn In, Seeks `Healing Touch' for Unrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with swearing-in ceremony. Pickup 10th graf ``Chandra Shekhar walked...'; Chandra Shekhar uses both names on second reference.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DEL2
DOC.TEXT: Chandra Shekhar was sworn in Saturday as the country's new prime minister, facing what he called a ``grim and challenging'' task to quell widespread unrest that helped topple his predecessor. The 63-year-old socialist leader took the oath from President Ramaswamy Venkataraman outside the presidential palace. Chandra Shekhar, who led efforts to unseat V.P. Singh as prime minister, pledged Friday that his government will seek ``to create a society of equals'' in a nation where thousands have died this year in battles over religious, ethnic and class differences. The clashes were used to rally opposition against Singh, the first Indian prime minister to be ousted by Parliament. He lost a confidence vote Wednesday. ``In all humility, I would like to say that the task before us is arduous,'' Chandra Shekhar said Friday. ``It is so grim and challenging. But one has to make every endeavor to retrieve the situation.'' At least 370 people have died in the last three weeks in Hindu-Moslem riots over a 460-year-old mosque that some Hindus claim was build on the site of the warrior god Rama. Hindus seeks to raze the mosque in Ayodhya in northeast India and build a temple. Meanwhile, at least 150 upper-caste students have committed suicide or died in clashes with police to protest Singh's attempt to reserve more government jobs for low-caste Hindus. Violent separatist campaigns in Kashmir and Punjab in the north and Assam in the east have cost thousands of lives, with 1990 emerging as the bloodiest year. Chandra Shekhar said he will seek Parliament's endorsement of his government by Nov. 20. So far, he has not disclosed his Cabinet plans. Devi Lal, a bitter rival of Singh, was sworn in Saturday as deputy prime minister, a post he held until Singh fired him over the summer. Chandra Shekhar walked away with 56 dissident members from Singh's Janata Dal Party and voted against him. Devi Lal sided with Chandra Shekhar and his breakaway Janata Dal (Socialist) Party. Chandra Shekhar has never held a Cabinet job in his more than three decades in politics. He has served in senior posts in a series of parties and was elected to Parliament four times. He was offered the prime minister's job after three other parties on Thursday declined Venkataraman's invitation to form a government. The new government has a slim hold in the 522-seat decision-making lower house of Parliament. Chandra Shekhar claims the support of 280 members, including 195 votes from former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party. Gandhi has said his party, the largest in Parliament, will not participate in Chandra Shekhar's government but will back it in parliamentary procedures. About 15 other small-party allies of the Congress Party also have pledged to back Chandra Shekhar, who does not use a surname. Singh's 11-month-old coalition government lost its majority in Parliament last month after the withdrawal of the Hindu fundamentalist Bharatiya Janata Party over the mosque dispute. The party was angered by Singh's opposition to plans to build the temple on the mosque site. Chandra Shekhar said his first step would be to ``apply the healing touch and cool down tempers.'' ``We have to eliminate mutual discord and hatred with the firm faith that problems can be solved by cooperation,'' he said. He declined to spell out details of his economic policy, saying ``our priority would be to meet the basic needs of our people.'' On foreign policy, he said India will not create ``a sense of doubt'' among smaller nations and will not bow to bigger powers.

DOC.HEAD: If Kids Play Hooky, Parents Face Jail
DOC.TEXT: Threatening to jail parents of chronic truants is one way to ensure students get a better education, some officials say. But Anetha and Willie Dorsey - the first parents convicted under a city pilot program - insist they're being punished for a situation beyond their control. ``I don't think it's fair,'' said Mrs. Dorsey, 44, a homemaker and mother of 12. ``We're doing the best we can.
