We buy him clothes, give him lunch money and we get him up. He just didn't go.'' On Wednesday, the Dorseys, parents of a 15-year-old Amundsen High School student, were hauled into court and charged with letting the boy miss too much school - a misdemeanor. Cook County Circuit Judge Thaddeus Kowalski scolded the boy and sentenced the couple to a year of court supervision. The judge also ordered the couple to go to school to pick up their son's report cards and to attend three meetings of the local school council. That panel was instrumental in forming the school's new truancy program. If the boy, who missed 80 days last year and has already missed 17{ days this year, is absent again without an excuse, state law would allow for his parents to be jailed for up to 30 days and fined up to $500. ``There's a direct correlation between how well (students) do and attendance,'' said Pauline Tarvardian, who oversees attendance matters at Amundsen. ``If they are doing well - and we expect our students to do well - we expect them to be here every day,'' she said Friday. The couple's conviction followed repeated warnings. It was the first since a joint program between the school and the Cook County state's attorney's office to end truancy was announced in May. ``Truancy was becoming a growing problem in Cook County,'' said Dan McCullough, a state attorney's spokesman. Educators and prosecutors first try numerous ways to persuade parents to get their children to school, he said. Court action against the parents is a last resort. ``Our intent was never to put parents in jail,'' said Harriet O'Donnell, a school council member at Amundsen who was instrumental in developing the program. ``Our intent was to get kids back in school where they belong.'' In Illinois, 180 days of school are required and under the pilot program a student must miss 18 days to be declared a chronic truant. The action was taken as a result of last year's attendance records, O'Donnell said. Absentees at Amundsen are down significantly from a year ago when an average of 76 percent of students attended school on any given day, Tarvardian said. ``Yesterday, we had 90 percent (attendance),'' she said. Amundsen's program is one of a series of moves taken by authorities nationwide to cut absenteeism. In Milwaukee this week, a judge reinstated an experimental program docking the welfare benefits of families whose teen-agers skip school. Last year, a Baltimore woman was sentenced to 10 days in jail for letting her daughter miss 101 days of school.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Bill Requiring New Disclosures of Universities
DOC.TEXT: Colleges and universities will be required to make public their graduation rates, camps security procedures and campus crime rates under legislation signed into law by President Bush. The legislation, which Bush signed Friday, applies to those schools participating in federal student aid programs. The new law requires that the institutions certify to the Education Department that they have campus security policies and will have to distribute to students, prospective students and employees an annual report of crime statistics. The bill also requires that the colleges provide students and prospective students with graduation rates. The institutions must report to the education secretary, as of July 1993, on the numbers and graduation rates of students who receive athletic-related student aid. That information must be broken down by race, sex and sport. The schools also must provide this information to potential student athletes, their parents, guidance counselors and coaches.
DOC.HEAD: Fence Removed from Steam Grate
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is abandoning a plan to stop homeless people from sleeping on a steam grate just yards from the street entrance to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's office. Workers recently dismantled a partially constructed fence around the steam grate. The fence drew protests in September from homeless people and their advocates. The day of the protest, someone drove off with the iron gate, which had not been installed by workmen. Until this week, the fence had stood without the gate, allowing homeless people to continue to sleep atop the grate, which covers a vent to a steam tunnel that runs between the Justice Department and several adjacent government buildings. Workmen planted holly bushes around the grate before removing the uncompleted fence. Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian said the fence was to be installed as a security measure. ``The attorney general never thought it was a good idea,'' Eramian said, adding that Thornburgh didn't know about plans to build it until the day of the protest. A department source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said an alternative measure had been taken to prevent anyone from entering the steam tunnel.
DOC.HEAD: Fines Proposed for Pacific & Southwestern Bells, Nynex
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission is recommending fines against four Bell telephone companies for accounting violations that diverted money to other telephone companies. Commission officials said after the Friday action that telephone customers were not hurt by what the companies did. The FCC sent notices of apparent liability to Pacific Bell, Southwestern Bell, New England Telephone and New York Telephone. They will be given 30 days to show why they should not pay the $250,000 fines. The commission also sent a letter of reprimand to the National Exchange Carrier Association Inc., a telephone-company operated entity that collects and distributes the ``access charges'' that long-distance companies pay local telephone companies to connect with the local networks. The association, based in Whippany, N.J., distributes access charge revenues to the local companies based on revenue and cost information reported by these companies, the FCC said. The apparent violations were discovered during an audit of the association. The Bell companies, as regulated monopolies, are allowed to earn only a fixed percentage above the costs of their investments, currently about 12 percent. After all participating companies collect their expenses from the common line pool, they claim profits from what's left over. The Bell companies make claims according to their permitted rates of return; what's left over is available for the maller companies.

DOC.HEAD: Two New Jersey Women Say Malaria Saved Them From Lyme Disease
DOC.TEXT: Two women say they were cured of Lyme disease by deliberately contracting malaria. Cyndi Monahan, 29, and Sallie Timpone, 30, both of New Jersey, said they were infected with blood tainted by a non-recurring strain of malaria at a Mexican medical college in late September. In interviews Friday from the Midwest Lyme Disease Symposium in Lincoln, Neb., the two women said they were weak, but free of pain for the first time in years, just weeks after malarial fevers wracked their bodies. Proponents of the treatment believe the malaria triggers an immune reaction that kills the bacteria causing Lyme disease. Monahan, a former body builder and aerobics instructor, had spent 2{ years curled up in a fetal position because the Lyme disease had damaged her joints. She said she developed three cancerous lesions as a result of the illness, and that her oncologist has declared her free of all signs of malignancy since her trip to Mexico. ``I was scared out of my pants,'' she said. ``I'm going to some Third World country, getting injected with malaria. But I just knew this was going to work. I feel like the Poltergeist - `She's back!' '' Timpone said her nine-year battle with the disease - transmitted by ticks - left her with symptoms of meningitis, encephalitis and other neurological disorders. Though she is confident the disease will not recur, she warns other sufferers not to rush to Mexico in a panic. Without 24-hour treatment at home for the month while the fevers rage, the therapy should not be risked, she said. Both women - two of 13 people who have tried the therapy - said they risked the treatment out of desperation. Years of antibiotic treatments did not clear up the symptoms, and both were nearly incapacitated while a stream of doctors pronounced them cured. Malaria therapy, which has not been approved for practice in the United States, was proposed as treatment for Lyme disease by Dr. Henry Heimlich, best known for the maneuver named for him used to save choking victims. In a telephone interview from Nebraska, he said he borrowed the idea from an old treatment for syphilis. Malaria therapy had been used for nearly 60 years until 1975 to treat syphilis by setting off an immune reaction and high fevers, he said. Heimlich said he thought the therapy would be effective with Lyme disease because the two illnesses are similar. Both are caused by corkscrew-shaped bacteria called spirochetes, he said. ``From all appearances from these patients, we can say that people who were severely crippled and bound to their home and could barely walk are well at this moment and are not in pain,'' he said. ``We cannot answer what percentage will have these results. I can't answer if they can be reinfected again or what will happen the rest of their lives.'' Willy Burdorfer, the research scientist credited with discovering the bacteria that causes Lyme disease, described himself as ``cautiously excited'' about the treatment. Dr. David Dennis, the physician in charge of the Lyme disease program at the federal Centers for Disease Control, said the treatment is too preliminary for him to comment on its merit.

Pentagon officials, speaking privately, said the troop buildup would likely not be completed until early next year. The additional 200,000 men and women that Bush ordered to the gulf Thursday will give the United States a clear offensive potential against Iraq which now holds an advantage in numbers of troops in the gulf area. The move also will mean a huge drain on U.S. military manpower elsewhere and thus will kill plans for relieving some weary soldiers in the gulf with fresh troops. ---= MIAMI (AP) - In a fight over freedom of the press, Cable News Network defied a federal court judge by broadcasting tapes of prison telephone calls between ousted Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega and his defense team. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler told CNN's attorneys only minutes before Friday's broadcast that he would hold the network in contempt if the tapes were played. No immediate contempt citation was issued.
